For this question, I tried subbing the values into the formula definitions and got $$a_{n}$$ < 1.75. Not sure what that value represents visually. Also I know I'm looking for N but I can't figure out how to do that. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 102, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-14T18:19:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-14T18:19:14Z", "content": "

Here you are looking for $$N$$ so that $$0.25 < a_n < 1.75$$. (i.e. the dots are stuck inside the yellow band) for ALL $$n > N$$.

The actual expression for the function was not given however so it was just a question about eyeballing when it seems like this (i.e. $$0.25 < a_n < 1.75$$) will be satisfied forever onward.

Sure between $$n\approx 8$$ to $$n \approx 12$$ it looks like we're in the yellow band but then it sneaks back out. It's not until around $$n = 45$$ onward that it's safe.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt"], "children": [], "id": "lmjhvui4w172dt", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "thank you! ", "created": "2023-09-14T20:51:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmjnb56nwk14t4", "updated": "2023-09-14T21:12:29Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmi8cd6kmqv162", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513650100, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz2"], "nr": 114, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-13T21:15:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmi8qbspkjmbz", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-13T21:15:13Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lmjiiitr7o43u9", "to": "lmi8qbsl98tby", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-14T18:36:52Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "to": "lmi8qbsl98tby", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-09-14T19:00:20Z", "cid": "lmjjcpburp237s"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "to": "lmi8qbsl98tby", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-09-15T14:40:40Z", "cid": "lmkpimwwk8f6f0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Extra Practice Chapter 2", "created": "2023-09-13T21:15:13Z", "content": "

How did the values after $$\\frac{1}{n^{2}+1}$$ get obtained?

\n

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 113, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-14T18:36:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-14T18:36:52Z", "content": "

In order to prove the limit = 0, we need $$ \\frac{1}{n^2+1} < \\epsilon$$. How do we get to there?

Okay, Note that $$n^2+1 > n^2$$, then we can get $$\\frac{1}{n^2+1} < \\frac{1}{n^2}$$. Also because $$\\forall n\\in \\mathbb{N}$$, $$n \\leq n^2$$, then $$\\frac{1}{n^2} \\leq \\frac{1}{n}$$.\u00a0

\n

We know that $$n\\geq N$$, then $$\\frac{1}{n} \\leq \\frac{1}{N}$$.
Similar logic, we know that $$N > \\frac{1}{\\epsilon}$$, then $$\\frac{1}{N} < \\epsilon$$.
By connecting those together, you will get the inequality in the screenshot. :)

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt"], "children": [], "id": "lmjiiitovvj3u8", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "This is very helpful thank you. In some of the examples in my lecture the professor never solved them like this, she solved for N in terms of epsilon. I'm just curious how we know when to solve it this way where we need to use more logical vs. just strictly solving for N in terms of eplison without changing anything and just using the fact that n>N.", "created": "2023-09-14T19:00:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I think both way works for proving a limit, it depends on personal preferences imo.", "created": "2023-09-15T14:40:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmkpimwwk8f6f0", "updated": "2023-09-15T14:40:40Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmjjcpburp237s", "updated": "2023-09-15T14:40:40Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmi8qbsl98tby", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 3, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513651163, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 97, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-17T13:51:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Khushi Jirge", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwc2gwxor57c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-17T13:51:06Z", "content": "

M represents some cutoff value, when trying to prove that the limit goes to negative infinity, we need to prove that for that cutoff value, all the other values approach negative infinity. Therefore, proving that M is greater than the sequence because all other values in the sequence will be getting smaller and smaller. 

For the example you gave it would still be approaching negative infinity, you're looking at the end behaviour not the sequence as a whole.

Hi, you can refer to the course notes from before. But here is my explanation

1-$$2^n < M, solving \: this\: we \:get: -2^n < M -1, then : 2^n > 1- M$$

Finally, we get:

$$n > log_2(1-m) = N$$

Therefore, we found cutoff N such that n > N

Hope it helps!!!

Also to clarify:

We can change the base of logs as long as they are the same.

Solving for n above we get:

n > log(1-m)/log(2). Both of them have base 10.

We can change the base to 2. Therefore log(2) turns into one. The only thing we are left with is log$$_2$$(1-m)

Hi! Let's recall that epsilon is any value that is greater than 0. Now, our sequence is 1(when perfect square) or 1/n (when anything else). To prove this, we will use a contradiction. We can pick any value for epsilon(this is important to know that we can pick any value for epsilon as long it is more than 0). 

Proof:

Let epsilon = 1/2. $$a_n$$ is 1 when n is a perfect square(eg. 4, 9), otherwise it is 1/n. 

Here is a sketch of what would happen.

We need to find a cutoff point N, after which the y-value is always in between (-epsilon, epsilon). That is impossible since there are infinitely many perfect squares. Thus, it would create a y-value of 1. Since 1>1/2(epsilon), we found a contradiction.

Hope this helps!!!

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-17T16:52:52Z", "content": "

Hello, I've had a problem understanding this too. Here is how I got it.

We can choose any epsilon or do anything to epsilon as long as it is >0. We can say 0.0000001$$\epsilon$$. As long as it is not negative. In this case, $$\sqrt L$$ was chosen since in the end, you would need the inequality to be equal to epsilon. 

For the next thing,

I am guessing you don't understand what happened on the bottom (denominator)

Basically, we ejected $$\sqrt a_n$$. We can do that since we for sure know that $$\sqrt a_n + \sqrt L < \sqrt L$$. We could do the same here for $$\sqrt a_n$$. 

Hope this helps a bit. I am not that great at explaining things.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 119, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-17T21:16:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-17T21:17:14Z", "content": "

We had similar cases like this during the lectures.

So, your initial inequality is: |1/$$\sqrt n$$ - 0| < epsilon
You need to solve this inequality in the way, such that n>N

So,

Drop the absolute value brackets(function is always positive) and solve for n

1/$$\sqrt n < \epsilon$$, then $$1/e < \sqrt n$$. Finally, $$1/\epsilon^2 < n$$

Note that N = $$1/\epsilon^2$$

Therefore, we get n>N

Hope this helps!!!

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Week 2 Practice Problem 7", "created": "2023-09-17T21:43:50Z", "content": "Can someone please explain questions 7 (a), (c), and (d)? "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wania Saqib", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwekj0scwfe", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 138, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-17T21:59:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Harbin Kaur Dhillon", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwaij6bmq2cc", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Wania Saqib", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwekj0scwfe", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-17T21:59:40Z", "content": "

Hi! 

for a) $$a_n$$ could have negative values in the sequence, depending on the equation. For example $$a_n$$ = n-10. As n increases, it will go to infinity(but still has negative values).

for c) We can take out the constant(3), then you are left with limit of $$n^2(a_n)$$

Since n ->$$\infty$$, and $$a_n \: is \:\infty$$ when $$ n-> \infty$$. Therefore, limit goes to infinity.

d) Same principle here. as limit goes to infinity, we get infinity/infinity. The answer is undefined.

I hope it helps!!

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-17T21:59:13Z", "content": "

Hi! 

So sequence $$a_n$$ is infinite. That means that subsequence has to be infinite too. Therefore, every subsequence will diverge eventually. Think of it like that:

if sequence doesn't converge, then it diverges. That also holds true for every subsequence.

I'm kinda confused with the value M represents.  Does M represent the limit of both an and bn? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 145, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-17T23:37:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Joy Zhuo", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwaqnwvj73ra", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-17T23:42:48Z", "content": "

Hi! You can think of M as some y-value. Here is a sketch for illustration, hard to explain in words...

M is a y-value that $$a_n \: and \: b_n$$ cross. In this case, $$a_n$$ crossed it twice. WE are only concerned about the last time it crosses M. You can also refer to @138 for a different answer if you'd like.

Edit:

You can also see N1 and N2 here which are cutoff points. The greatest one guarantees that the statement is true. In this case, N2 is the greatest.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 152, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-18T01:49:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmo8ahoq7x44ch", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-18T01:49:32Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "data": "lmo9q08p9m96lj", "to": "lmo8ahontwr4cg", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-18T02:29:35Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Proof of Uniqueness of Limits for Sequences", "created": "2023-09-18T01:49:32Z", "content": "
How does “at least one term must be in both intervals” come from?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 134, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-18T02:29:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Le Kong", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcluq3qmxm", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Ghazia Fatima", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwabu0902154", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-18T02:29:35Z", "content": "

If you read further, it says that intervals are disjoint. Remember, for a limit to exist, a sequence (precisely, a tail of a sequence) needs to converge to some L or M. We know that tail is infinite in this case. However, some finite values omitted from the beginning of a sequence(eg.  if $$a_n = \{1, 2, 3, 4 ... n\}$$, a tail could be {5, 6, 7, 8 ... n}). So, if limits are not unique, you would find at least one value of a tail that is in both intervals after a cutoff point. This can't be true since limit intervals are disjoint.

The book explanation is a bit complicated:

Think of it like this:

FOr a limit to exist, there should be a tail that converges to some value after a cutoff(in other words - forever). It simply can't converge to two different values at the same time. 

I hope this isn't too complicated!

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwcluq3qmxm", "lkqwabu0902154"], "children": [], "id": "lmo9q08l78m6li", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmo8ahontwr4cg", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513691729, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I was wondering if we are also able to prove these statements wrong mathematically by using the formal definition of a limit approaching infinity or is a counter example sufficient."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 121, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-18T23:43:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Shreeya Santha", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdjis2njc7", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-18T23:43:40Z", "content": "

Hi! I believe that formal definition of a limit requires the value of a limit to be a fixed value(according to the textbook). Therefore, formal definition of a limit shouldn't work here. Since you don't know the equation for both sequences, the only way (as i see it) is to provide a counterexample.

Hope it helps!!

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdjis2njc7"], "children": [], "id": "lmpj8hqmh3124t", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-19T06:46:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-19T06:49:51Z", "content": "Counter example is sufficient and is probably the most effective way to disprove it :)"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-19T06:46:47Z", "content": "

Counter example is sufficient.

In fact, using counter example in this case is a lot faster than using formal definition of limit.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz2"], "nr": 157, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-18T23:42:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmpj6mwibtp3mp", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-18T23:42:14Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "data": "lmpjabpmxy36b0", "to": "lmpj6mwfrqi3mo", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-18T23:45:06Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "data": "lmpjb4u8c9hat", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-09-18T23:45:44Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Week 2 Practice Problems - Question 5b", "created": "2023-09-18T23:42:14Z", "content": "

I am not sure if my approach for 5b (in order to prove L$$\leq$$M), is correct..

I assumed that L+$$\varepsilon$$$$< M+\varepsilon$$

Then I subsituted L=M+d in for L and simplified

I got d<0 which can't be true since d must be positive 

Therefore, I arrive at a contradiction. 

Can someone correct me please? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 118, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-18T23:45:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Deeksha Khullar", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwb4avaj4657", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-18T23:45:44Z", "content": "

Hi! You made a slight mistake with a negative sign. The inequality should be:

$$L - \epsilon < M + \epsilon$$

Therefore,

$$M + d - \epsilon < M + \epsilon$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-18T23:45:06Z", "content": "

Hi! You made a slight mistake with a negative sign. The inequality should be:

$$L - \epsilon < M + \epsilon$$

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwb4avaj4657"], "children": [], "id": "lmpjabpjljd6az", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmpj6mwfrqi3mo", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513697207, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Which means, if $$\\lim_{n->\\infty} a_n = L$$, not only you can find N which $$|a_n-L|< \\epsilon$$, you can also find N which $$|a_n-L|< x \\epsilon$$ where $$x > 0$$.

Now we want to prove $$\\lim_{n->\\infty} \\sqrt a_n = \\sqrt L$$. Which means, we want $$|\\sqrt a_n - \\sqrt L|< \\epsilon$$. So, what value of x in $$|a_n-L|< x \\epsilon$$\u00a0 we need to make this inequality work ?"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmqk34x64l61k", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "why is $$\\sqrt{L}$$ tho? im a bit confused on how its such a simple answer. $$|\\sqrt{a_n} - \\sqrt{L}| = |(\\sqrt{a_n} - \\sqrt{L})\\dfrac{(\\sqrt{a_n} + \\sqrt{L})}{\\sqrt{a_n} + \\sqrt{L}}| = \\dfrac{|a_n - L|}{\\sqrt{a_n} + \\sqrt{L}} < \\dfrac{|a_n - L|}{\\sqrt{L}} < \\dfrac{\\sqrt{L}\\epsilon}{\\sqrt{L}} = \\epsilon$$", "created": "2023-09-19T22:27:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Alex Fang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw9182jfyvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Jayden DeSouza", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcef64b7ck", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqw9182jfyvy", "lkqwcef64b7ck"], "id": "lmqvyj68kek6tc", "updated": "2023-09-20T19:55:42Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmqv2y39wga2p", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-09-19T22:27:38Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmqao1n43iq7is", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 7, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513701552, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Here, you just need to consider the largest powers of $$n$$ in the numerator and denominator.", "created": "2023-09-19T14:26:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt"], "id": "lmqesf766343e3", "updated": "2023-09-19T14:27:22Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmqchu51fyb5g1", "updated": "2023-09-19T14:26:59Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "The largest power resides in the denominator (n^2) so the limit is 0. Alternatively, you can use the factoring the numerator and denominator strategy. You only use formal definition to prove the limit, not find it.", "created": "2023-09-19T14:03:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "How do you factor the numerator and denominator when they have +1 and -1?", "created": "2023-09-19T14:06:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmqe2b60fub6z", "updated": "2023-09-19T14:06:40Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "To prove you still need to solve for n in terms of epsilon and I'm not sure how that is possible.", "created": "2023-09-19T14:08:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmqe4gdo3aq4d1", "updated": "2023-09-19T14:08:20Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

The question doesn't ask you to prove for epsilon, unless you want to, that's a different story. All you gotta do is find the limit.

To factor, let's factor the top and bottom by n^2. You get $$\frac{n^{-0.5}+n^{-1}+n^{-2}}{1+n^{-1.5}-n^{-2}}$$. Since all of the terms on the numerator approach to zero, and all of the terms except the 1 in the denominator (formerly n^2) approach 0, you are left with 0/1 which is 0.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 163, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-19T13:57:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ktd0gqt5nhy2ei", "data": "lmqdr39rrkm2o", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-19T13:57:56Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hl8fubeco7s4c0", "to": "lmqdr39ojbs2n", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-09-19T14:19:20Z", "cid": "lmqeilsknyc1wz"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ktd0gqt5nhy2ei", "subject": "Seeking Math Enthusiasts for Key Clues Challenge Team!", "created": "2023-09-19T13:57:56Z", "content": "

Hey everyone,

I hope this message finds you well! I wanted to share an exciting opportunity that has come up – the University of Waterloo Key Clues Challenge. It's a University-wide puzzle hunt event, and I'm looking to form a team of dedicated math students who are eager to crack this case!

The challenge involves solving puzzles and clues, and I'm specifically on the lookout for individuals with experience in coding, cryptography, steganography, and related fields. If you're a serious math student with a passion for puzzles and possess skills in these areas, you're exactly who I'm looking for!

Don't worry; I'm known for being nice to people and fostering a collaborative atmosphere.

Together, we can put our mathematical and technical skills to the test and emerge victorious in this thrilling event. To find out more about the Key Clues Challenge, you can visit the official website here: Key Clues Challenge Website.

I'd love to meet potential teammates and discuss our strategy before the kickoff event, which is scheduled for September 21 from 2:00pm to 3:30pm in the DC Fishbowl. It's the perfect opportunity to get to know each other and start planning our approach.

If you're interested in joining forces and embarking on this exciting adventure, please feel free to reach out to me at either of the following email addresses: jeremie.notebaert@gmail.com or jnotebae@uwaterloo.ca. Let's put our math, coding, and cryptography skills to the test and have a blast while doing it!

Looking forward to meeting my future teammates and conquering the challenge together!

Sincerely,
     - Jeremie Notebaert

Oh you just try all the values x belongs to real numbers one by one and eventually you will find the value which works! Very efficient frfr! 

*Cough cough* Jokes aside, for these kind of question, you actually solve those inequality in the end. I personally prefer the first way more than the alternative solution, not only it's simpler but also it can actually help you solve the inequality.

In the beginning I will write all the necessary stuff, but leave N > ________ blank. Cause that is what I am trying to solve. Then I will just establish the inequality as part of my solution:


Okay now, in order to prove the limit is correct,  we need $$|a_n - L| < \epsilon$$. That implies we need $$\frac{2}{N+1} < \epsilon$$. I just solve this inequality to get $$N > \frac{2}{\epsilon} -1$$. I fill the blank and finish up my proof. Done. *Throws pen on the table*

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz1"], "nr": 170, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-19T22:14:20Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lmqvhg1goay431", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-19T22:14:20Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "to": "lmqvhg1dape430", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-09-19T22:47:35Z", "cid": "lmqwo7ggrlz3yk"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "Quiz 1 Results Now Available", "created": "2023-09-19T22:14:20Z", "content": "

Quiz 1 marking is now complete and you can see your results in Crowdmark.

Recall that Crowdmark erroneously increases the denominator of your score. Your actual percentage grade can be found in the LEARN gradebook.

In the event you feel the TA marked your quiz incorrectly, you can request a re-mark. Note that the entire quiz will be re-marked. This means your mark could decrease, stay the same, or increase. If you are still interested in having your quiz re-marked, please email math137@uwaterloo.ca. In your re-mark request, you must explain where you think the TA made an error. It is not enough to say that you feel you deserve more credit; there must have been an error in the marking!

You are not likely to get any reply to your email but rather a bulk message will be sent once all re-marks are complete. 

The deadline for re-mark requests is Tuesday, September 26th, 1 pm. Any late requests will not be accepted.

"}], "type": "note", "tags": ["instructor-note", "pin", "quiz1"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 505, "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

A quick follow up:

If you wrote version A, it is intended that 51 -- 55 are automatically graded as "incorrect."

If you wrote version B, it is intended that 1 -- 5 are automatically graded as "incorrect."

However, this does not have an impact on your score. Specifically, notice that on Crowdmark, he quiz is out of 30 points and on LEARN the quiz is out of 22 points. The additional 8 points are coming from the "extra" MC/TF question between the two versions (i.e., 51 -- 55 for version A and 1 -- 5 for version B). That is, if you scored 8/16 on the MC/TF section, you actually scored 8/8 and this will be reflected in the LEARN gradebook.

Thus, the "incorrect" answers on the bubble sheet as described above do not impact your actual grade since they are not actually counted against you.

In Practice problems 2 Q2 a) in order to contradict the statement, 3 sequences are chosen to fulfil the inequality 

$$an \leq bn \leq cn$$

While I kind of understand the choice of -1, 1, and sin(n) for the purposes of the question I am still confused as to how one sequence can be considered "less than" another in other cases.

Is the sequence {n} less than {$$n^{2}$$}? How would you know considering they both grow without bound? What about two completely different kinds of sequences like {$$2^{n}$$} and {$$n^{2}-2n+1$$} ? What exactly constitutes a sequence being greater than/less than another?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 102, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-20T00:29:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-20T00:29:28Z", "content": "The nth term in sequence a is less than nth term in b and nth term in c. "}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmr0b8x2plb28e", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Followup to the student's answer:

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other", "quiz2"], "nr": 184, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-20T01:24:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmr2ag62nug4ex", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-20T01:24:50Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lmr2cavt3nrpe", "to": "lmr2ag5zwv14ew", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-20T01:26:17Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lmr2sadxg9h4bh", "to": "lmr2ag5zwv14ew", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-20T01:38:43Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "why the aside is 2/N^N", "created": "2023-09-20T01:24:50Z", "content": ""}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 115, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-20T01:26:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-20T01:26:17Z", "content": "why the aside is 2/N^N <E but not 2/(N^N +4)< E"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmr2cavpfnkpd", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-20T01:38:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jie Yang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwabr0j5p14l", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-20T01:38:43Z", "content": "

I did a "trick:" $$\\dfrac{4}{2N^2 + 8} < \\dfrac{4}{2N^2}$$ and then did the aside.

\n

\n

Note this isn't necessary: you could do the aside with $$\\dfrac{2}{N^2+4} < \\epsilon$$. There's nothing wrong with this, it just gives a somewhat uglier $$N$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwabr0j5p14l"], "children": [], "id": "lmr2sadwajm4bg", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmr2ag5zwv14ew", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513726223, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz2"], "nr": 185, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-20T02:28:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmr4jr0pvtw2u9", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-20T02:28:04Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "data": "lmr6o12xb1y28q", "to": "lmr4jr0n9pk2u8", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-20T03:27:23Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "definition about an", "created": "2023-09-20T02:28:04Z", "content": "When can we assume {an} is a sequence of natural numbers? if not why does the definition of limit indicate that N belongs to natural numbers?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 97, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-20T03:27:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-20T03:27:23Z", "content": "the definition of the limit says that $$N \\in \\mathbb{N}$$ because N represents a term of the sequence. for example, if i had the sequence $$\\{ 2,4,6,8,...\\}$$ then 2 would be the first term, 4 would be the second term, and so on. It doesn't make sense to have a term that is not a natural number. For example, there is no -2 term of a sequence or no 0.2 term of a sequence. Since N represents a\u00a0term of the sequence, it must be a natural number. Whether or not $$\\{ a_n\\}$$ is a sequence of natural numbers depends on the function that defines the sequence. if $$a_n=n$$, the sequence will just be 1,2,3,4,... and the sequence will consist of only natural numbers ($$f:n\\rightarrow \\mathbb{N}$$). if $$a_n=\\frac{1}{n}$$, the sequence will be $$1, 1/2, 1/3, ...$$ and will not just consist of natural numbers ($$f:n\\rightarrow \\mathbb {R}$$)."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmr6o12ujce28p", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmr4jr0n9pk2u8", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513727289, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz2"], "nr": 206, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-20T20:20:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lms6urjt56n2zw", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-20T20:20:23Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lms7rs4r1jd549", "to": "lms6urjq8hz2zv", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-20T20:46:03Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lms7u6xu4pj2qe", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-09-20T20:47:56Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lms7vj6cmp25dn", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-09-20T20:48:58Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lms7wv1gry5kp", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-09-20T20:50:00Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lms7xc4ymfl1pf", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-09-20T20:50:23Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Mobius Question", "created": "2023-09-20T20:20:23Z", "content": "

How are we supposed to solve this question? Isolating n takes a long time, and so does substituting the answers into the equation. What is the intended solution?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 140, "children": [{"history_size": 5, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-20T20:46:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "David-Nuo Cheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-20T20:50:23Z", "content": "

@187 @159

Basically, you're supposed to solve it like a quadratic. You end up getting a quadratic like "εn² + (ε-2)n - 1 > 0".

Note that, if you imagine a parabola in your head, there are two areas where εn² + (ε-2)n - 1 > 0 (we will deal with this later).

Plug into the quadratic formula.

$$\frac{\sqrt{\epsilon^2+4)}-\epsilon + 2}{2\epsilon}$$

Note that we get two solutions, the positive square root, and the negative square root. The negative square root is extraneous (we know that the negative solution is less than 0 using the geometric fact that the hypotenuse is the longest side of a triangle i.e. $$\sqrt{\epsilon^2+2^2} > 2$$ so $$\sqrt{\epsilon^2+2^2} > 2-\epsilon$$, and $$n \geq 1$$ so negative solution is not possible).

Then you can basically just cross out incorrect answers (need answers of N that are greater than $$\frac{\sqrt{\epsilon^2+4)}-\epsilon + 2}{2\epsilon}$$).

This is a bit of a longer question so don't worry too much if it takes a while.

{"history_size": 4, "folders": ["quiz3"], "nr": 221, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-23T23:55:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmwoubgmwzhgy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-23T23:55:00Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lmwovak9sed22p", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2023-09-23T23:55:45Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lmwowfd1wat3v6", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2023-09-23T23:56:38Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lmwoxltgjv35jy", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2023-09-23T23:57:33Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "data": "lmxqq0141kt6uc", "to": "lmwoubgjkpdgx", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-24T17:35:24Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Week 3 Practice Problems Q1", "created": "2023-09-23T23:57:33Z", "content": "

In Q1 for Week 3's Practice Problems, the intended solution applies squeeze theorem to $$a_n \text{sin}(n) + b_n \text{cos}(n)$$ as a whole.

Instead, are we allowed to use squeeze theorem for $$a_n \text{sin}(n)$$ and $$b_n \text{cos}(n)$$ separately and use the arithmetic rules for limits of sequences to add them up to get $$0$$? I.e, $$-a_n \le a_n\text{sin}(n) \le a_n$$ and similarly for $$b_ncos(n)$$.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Week 3 Practice Problems Q1", "created": "2023-09-23T23:56:38Z", "content": "

In Q1 for Week 3's Practice Problems, the intended solution applies squeeze theorem to $$a_n sin(n) + b_n cos(n)$$ as a whole.

Instead, are we allowed to use squeeze theorem for $$a_n sin(n)$$ and $$b_n cos(n)$$ separately and use the arithmetic rules for limits of sequences to add them up to get $$0$$? I.e, $$-a_n \le a_nsin(n) \le a_n$$ and similiarly for $$b_ncos(n)$$.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Week 3 Practice Problems Q1", "created": "2023-09-23T23:55:45Z", "content": "

In Q1 for Week 3's Practice Problems, the intended solution applies squeeze theorem to $$a_n sin(n) + b_n cos(n)$$ as a whole.

Instead, are we allowed to use squeeze theorem for $$a_n sin(n)$$ and $$b_n cos(n)$$ separately and use the arithmetic rules for limits of sequences to add them up to get $$0$$?

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Week 3 Practice Problems Q1", "created": "2023-09-23T23:55:00Z", "content": "In Q1 for Week 3's Practice Problems, the intended solution applies squeeze theorem to $$a_n sin(n) + b_n cos(n)$$ as a whole."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz3", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Michael Volovyk", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwd3xnhyi5aw", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 92, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-24T17:35:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-24T17:35:24Z", "content": "

Yes, you can do it separately.

For $$a_n$$sin(n)

$$-a_n\leq a_nsin(n)\leq a_n$$

For $$b_ncos(n)$$

$$-b_n\leq b_ncos(n)\leq b_n$$

Both are 0, then you can use limit rules to solve it.

For the sake of learning, you should try doing it with squeeze theorem."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmxqkn3vgw33zj", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-24T21:50:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-24T21:50:52Z", "content": "

You can only use the squeeze theorem here.

The arithmetic rules for limits (aka "limit rules") theorem requires that $$\lim a_n$$ and $$\lim b_n$$ to exist before you can do $$\lim a_n b_n = \lim a_n \lim b_n$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 224, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-24T15:26:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmxm3v5a3dt7r", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-24T15:26:13Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "data": "lmxqj16i6nfxt", "to": "lmxm3v57aw27q", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-24T17:29:59Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "data": "lmxqjnq56ue20r", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-09-24T17:30:28Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "data": "lmxqrt39io02hq", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-09-24T17:36:48Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Squeeze Theorem Question", "created": "2023-09-24T15:26:13Z", "content": "

Hello, with squeeze theorem how do you know which limits to use on the side? I.e for both of these examples, how does one know the values have to be 6 and 8 or 1/n^2 and -1/n^2? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 100, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-24T17:29:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Maliha Ahmed", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "k0nwvpb1pzxra", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Zhenghong Chen", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": "1690993275_200.jpg", "id": "lkqwe7nglje5q8", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/lkqwe7nglje5q8/1690993275_200.jpg", "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Emma C", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwaf36re71ph", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "David-Nuo Cheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Ghazia Fatima", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwabu0902154", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-24T17:36:48Z", "content": "

Think of it like this:

For first example we start with cos($$n^2$$ + 7)

We know that $$-1\leq cos(n)\leq1$$. Note, we don't care what is inside cos

Add 7: $$6\leq cos(n)+7\leq 8$$

Divide by n

$$\frac{6}{n}\leq \frac{cos(n)+7}{n}\leq \frac{8}{n}$$

Example 2:

Start with $$(-1)^{n+1}$$. It is either -1 or 1

Hence: $$-1\leq(-1)^{n+1}\leq1$$

Divide by $$n^2$$

$$\frac{-1}{n^2}\leq \frac{(-1)^{n+1}}{n^2}\leq\frac{1}{n^2}$$

Essentially, you need to find some function inside the equation that is guaranteed to have upper and lower bound. Then you can use them as the "anchor" to use the squeeze theorem.

Hope that helps!

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-24T17:30:28Z", "content": "

It is always decreasing. 

Take n = 1, then sin($$\frac{pi}{4}$$)

The larger the n is, the smaller the value in sin. Therefore, it is always decreasing. I am too lazy to check, but it should be getting closer and closer to zero as n goes to infinity.

Hope it helps!

\n

How could this be bounded below and not bounded at the same time? Is it due to the n that diverge when n is even?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz3"], "nr": 230, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-25T19:29:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmza89n0s896gt", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-25T19:29:15Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lmzkkclmg094j1", "to": "lmza89mwxnv6gs", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-26T00:18:35Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": ""convergent" or "divergent" and "bounded above" or "bounded below" and "monotonic"", "created": "2023-09-25T19:29:15Z", "content": "

I am just curious if there are some rules applied to the relationship between "convergent" or "divergent" and "bounded above" or "bounded below" and monotonicity.

I understand that from MCT, we have if an converges if and only if it is bounded above which means that we can interpret from either direction. Does this also indicate that this sequence is monotonic?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T00:18:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-26T00:18:35Z", "content": "

Most of these are separate concepts.


For example, a sequence can be bounded below and diverge (e.g., $$a_n = n$$, or it converge (e.g., $$a_n = -\frac{1}{n}$$). Similarly for monotonic.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmzkkclj2ky4j0", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmza89mwxnv6gs", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513775963, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz3"], "nr": 231, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-25T19:32:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmzacsvbcou2t9", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-25T19:32:47Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lmzfxm912eu36i", "to": "lmzacsv8ve32t8", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-25T22:08:56Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lmzacsv8ve32t8", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-09-25T22:09:46Z", "cid": "lmzfyoxu1wa5rz", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lmzkhif4dxc6ew", "to": "lmzacsv8ve32t8", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-26T00:16:22Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lmzkhs6c6x16xz", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2023-09-26T00:16:35Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "week3 Monotone Convergence Theorem", "created": "2023-09-25T19:32:47Z", "content": "

__2023-09-25_15.30.38.png

Can someone explain these three true or false questions with explanations and examples? Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 77, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-25T22:08:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-25T22:08:56Z", "content": "For the first one you have to take into consideration MTC which says that if a sequence in bounded then it will converge."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmzfxm8xubd36h", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "The second one is false you can prove with a counterexample ", "created": "2023-09-25T22:09:46Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmzfyoxu1wa5rz", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-09-25T22:10:02Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T00:16:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-26T00:16:35Z", "content": "

Careful, a bounded sequence doesn't necessarily converge. For example, $$(-1)^n$$ is bounded (below by $$-1$$ and above by $$1$$) and diverges.

The MCT requires that a sequence be monotonic and bounded (either above or below depending on whether it's non-decr/non-incr) to conclude it converges.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-26T00:16:22Z", "content": "

Careful, a bounded sequence doesn't necessarily converge. For example, $(-1)^n$ is bounded (below by -1 and above by +1) and diverges.

The MCT requires that a sequence be monotonic and bounded (either above or below depending on whether it's non-decr/non-incr) to conclude it converges.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt"], "children": [], "id": "lmzkhif3le6eu", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmzacsv8ve32t8", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513777025, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz3"], "nr": 233, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-25T20:01:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lmzbe21jipd6f6", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-25T20:01:45Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lmzftygvuml18x", "to": "lmzbe21fb2r6f4", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-09-25T22:06:05Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lmzbe21fb2r6f4", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-09-25T22:28:52Z", "cid": "lmzgn9e2iea1ru", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lmzhgg9r5uk5k2", "to": "lmzbe21fb2r6f4", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-25T22:51:34Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Proving a sequence is increasing and bounded above at the same time", "created": "2023-09-25T20:01:45Z", "content": "

Hello,

In Q4 and Q5 of week 3 problems, the solutions prove a sequence is increasing and bounded above separately, using induction twice. Can you prove both at the same time, as shown below?

Q4. a

Base Case:

$$a_2 = 8/6 > a_1 = 1$$. Thus, $$a_1 < a_2 \leq 2$$ in the base case.

Inductive hypothesis:

Assume $$a_k < a_{k+1} \leq 2$$ for some fixed $$k$$.

Inductive Step:

$$a_k + 7 < a_{k+1} + 7 \leq 9$$ 

$$\frac{a_k + 7}{6} < \frac{a_{k+1} + 7}{6} \leq \frac{9}{6}$$ 

$$a_{k+1} < a_{k+2} \leq \frac{3}{2} \leq 2$$ as required.

Is this valid? Thank you.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-25T22:06:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-25T22:06:05Z", "content": "But I don't think this shows that it is increasing, only that it is bounded?"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmzftygqhll18w", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Regarding the students' answer, doesn't it show that $$a_{k+1} > a_{k}$$ for all $$k \geq 1$$? The base case shows it is increasing for $$a_2 > a_1$$ and the inductive step shows this pattern continues, i.e. $$a_k < a_{k+1} < a_{k+2} < a_{k+3} \ ...$$ for all $$k \geq 1$$.", "created": "2023-09-25T22:28:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "ta", "name": "David-Nuo Cheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["kcat0wu2cik59z"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmzgn9e2iea1ru", "updated": "2023-09-25T22:53:06Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-25T22:51:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vikas Nibhanupudi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwenjljntyg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-25T22:51:34Z", "content": "I believe you can."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwenjljntyg"], "children": [], "id": "lmzhgg9qx3m5k1", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lmzbe21fb2r6f4", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513779170, "default_anonymity": "no"}

In this case, we suppose $$0 < a_k < a_{k+1}$$ holds. In order for the inductive step to be true, we need to prove $$ 0 < a_{k+1} < a_{k+2}$$ holds as well. This is the standard format for proving the inductive hypothesis."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lmzf2cuy8co601", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Okay thank you. I think this sequence is obvious enough that $$\lim_{n->\infty} a_n = 3$$. Then by formal definition of limit, you can always find a cutoff N s.t.  $$\forall n \geq N, |a_n - 3| < \frac{1}{5}$$.

EDIT: it should be $$\frac{1}{5}$$, the original was typo D:", "created": "2023-09-25T22:12:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmzg1mfrqdn3s4", "updated": "2023-09-25T22:19:46Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Ohhh okay! Was the choice for 1/15 arbitrary?", "created": "2023-09-25T22:13:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmzg3fhp5ph2a4", "updated": "2023-09-25T22:13:27Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Thank you so much!", "created": "2023-09-25T22:13:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmzg3o1lv8j2y9", "updated": "2023-09-25T22:13:38Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

", "created": "2023-09-25T22:18:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmzg9s7kgm54pz", "updated": "2023-09-25T22:18:23Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "well, $$|3 - \frac{14}{5}| = \frac{1}{5}$$.

2.99 is not an upper bound because you can find a term in the sequence which is greater than 2.99. 

1 is glb is because we are talking about the entire sequence here, but $$\frac{14}{5}$$ is glb for a tail of sequence, which not all terms are included. ", "created": "2023-09-25T22:21:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmzgdjz8zvd3by", "updated": "2023-09-25T22:21:19Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I'm sorry I'm very lost with what you mean by |3- 14/5| = 1/5. 

What is the difference when calculating the glb of a tail and of the entire sequence?

", "created": "2023-09-25T22:24:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lmzghl2heqa2tl", "updated": "2023-09-25T22:24:27Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

$$|3 - \frac{14}{5}| = \frac{1}{5}$$ is to show how I get $$\frac{1}{5}$$. 

glb of the tail might be different of glb of the entire sequence. Reason being, some of the terms at the beginning of the sequence might be bigger than the glb of the tail.

Consider the sequence $$a_n = -\frac{1}{n}$$. The glb of the entire sequence is -1. However, let's say there is a sequence $$b_m$$ which is the tail of $$a_n$$ starting from n = 10. so $$b_1 = -\frac{1}{10}$$, $$b_2 = -\frac{1}{11}$$, and so on. Then for this tail of $$a_n$$, the glb is $$-\frac{1}{10}$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz3"], "nr": 245, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T14:46:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ln0fkmtp3ordb", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-26T14:46:36Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "data": "ln0xo26ixzg5p7", "to": "ln0fkmtmdwhda", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-26T23:13:09Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ln0fkmtmdwhda", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-09-26T23:25:48Z", "cid": "ln0y4bpklb86mk", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "to": "ln0fkmtmdwhda", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-09-27T11:57:52Z", "cid": "ln1ozhh68du7a3"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ln0fkmtmdwhda", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-09-27T12:03:25Z", "cid": "ln1p6mr5q816zz", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Mod Quiz 3 question", "created": "2023-09-26T14:46:36Z", "content": "For this question here how would you go about picking the an and bn for the squeeze theorem? "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 72, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T23:13:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-26T23:13:09Z", "content": "

You are told (and it is sort of evident) that $$b_n > 0$$ so what is left is to find a $$c_n$$ that goes to $$0$$ that is larger than $$b_n$$.

For example $$c_n = \frac{2}{n}$$ would be ok. Anything bigger than (or equal to) $$\frac{1}{n}$$ is fine.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ln0xo26ft5l5p6", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "so will 1/n and 1/n^2 be an and bn? and the choice for cn is chosen afterwards? And if so how do we know which is which for an and bc?", "created": "2023-09-26T23:25:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

In this case $$b_n$$ is a piecewise sequence that has both $$\frac{1}{n}$$ and $$\frac{1}{n^2}$$.

This means that $$a_n = 0$$ and $$c_n$$ should be any sequence whose values are larger than (or equal to $$b_n$$). Since $$\frac{1}{n} > \frac{1}{n^2}$$ then you need to pick your $$c_n$$ so that it's larger than (or equal to) $$\frac{1}{n}$$

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz3"], "nr": 266, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T23:29:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ln0y91evosh1ex", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-09-26T23:29:28Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "ln1yon25bk1708", "to": "ln0y91es16d1ev", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-09-27T16:29:22Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Boundness", "created": "2023-09-26T23:29:28Z", "content": "Is the only way to determine if a sequence is bounded is to plug numbers in? or is there a more systematic precise way of determining the boundeness?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz3", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Oluwafadekemi Odu-onikosi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llnqx80eduxbu", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Awais Choudhary", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8qaa37q6q2", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 108, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-27T16:29:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ghazia Fatima", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwabu0902154", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-27T16:29:22Z", "content": "Well if you know the sequence is monotonic, then you already know it's bounded either below or above. For the side which you are trying to see if it's bounded, The standard way is you calculate the first few terms of the sequence and you will have a brief idea if a sequence converges or not. If you know think bounded then you can try prove it using induction (recursive sequence) or other limit rules."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwabu0902154"], "children": [], "id": "ln1yon22mvj707", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["llnqx80eduxbu", "lkqw8qaa37q6q2"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ln0y91es16d1ev", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513814631, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 98, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-26T23:52:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-27T15:03:40Z", "content": "Consider $$a_n = -1, b_n = cos(n\\pi), c_n = 1$$. Limit of $$b_n$$ DNE."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-26T23:52:53Z", "content": "Consider $$a_n = -1, b_n = sin(n\\pi), c_n = 1$$. Limit of $$b_n$$ DNE."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ln0z35oxf9349", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Then why C is incorrect?", "created": "2023-09-27T02:32:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I have figured out this, never mind. But why if\u00a0bn=sin(n\u03c0)
, limit of\u00a0c\u00a0limit of\u00a0bn DNE? Isn\u2019t it always equal to 0 if n is a natural number?", "created": "2023-09-27T02:43:52Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ln157141osh2j", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-09-27T02:43:52Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Do you mind explaining why c is incorrect?", "created": "2023-09-27T13:32:12Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ln1scstxb9n2ij", "updated": "2023-09-27T13:32:12Z", "config": {"editor": "plain"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Yeah it should be $$cos(n\\pi)$$. Nice catch :)

C is incorrect because consider the following counter example: $$a_n = \\frac{1}{n^3}, b_n = \\frac {1}{n^2}, c_n = \\frac{1}{n}$$. You will get $$0 \\leq \\frac{1}{n^2} \\leq 0$$, which is false.\u00a0

Can someone give me a counterexample because I was having trouble thinking of one", "created": "2023-09-27T16:30:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

For example,

Say you have $$\frac{1}{n^3}\leq \frac{1}{n^2}\leq \frac{1}{n}$$

So, this would mean,

$$\lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{1}{n^3} \leq \frac{1}{n^2}\leq \lim_{x\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}$$

i.e.

$$0 \leq \frac{1}{n^2}\leq 0$$

Which is false because $$\frac{1}{n^2}\geq 0$$ for all n.

", "created": "2023-09-27T03:30:37Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwehero027lg", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ln16v5je6fn7jr", "updated": "2023-09-27T03:30:37Z", "config": {}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I think you just have to plug in numbers and see where it goes\u00a0", "created": "2023-09-27T12:54:42Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ln1r0kh9pyz4on", "updated": "2023-09-27T12:54:42Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ln16q9kmxyb665", "updated": "2023-09-27T15:18:41Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-27T14:53:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-27T14:53:07Z", "content": "Technically, if the question wants you to prove that $$a_n$$ is\u00a0
monotonic and converges, then you know this sequence has a limit. If you calculate the limit for this question you should get either L = 1 or L = 2. L = 1 won't work as a limit so the limit is L = 2.

Note that, if you use 1 as the lower bound, you can also prove the sequence is lower bounded, by mathematical induction."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ln1v8vd8wou4de", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "How do we know that the limit can\u2019t be 1 though?", "created": "2023-09-27T14:55:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "If you write a few terms out, you will realize that the sequence is becoming 1 + root of root of root of (we ignore 7470402810381820x "root of" here) 2. and the root of that whole thing approaches to 1, so you already kinda have the idea that the sum can't be less than 2.", "created": "2023-09-27T14:59:38Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yilin", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwam6q3i52z9", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwam6q3i52z9"], "id": "ln1vh8pi8l05xx", "updated": "2023-09-27T15:19:23Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I see. I would assume that this is as n approaches positive infinity.

As n approaches positive infinity, the part inside the cos() approaches pi.

Therefore, a_n approaches cos(pi) as n approaches positive infinity.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["llnqx80eduxbu", "lkqwabu0902154", "ixjsn8icw2y1c3"], "children": [], "id": "ln28w59ltwk6z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ln28mt6u4c12vr", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513841420, "default_anonymity": "no"}

C is true by the MCT, but looking at b, if it never increases or decreases, then the sequence is constant.

Since the sequence is constant, it would also converge.

Why doesn't it converge?

Is 0 considered a natural number? I've been reviewing my notes because I'm getting confused but I can't find any explicit statements about it.\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 122, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-28T20:11:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-28T20:11:31Z", "content": "No it is not"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ln3m26nn3jb73r", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-09-28T20:44:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Anika Smith", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Ghazia Fatima", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwabu0902154", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-09-28T20:44:24Z", "content": "For MATH 137, 0 is not natural number.\u00a0

I think it is strange that somehow mathematics field doesn't not universally agree if 0 is natural number or not. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz3"], "nr": 297, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-01T07:14:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ln74m8s0ngt766", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-01T07:14:19Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ln76jsvzu532o4", "to": "ln74m8rwurc765", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-10-01T08:08:24Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ln76p7wid5a6q2", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-10-01T08:12:37Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ln76q4ls91o7hy", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-10-01T08:13:19Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ln76r77rn7omc", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-10-01T08:14:09Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "QUIZ 3A (TF) Q2", "created": "2023-10-01T07:14:19Z", "content": "The question was "If a sequence converges, then it is bounded" and the answer to that was "True". I have a little misconception about that. I thought a sequence could converge if it it was increasing and bounded above.(and not necessarily bounded below, making it non bounded). Wouldn't that mean that a convergent sequence does not have to be bounded? "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz3", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Celina Peixoto", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8y3558fcp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Ismail Hosny", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwa900l7one", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 127, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-01T08:08:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Emma C", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwaf36re71ph", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-01T08:14:09Z", "content": "

If a sequence converges, then we know there is an $$\epsilon > 0$$ such that aₙ$$\epsilon \left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$ (i.e. all of the rest of the function after some n is contained within this interval). This means you can just find the number that is the lowest for non-decreasing functions and call that the greatest upper bound (or highest for non-increasing functions, and say that's the lowest upper bound). I.e. there aren't an infinite number of points outside of this interval so surely one of them must be the lowest (or highest) (or in a case where aₙ is entirely contained within $$\left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$, just find the point in the interval or say $$L-\epsilon$$/$$L+\epsilon $$ is a lower bound/upper bound respectively).

So now we have identified both a greatest lower bound and lowest upper bound. Therefore, the function is bounded.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-01T08:13:19Z", "content": "

If a sequence converges, then we know for all $$\epsilon > 0$$ such that aₙ$$\epsilon \left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$ (i.e. all of the rest of the function after some n is contained within this interval). This means you can just find the number that is the lowest for non-decreasing functions and call that the greatest upper bound (or highest for non-increasing functions, and say that's the lowest upper bound). I.e. there aren't an infinite number of points outside of this interval so surely one of them must be the lowest (or highest) (or in a case where aₙ is entirely contained within $$\left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$, just find the point in the interval or say $$L-\epsilon$$/$$L+\epsilon $$ is a lower bound/upper bound respectively).

So now we have identified both a greatest lower bound and lowest upper bound. Therefore, the function is bounded.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-01T08:12:37Z", "content": "

This means you can just find the number that is the lowest for non-decreasing functions and call that the greatest upper bound (or highest for non-increasing functions, and say that's the lowest upper bound). I.e. there aren't an infinite number of points outside of this interval so surely one of them must be the lowest (or highest) (or in a case where aₙ is entirely contained within $$\left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$, just find the point in the interval or say $$L-\epsilon$$/$$L+\epsilon $$ is a lower bound/upper bound respectively).

So now we have identified both a greatest lower bound and lowest upper bound. Therefore, the function is bounded.
