If a sequence converges, then there is always an $$\epsilon > 0$$ such that aₙ$$\epsilon \left ( L-\epsilon, L+\epsilon \right )$$ (i.e. all of the rest of the function after some n is contained within this interval). This means you can just find the number that is the lowest for non-decreasing functions and call that the greatest upper bound (or highest for non-increasing functions, and say that's the lowest upper bound). I.e. there aren't an infinite number of points outside of this interval so surely one of them must be the lowest (or highest).

So now we have identified both a greatest lower bound and lowest upper bound. Therefore, the function is bounded.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz4"], "nr": 300, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-01T19:56:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ln7vub6qeba60t", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-01T19:56:25Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lnaek8g7yq940b", "to": "ln7vub6mljf60s", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-03T14:16:00Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Alternate proof for week 4 practice question 2", "created": "2023-10-01T19:56:25Z", "content": "

Hi, I realized my proof is slightly different from the answer, may I ask if this is valid as well? Thx!

Question: Let $$f(x) > 0$$ for all $$x \neq a$$ and assume limx→a
f(x) = L with L $$\neq$$±∞. Use the definition of limits
to show that L ≥ 0.

Pf:

We know $$|f(x)-L|<\epsilon$$ when $$0<|x-a|<\delta$$ for all $$\epsilon>0$$. Assume $$L<0$$. When $$f(x)>0$$, $$f(x)-L>0$$ so we can drop the absolute values to get $$f(x)-L<\epsilon$$. Now choose $$\epsilon =-L$$, which is greater than 0, then $$f(x)-L<-L$$ and $$f(x)<0$$, which is a contradiction, so $$L\geq0$$.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 111, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-03T14:16:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Herrick Leung", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwaxyw38k512", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-03T14:16:00Z", "content": "Looks good to me."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwaxyw38k512"], "children": [], "id": "lnaek8g4dn340a", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ln7vub6mljf60s", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513851520, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz4"], "nr": 303, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-02T18:02:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwcn9sao016r", "data": "ln977bq1f9t1gv", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-02T18:02:14Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "ln9a6djv4n82s", "to": "ln977bpxjvm1gu", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-02T19:25:28Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwcn9sao016r", "subject": "Week 4 Practice Problem 8", "created": "2023-10-02T18:02:14Z", "content": "For this problem, I'm just wondering if the function's numerator is supposed to be (sinx)^2 or sin(x^2)?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 91, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-02T19:25:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ghazia Fatima", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwabu0902154", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-02T19:25:28Z", "content": "$$sin^2(x) = sin(x)^2$$, those two are same thing. You should say them as "sin squared x"
$$sin(x^2)$$ is "sin x squared".

$$sinx^2$$ will be ambiguous. You will definitely lose mark if you write this in your solutions.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz4"], "nr": 313, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-03T23:53:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnaz6hmfaxf38c", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-03T23:53:10Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "data": "lnazq4y53bkr", "to": "lnaz6hmbpmt38b", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-10-04T00:08:27Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice Problems Q2 - Choosing Epsilon Value", "created": "2023-10-03T23:53:10Z", "content": "For question 2 in Quiz 4's Practice Problems, how do we know to choose epsilon = $$|L|/2$$?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 69, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-04T00:08:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "David-Nuo Cheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Kenzy Soror", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcm6iy84zh", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-04T00:08:27Z", "content": "

You can choose any epsilon as long as it is above 0. For that specific question you could pick: $$\frac{|L|}{4}$$ or $$\frac{|L|}{5}$$ or 6 and so on. The thing you are trying to contradict is that if f(x)>0 and L<0 cannot be true.

However, the reason why you choose $$\frac{|L|}{2}$$ is because L + $$\frac{|L|}{2}$$ is less than zero. That can't be since f(x) > 0.

Hope it helps ;)

We proved that $$|\frac{x+3}{9x^2}| \leq \frac{7}{36}$$. We need to choose some number for |x-3| such that when multiplied, it equals epsilon.

Specifically, we established that $$2 \leq x \leq 4$$. Now 4 +3 = 7 and 9(2)(2) = 36. Therefore, we get $$\frac{7}{36}$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-04T00:15:03Z", "content": "We proved that $$|\frac{x+3}{9x^2}| \leq \frac{7}{36}$$. We need to choose some number for |x-3| such that when multiplied, it equals epsilon. Could you further explain why for x+3, we choose x equal 4? But for $$9x^2$$ we choose x = 2. Why do we need to use a different x value? Isn't $$|(x+3)/(9x^2)|$$ have the maximum when x=2. Why can't we just use x=2 for the upper and lower x?

Thank you

", "created": "2023-10-05T02:11:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

You can certainly do that if you know how the function behaves.

However, in a quiz/test situation, it might not be obvious where the maximum of $$|x+3|/9x^2$$ is on $$(2,4)$$ but it is somewhat more obvious where the maximum of $$|x+3|$$ and $$1/9x^2$$ is on $$(2,4)$$.

I think it's the justification for picking the positive root.

Specifically, it looks like you chose the positive root because $$a_n >0 $$ but you may not have demonstrated that $$a_n$$ is bounded below. Instead, you could say that $$a_n$$ is increasing and $$a_1 = 1$$ and that would be enough justification for picking the positive root.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz4"], "nr": 321, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-04T01:06:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdteqeyu1zj", "data": "lnb1s9q7gp23j8", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-04T01:06:06Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lnbrviy44js543", "to": "lnb1s9q3w5h3j7", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-04T13:16:28Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdteqeyu1zj", "subject": "Practice Quiz 4 - LA 2", "created": "2023-10-04T01:06:06Z", "content": "
I was wondering if factoring out the x from both the numerator and denominator was necessary?
What I did was split the limit into two, with one part being the numerator and the other being the denominator (so (lim_(x->0) x^2) * (lim_(x->0) (1/(3+ sqrt(x^2 + 9))). I then showed that the limit of the numerator was 0, and since the denominator had a limit that was not 0 (in particular, the denominator was approaching 6), so we were getting 0 * 1/6 as the limit, which is equal to 0. Thus, by the squeeze theorem, the limit of the original function is 0."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 76, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-04T13:16:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-04T13:16:28Z", "content": "

I don't think factoring it out was necessary. You're correct that the form of the limit is "0 / number" so you can just sub in $$x=0$$.

\n

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz4"], "nr": 328, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-04T03:33:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnb718avyf25av", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-04T03:33:02Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lnb8jk7kz061p0", "to": "lnb718assfn5au", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-04T04:15:17Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lnb8ljjraa61r", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2023-10-04T04:16:49Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice Problem Q7d", "created": "2023-10-04T03:33:02Z", "content": "

I'm a little confused how we can compute the limit of the sin function to equal 1 when x->2. I thought we only applied this rule when

x->0. Can someone please clarify?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz4", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wania Saqib", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwekj0scwfe", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 119, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-04T04:15:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sampoorna Prakash", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697050635}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Wania Saqib", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwekj0scwfe", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-04T04:16:49Z", "content": "

The solution didn't assume $$\lim_{x->2} \frac{sin (x)}{x} =1$$, it's still x-> 0.


Remember the variables are interchangeable. Let $$y = x^2 - 4$$. When x approaches 2, y approaches 0. then the limit becomes $$\lim_{y-> 0} \frac{sin (3y)}{3y}$$, which is 1.

Well if you are wondering why that goes to 1, then let z = 3y, and follow the steps above, you will get the original fundamental limit of trig :)

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-04T04:15:17Z", "content": "

The solution didn't assume $$\lim_{x->2} \frac{sin (x)}{x} =1$$, it's still x-> 0.


Remember the variables are interchangeable. Let $$y = x^2 - 4$$. When x approaches 2, y approaches 0. then the limit becomes $$\lim_{y-> 0} \frac{sin (y)}{y}$$, which is 1.

Why would these be wrong?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 82, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-04T17:05:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nicole Cui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdliollvp0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwad9oocb1eb", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-04T19:05:06Z", "content": "

For this question, we want to use the sequential characterization of limits, so we need a sequence $$x_n$$ that goes to 1 from the right when $$n\to \infty$$ and $$x_n \ne 1$$.

Choice 1 doesn't work as it approaches from $$1^-$$. When $$n$$ is small, we can see that $$x_n$$ is increasing, so it must approach 1 from the left ($$1^-$$), while we want a sequence that approaches from $$1^+$$ 

Choice 2 does not work because $$x_n = 1$$ which violates the definition of the theorem.

Choice 3 approaches 1 from the bottom. When n is smaller such as $$n= 1, 2, 3$$ the value of $$1- \frac{1}{n}$$ is closer to 0, and gets closer to 1 as the value of $$n$$ gets larger, so it approaches from $$1^-$$ while we want a sequence that approaches from $$1^+$$ as desired in the question and thus also does not work.

Choice 4 approaches zero (we can derive this using Squeeze Theorem), but we want a sequence that approaches 1 as n goes to infinity so it also doesn't work.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwad9oocb1eb", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-04T17:06:02Z", "content": "

Choice 1 approaches 0 as n goes to infinity, not 1, so it doesnt work.

Choice 2 does not work because $$x_n = 1$$ which violates the definition of the theorem.

Choice 3 approaches 1 from the bottom. When n is smaller such as $$n= 1, 2, 3$$ the value of $$1- \frac{1}{n}$$ is closer to 0, and gets closer to 1 as the value of $$n$$ gets larger, so it approaches from $$1^-$$ while we want a sequence that approaches from $$1^+$$ as desired in the question and thus also does not work.

Choice 4 approaches zero (we can derive this using Squeeze Theorem), but we want a sequence that approaches 1 as n goes to infinity so it also doesn't work.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz4"], "nr": 334, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-04T15:41:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnbx2kpojw465q", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-04T15:41:55Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lnbxuc648ni15c", "to": "lnbx2kpl8n65p", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-10-04T16:03:30Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lnc4ydsscfx6gd", "to": "lnbx2kpl8n65p", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-04T19:22:36Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Week 4 Practice Problem Q9", "created": "2023-10-04T15:41:55Z", "content": "

Hi, can someone please explain to me how epsilon/3 is true. Thank you for your time!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 74, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-04T16:03:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "David-Nuo Cheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-04T16:03:30Z", "content": "

When you do your rough work/aside, you write |(3x-2)-14|<epsilon and get |3x-12|<epsilon. Factoring will find that you get

\n

3|x-4|<epsilon. Divide both sides by 3 to get epsilon/3 as the largest possible delta value. Anything bigger (with a smaller denominator) will not work.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kcat0wu2cik59z"], "children": [], "id": "lnbxuc60h7l15b", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-04T19:22:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Angus Chou", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7t3eal4gi3wi", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-04T19:22:36Z", "content": "I also strongly recommend you to go over the practice question 1 all over again without help, cause if you try to prove $$\\lim_{x->4}3x+2 = 14$$ normally using $$\\epsilon - \\delta$$ definition, you should get $$\\frac{\\epsilon}{3}$$ as your choice. o.o"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7t3eal4gi3wi"], "children": [], "id": "lnc4ydsqvm96gc", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnbx2kpl8n65p", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513889306, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 84, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-04T17:32:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Angus Chou", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm7t3eal4gi3wi", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Nicole Cui", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdliollvp0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "David-Nuo Cheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwad9oocb1eb", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-04T17:32:02Z", "content": "

To use the fundamental trigonometric limit we will multiply the top/bottom by $$2\\theta$$.

\n

Then, we have $$\\lim_\\limits{\\theta \\to 0} \\frac{sin\\theta}{\\cos\\theta} \\frac{1}{\\sin(2\\theta)}\\frac{2\\theta}{2\\theta} = \\lim_\\limits{\\theta \\to 0} \\frac{sin\\theta}{\\theta} \\frac{2\\theta}{\\sin(2\\theta)}\\frac{1}{2\\cos\\theta}$$ by rearranging some of the numerators and denominators so we can use the fundamental trigonometric limit, $$\\lim\\limits_{\\theta\\to 0} \\frac{sin\\theta}{\\theta} = 1$$. Since $$\\cos\\theta = 1$$ for $$\\theta=0$$, then we get $$1\\cdot 1\\cdot \\frac{1}{2(1)} = \\frac{1}{2}$$ as desired.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lm7t3eal4gi3wi", "lkqwdliollvp0", "kcat0wu2cik59z"], "children": [], "id": "lnc106zkz343eu", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnbxjf6mr7h7kw", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513890370, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I don't know either :((

Well for this question, it's asking which of the following might be true. Doesn't mean it is always true.


a) is true cause it's could be continuous function.
b) is true cause with the information given, limit as x approaching any point from the left could be any value.
c),d) is true is due to similar reason is why b) is true.
However, e) is false because it states that "$$\forall x \in \mathbb{R}, f(x) = f(x+4)$$", which you can say that the function repeats itself for every 4 units. which guarantees that it can't satisfy "diverge to infinity". consider the following example: $$f(x) = cos(x\pi)$$, which $$f(x) = f(x+2)$$

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz5"], "nr": 353, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-11T20:32:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnm7ji9axtn53m", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-11T20:32:43Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lnm7ji973ic53l", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-10-11T23:15:23Z", "cid": "lnmdcphaxwi1fy", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lnn6pb827tv18q", "to": "lnm7ji973ic53l", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-12T12:57:00Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "to": "lnm7ji973ic53l", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-10-12T12:58:21Z", "cid": "lnn6r1etp0u3d8"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice Problem 5, Question 4", "created": "2023-10-11T20:32:43Z", "content": "

Hi, 

For the following question, 

For determining the interval, if the function was in fact continuous at x = 2 and x = -3, how would the interval change, for example, would I put square brackets instead?

Just to make sure my understanding is clear, is a function is only continuous if its limit and f(a) is the same?

Thank you in advance.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz5", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Shihan Sharar", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdbxatel6pr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 84, "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I wanted to ask as well by defining f(x)=0 at x=2, does that not remove the discontinuity? 2 should be included in the values that are continuous to this function if Im not wrong but the solution does not include x=2", "created": "2023-10-11T23:15:23Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Shihan Sharar", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdbxatel6pr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "The discontinuity is only removed if $$\lim_{x\to 2} f(x) = f(2)$$. Here, we have that $$\lim_{x\to 2} f(x) = \frac{4}{5}\cos(4) \neq f(2) = 0$$, so it's discontinuous at $$x=2$$.", "created": "2023-10-12T12:58:21Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lnn6r1etp0u3d8", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-10-12T12:58:21Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwdbxatel6pr"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnmdcphaxwi1fy", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-10-12T12:58:22Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-12T12:57:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nadia Anwar", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdnjctl125", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-12T12:57:00Z", "content": "

If we were to re-define $$f(2) = \frac{4}{5} \cos(4)$$ then $$f(x)$$ would be continuous at $$x=2$$. You are correct that we would change the open bracket to a square bracket: $$(-3,2]\cup[2,\infty)$$. However, notice that this interval is the same thing as $$(-3,\infty)$$.

So, our final answer would be $$(-\infty, -3) \cup (-3,\infty)$$.


A function is continuous at $$x=a$$ if

$$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to a} f(x) $$ exists and $$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to a} f(x) = f(a)$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdnjctl125"], "children": [], "id": "lnn6pb7zvy018p", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwdbxatel6pr"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnm7ji973ic53l", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513910003, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I got 0 as the final answer, but I don't know which step I did wrong.", "created": "2023-10-14T22:27:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnqlz8ylqaj3mm", "updated": "2023-10-16T00:29:33Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-16T00:29:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-16T00:29:27Z", "content": "

Note that $$0 \\cdot \\infty$$ is not always $$0$$. In fact if you consider $$f(x) = \\frac{a}{x}$$ and $$g(x) = x$$ then $$f \\to 0$$ and $$g \\to \\infty$$ as $$x \\to \\infty$$ but $$f\\cdot g \\to a$$.

\n

\n

This is a simple example but you can build more complicated ones that are finite. Basically every derivative is $$0 \\cdot \\infty$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lns5rcsic3a32g", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwayddv4r53q"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnncpgnh84l3wp", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513911077, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-14T03:22:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-14T03:24:07Z", "content": "Note that since the wording is "for every M > 0," it basically means "no matter what M > 0 you pick, f(x) will be greater past cutoff N." If f(x) is non-decreasing and approaches a limit, then that means that there must be an M > 0 that is above the limit (and thus is greater than f(x) to infinity), and hence it doesn't diverge to infinity."}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-14T03:22:27Z", "content": "Note that since the wording is "for every M > 0," it basically means "no matter what M > 0 you pick, f(x) will be greater past cutoff N." If f(x) is non-decreasing and approaches a limit, then that means that there must be an M > 0 that is above the limit (> f(x)), and hence it doesn't diverge to infinity."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lnph252crdf55z", "config": {"editor": "plain"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnp9ln2h3t439j", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513915328, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz5"], "nr": 359, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-14T00:26:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnparnwrro54js", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-14T00:26:21Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lnszeqi18ce4j3", "to": "lnparnwn27y4jq", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-16T14:19:26Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lnszexp2f3o4uh", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2023-10-16T14:19:36Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Proving discontinuities", "created": "2023-10-14T00:26:21Z", "content": "Is there a formal way of proving the type of discontinuities and also a way to distinguish between them (holes, jumps and asymptote)\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 70, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-16T14:19:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-16T14:19:36Z", "content": "I'm not sure necessarily of a formal way, but for example, if you have a jump discontinuity, then you would show that both $$\\lim_{x\\to a^{-}} f(x)$$ and $$\\lim_{x\\to a^{+}} f(x) $$ exist but do not equal. If you had a removable discontinuity, you would show that $$\\lim_{x\\to a} f(x)$$ exists but does not equal $$f(a)$$ and so on."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-16T14:19:26Z", "content": "I'm not sure necessarily of a formal way, but for example, if you have a jump discontinuity, then you would show that both $$\\lim_{x\\to a^{-}} f(x)$$ and $$\\lim_{x\\to a^{+}} f(x) $$ exist but do not equal. If you had a removable discontinuity, you would show that $$\\lim_{x\\to a f(x)$$ exists but does not equal $$f(a)$$ and so on."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt"], "children": [], "id": "lnszeqhyx904j0", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnparnwn27y4jq", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513916397, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz5"], "nr": 365, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-16T22:38:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "data": "lnth864qsck6rp", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-16T22:38:13Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lnuidckandl4kv", "to": "lnth864nd0l6ro", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-17T15:58:00Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "subject": "question about definition of continuity", "created": "2023-10-16T22:38:13Z", "content": "

I need some example to understand this definition. Could someone use this definition to prove that x/x is not continuous at x=0?

Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 66, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-17T15:58:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Bill Xu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8dotmoy4md", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Xinhao Wang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwelvposqnn", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-17T15:58:00Z", "content": "

For $$f(x) = \frac{x}{x}$$, we would just have $$f(0)$$ undefined, so $$f(x)$$ is discontinuous at $$x=0$$.

Here's another example: $$f(x) = \begin{cases} 0 \ \text{ if } x \neq 0 \\ 1 \ \text{ if } x = 0\end{cases}$$

To show that $$f(x)$$ is discontinuous at $$x=0$$, we just need to show the definition above doesn't hold for one value of $$\epsilon.$$

Let $$\epsilon = \frac{1}{2}$$, then notice that the inequality reads $$|f(x) - f(0)| = |0 - 1| = 1 \not < 1/2$$ for any $$\delta$$. In other words, there is no $$\delta$$ such that $$|x| < \delta$$ implies $$|f(x) - f(0)| < \frac{1}{2}$$, so the function is discontinuous at $$x=0$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8dotmoy4md", "lkqwelvposqnn"], "children": [], "id": "lnuidck7gbd4ku", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnth864nd0l6ro", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513922790, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hello.\u00a0

\n

\n

I've noticed my performance for this course is lacking in terms of the quizzes. My other Math/CS courses' averages are 10% - 20% higher and I'm left wondering what I'm doing wrong. I understand the concepts but I am still not performing on the quizzes.\u00a0\u00a0

For those reading this, what do you do specifically to prepare for the quizzes and translate conceptual knowledge into practical knowledge (used to answer the questions on the quizzes)?

Any response is appreciated.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Smeet Shah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwda7cwkc6ez", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Simon Hampton", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdcyaasj6we", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 130, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-17T17:27:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-17T17:27:38Z", "content": "Memorize all the steps"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lnulkm5fiizwp", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-17T19:54:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jeremie Notebaert", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ktd0gqt5nhy2ei", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-17T19:54:18Z", "content": "I just checked your past 2 quizzes, your mark is still decent since it's higher than class average so don't beat up yourself too much :)

My suggestion for you is, go over the formal definition again and do practice questions. It feels like you did not fully grasp the material and the steps. When I say do practice questions, don't just look at the answers. Do it first yourself without help, then check the answer. If it matches, then great! :D if not, then try understand what's required in the solution, and understand why it was written this way in the solution, then do the question without help again until you can say "I can get the marks that I wanted with any similar kinds of this question." o.o

Those are both theorems found in the course notes.

The Arithmetic Rules are properties such as

"if $$f(x)$$, $$g(x)$$ are continuous at $$x=a$$, then $$f+g$$ is continuous at $$x=a$$"
and so forth.

Continuity of composites lets us say that since $$x^2$$ and $$\cos(x)$$ are continuous on $$\mathbb{R}$$, then so is $$\cos(x^2)$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz5"], "nr": 394, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-18T06:52:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnvec9a04k76yh", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-18T06:52:57Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "data": "lnvsqeld11u5kn", "to": "lnvec99wv26yg", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-10-18T13:35:52Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Confusion about continuity of inverse", "created": "2023-10-18T06:52:57Z", "content": "

__2023-10-18___2.46.44.png

I have 2 questions about this theorem.

1. What does invertible means? Can we assume every functions have a inverse function?

2. Do we need to know the domain of the inverse function in order to apply the theorem? (Eg. Let's say for sin(x) we assume it has a inverse function and we do not know the domain. But since we can always find a x value for any y value between -1 and 1 in sin(x), we conclude that the inverse of sin is continuous from -1 to 1 even if we do not know the domain of arcsin)

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 69, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-18T13:35:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-18T13:35:52Z", "content": "

I think it means that the function's inverse is also a function? For example x^2 the inverse has two separate sections. 

I think if you know the domain and range of the og function you will know the domain of the inverse. Because the domain of the og function becomes the range and the range becomes the domain. For example the range of sin(x) is 1 <= y <= -1, therefore the domain of acrsin is 1 <= x <= -1, 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lnvsqel9vhe5km", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnvec99wv26yg", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513954285, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I believe that is a typo, it is supposed to be:

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow ∞}\frac{6+\frac{1}{e^{x}}}{2-\frac{1}{e^{x}}}$$

since:

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow -∞}e^{x}=\lim_{x\rightarrow ∞}\frac{1}{e^{x}}$$

Edit: This is LA2 not LA1

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-18T13:51:51Z", "content": "

I believe that is a typo, it is supposed to be:

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow ∞}\frac{6+\frac{1}{e^{x}}}{2-\frac{1}{e^{x}}}$$

since:

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow -∞}e^{x}=\lim_{x\rightarrow ∞}\frac{1}{e^{x}}$$

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwe7nglje5q8", "lkqwasxgeh145l"], "children": [], "id": "lnvtayfgovy2du", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

However, I do not really get how that can happen. Can someone explain it for me? Thank you! :D"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "quiz5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 96, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-18T20:12:49Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-18T20:12:49Z", "content": "

For $$\\lim_{x\\to a}f(x)=f(a)$$ to be guaranteed, $$f(x)$$ needs to be continuous at $$x=a$$.

\n

\n

However, since this is not specifically stated in the question, there is no guarantee.

Limit of x approaches 3 for : (sin(x^2-9))/(x-3)

I know this can turn into (sin((x-3)(x+3)))/(x-3) and then if I can turn this into the sin(x)/x identity I can work from there. I am just unsure how to go from

(sin((x-3)(x+3)))/(x-3) to the sin identity

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Question 4b Maliha Ahmed midterm review question", "created": "2023-10-19T02:02:46Z", "content": "

The question is as follows:

Limit of x approaches 3 for : (sin(x^2-9))/(x-3)

I know this can turn into (sin((x-3)(x+3)))/(x-3) and then if I can turn this into the sin(x)/x identity I can work from there. I am just unsure how to go from

(sin((x-3)(x+3)))/(x-3) to the sin identity

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 94, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-19T13:37:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-19T13:37:51Z", "content": "I'm going to make this question public as I think it's an interesting problem that other students may be interested in.

For $$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to3} \frac{\sin(x^2-9)}{x-3}$$, you have the right idea in trying to manipulate this into an FTL type question. However, modifying the argument of sin will probably not work. Can you think of a different operation you can perform to make this look like the FTL: $$\displaystyle \lim_{\theta \to 0} \frac{\sin(\theta)}{\theta}$$."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lnx88sww7m86jr", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Could we multiply everything by $$\frac{x+3}{x+3}$$ ? {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz3"], "nr": 413, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-19T19:29:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnxksmcps7719f", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-19T19:29:11Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lnxm0rdxx0z35d", "to": "lnxksmcm2l019e", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-10-19T20:03:30Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Quiz 3 Q1", "created": "2023-10-19T19:29:11Z", "content": "

\n

I am not sure why 0 is the upper bound. When n=3/2 (n $$\\geq$$1) and sin($$\\pi$$n)=-1, then its upper bound is 1.\u00a0

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 56, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-19T20:03:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-19T20:03:30Z", "content": "When we are dealing with sequences, the $$n$$ has to be a positive integer, so we can not have $$n = \\frac{3}{2}$$. Hello,

I am a bit confused on how to evaluate limits at -∞, usually when finding horizontal asymptotes. I get that we have strategies for +∞, such as dividing by x to the highest power, but I don't know any for -∞.

Take, for example, Q7 on the midterm review:

I evaluated the limit going to +∞ as 0, but I have no idea how to do the limit going to -∞.

I would appreciate it if I could get some help on how to tackle these kinds of questions.

Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 94, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-20T01:26:54Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-20T01:29:03Z", "content": "

In this case if $$x<-3$$, then $$|x^2-2x-15|=x^2-2x-15$$.

Therefore, the same must hold true for $$x\rightarrow -\infty$$.

So we have $$f(x)=\frac{x+3}{|x^2-2x-15|}=\frac{x+3}{(x+3)(x-5)}=\frac{1}{x-5}=\frac{1}{x}\cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{5}{x}}$$.

$$\lim_{x\rightarrow -\infty }\frac{1}{x}\cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{5}{x}}=0\cdot \frac{1}{1+0}=1\cdot1=0$$.

Generally speaking when solving limits at negative infinity, the process is quite similar to limits at positive infinity, you just have to keep an eye out for negative values in exponents, and the sign of your variables.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz3"], "nr": 430, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-21T02:08:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lnzehiuxk4p6tl", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-21T02:08:08Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lnzi1w8zas03kk", "to": "lnzehiuu82c6tk", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-21T03:47:57Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Quiz 3A - Q2 (Definition of Non-Decreasing)", "created": "2023-10-21T02:08:08Z", "content": "

Terminology-wise, when we say that a function is non-decreasing, does that automatically make it monotonic? When looking at this question, I was thinking of something like the sine function, which is not decreasing + bounded above + not converging.

Is "not decreasing" different from "non-decreasing"?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 49, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-21T03:47:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Kenzy Soror", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcm6iy84zh", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-21T03:47:57Z", "content": "Well, when we claim a sequence is non-decreasing, it means that it's not decreasing throughout the entire sequence.

Sine function is not monotonic because it's neither non-decreasing nor non-decreasing. it's increasing at some part of the function and decreasing at some part of the function as well."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwcm6iy84zh"], "children": [], "id": "lnzi1w8vjrn3kj", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lnzehiuu82c6tk", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714513992920, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"content": "If $$y_n$$ is bounded then that means there exists at $$M$$ such that $$|y_n| \leq M$$.

Using this info, can you bound $$|x_n y_n|$$? Maybe the Squeeze Theorem will be useful here"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt"], "children": [], "id": "lo07ungvg3158l", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Would this work? 

-M <= y <= M 

-M(x_n) <= y <= M(x_n)

0 <= y <= 0 

then use the squeeze theorem?

Also, how did you know it was |y| <= M not just y<=M?

", "created": "2023-10-21T15:53:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Close, we start with

$$|x_n y_n| \leq M |x_n| \iff - M |x_n| \leq x_ny_n \leq M |x_n|$$. Now you just need to argue that $$|x_n| \to 0$$ and then by Squeeze Theorem, you have that $$x_ny_n \to 0$$ as well.

"Bounded" means bounded above and below. So this means that there exists an $$A, B$$ such that $$A \leq y_n \leq B$$ for all $$n$$ and then you can pick an $$M$$ accordingly.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz5"], "nr": 441, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-21T16:10:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo08kglqyit1k", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-21T16:10:13Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwatfhhwv48n", "data": "lo0a1oirrdi3cq", "to": "lo08kgllkcy1j", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-10-21T16:51:36Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lo0a1uz9oy63ld", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-10-21T16:51:45Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Question 5 Quiz 5A", "created": "2023-10-21T16:10:13Z", "content": "

\n

I tried solving this by assuming if x > 0 its continuous because its just a normal polynomial and then for x = 0 checking the left and right side limits. If you check them, the right is 2 and the left DNE. Doesn't this mean that f(x) is discontinuous at x = 0 and therefore not continuous on the interval [0, 1]?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 65, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-21T16:51:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-21T16:51:45Z", "content": "It\u2019s a closed interval though, and for a function to be continuous on a closed interval [a,b] the right limit of a must equal the function value of a, the left limit of b must equal the function value of b, and the function must be continuous on the open interval (a,b). You\u2019re right in saying the polynomial is continuous for x >0, and that satisfies the last condition. But because the interval is closed you really don\u2019t have to check the left and right side limits of 0 for the statement to be true, just the right one, and the right limit at x= 0 is 2 which is also f(0). The left limit of 1 is 9, and f(1) is also 9, therefore the statement is true."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwatfhhwv48n", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-21T16:51:36Z", "content": "It\u2019s a closed interval though, and for a function to be continuous on a closed interval [a,b] the right limit of a must equal the function value of a, the left limit of b must equal the function value of b, and the function must be continuous on the open interval (a,b). You\u2019re right in saying the polynomial is continuous for x >0, and that satisfies the last condition. But because the interval is closed you really don\u2019t have to check the left and right side limits of 0 for the statement to be true, just the right one, and the right limit at x= 0 is 2 which is also f(0). The left limit of 1 is 9, and f(1) is also 9, therefore the statement is true."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ixjsn8icw2y1c3"], "children": [], "id": "lo0a1oimfg3cp", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lo08kgllkcy1j", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514004790, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz5"], "nr": 445, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-21T17:52:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo0c8j87o9z24g", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-21T17:52:55Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lo0cfa8ce9r6r5", "to": "lo0c8j842dv24f", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-10-21T17:58:10Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lo0c8j842dv24f", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-10-21T19:36:29Z", "cid": "lo0fxpzfrhb98", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "5A Short Answer Question A", "created": "2023-10-21T17:52:55Z", "content": "I am confused how to get the limit when n goes to negative infinity. Why is it 1? And why can we get the limit as x goes to positive infinity by dividing an e to the power of x?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 57, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-21T17:58:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-21T17:58:10Z", "content": "Also for the very last question, why we can decide the range of continuity of two functions when they are multiplied by looking at in what part both of the functions are continuous? How does this work?"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lo0cfa882e66r3", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "For your first question, it is 1 because e to the power of negative infinity equals 1/(e to the power of positive infinity) which equals 0. For your second question, we can get the limit as x goes to positive infinity by dividing an e^x basically because e^x is not equal to 0. For your third question, due to the continuity of products f&g. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz4"], "nr": 462, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T02:16:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo0u8erciek669", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-22T02:16:42Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lo0w7ps3q5w4rd", "to": "lo0u8er9972668", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-10-22T03:12:09Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Quiz 4A Justification for this answer", "created": "2023-10-22T02:16:42Z", "content": "

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz4", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 55, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T03:12:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wania Saqib", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwekj0scwfe", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-22T03:12:09Z", "content": "

To show that the limit DNE, your aim is to find a sequence {xn} that converges to infinity, but the lim x-> inf sin(x) diverges.

a) xn = {Πn = {Π, 2Π, 3Π, ...}

b) xn = {Π/2, Π, 3Π/2, ...}

c) xn = {Π, Π/2, Π/3...}

Clearly, only a) and b) goes to infinity since c) goes to 0. Now, you want to see if f(xn) would converge/diverge for a/b.

a) f(xn) = {0,0,0,...}

b) f(xn) = {1,0,-1,0,...}

Since a) converges to 0 but b diverges, then you that b) would be the sequence to choose to show that the limit DNE.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwekj0scwfe"], "children": [], "id": "lo0w7przgif4rc", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwec73jwh6mz"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lo0u8er9972668", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514027522, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Why is this true?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 71, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T15:52:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-22T15:52:34Z", "content": "There's a theorem related to this. Basically, you're given that $$\\lim_{x\\to a} f(x)/g(x)$$ exists and that $$\\lim_{x\\to a} g(x) =0$$. This means that $$\\lim_{x\\to a}f(x)=0$$ too. For example, if $$\\lim_{x\\to a} f(x) = 1$$, then $$\\lim_{x\\to a} f(x)/g(x)$$ would not exist."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lo1ndm75rg83mj", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I see. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz3", "midterm", "other"], "nr": 473, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T14:32:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwarf9r4h3w4", "data": "lo1kiod0kzzw", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-22T14:32:31Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwda7cwkc6ez", "data": "lo1kpiz17dx5qg", "to": "lo1kiocw9qjv", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-10-22T14:37:51Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwarf9r4h3w4", "subject": "Bounded Question", "created": "2023-10-22T14:32:31Z", "content": "

\n

Why is this true? Can't an be non-decreasing so it does not matter an is bounded below or not? In this case , \u00a0it should not be bounded because bounded only happens when both upper bound and lower bound exist.\u00a0

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "other", "quiz3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 75, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T14:37:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwda7cwkc6ez", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-22T14:37:51Z", "content": "While you\u2019re right about whether it doesn\u2019t matter if it is bounded below, this is because we note it is bounded below. Take for example an = n. An non-decreasing sequence that doesn\u2019t matter if it is bounded below because it\u2019s already implied it is bounded below, we care about the behaviour while it goes to infinity.

Hope that helps.

Would it be a valid answer if we said:

If f(x) is bounded above by 1 as the least upper bound, then global max [0,infinity) = 1, which is defined at x = 0.

If f(x) is bounded above by 1 + k as the least upper bound, for some k>0, then the global max on [0,infinity) = 1 + k. Since f(x) is continuous for all x in Real numbers, there exists a c in (0, infinity) where f(c) = 1+k

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Midterm 22F Q6 Long Answer", "created": "2023-10-22T16:21:47Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 477, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T16:38:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo1p0l1ta3n6qg", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-22T16:38:25Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "data": "lo23u5wrh5z1sl", "to": "lo1p0l1ph8w6qf", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-22T23:33:20Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lo1p0l1ph8w6qf", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-10-22T23:34:42Z", "cid": "lo23vwr7ctc52m", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "to": "lo1p0l1ph8w6qf", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-10-23T12:33:52Z", "cid": "lo2vpxl6wtd7ht"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "to": "lo1p0l1ph8w6qf", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-10-23T13:59:43Z", "cid": "lo2ysbxmb2u4rn"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Proof question", "created": "2023-10-22T16:38:25Z", "content": "

How would we prove this question? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 62, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T23:33:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-22T23:33:20Z", "content": "

If you know $$\{a_n\}$$ and $$\{b_n\}$$ converge (let's say to $$L$$ and $$M$$ respectively) then you can do a simple contradiction by assuming $$L > M$$ and building an $$\epsilon$$ interval around $$L$$ that will contain values of $$\{a_n\}$$ greater than $$b_n$$.

Knowing that $$\{a_n\}$$ is increasing allows you to state that it does in fact converge because it's bounded by $$b_1$$. A similar argument works for $$\{b_n\}$$. 

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lo23u5wnrx81sk", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "How do you know that it converges though? ", "created": "2023-10-22T23:34:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "You can prove it converges because it is increasing and bounded above by $$b_1$$. In the same way $$\{b_n\}$$ converges because it is decreasing and bounded below by $$a_1$$", "created": "2023-10-23T12:33:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lo2vpxl6wtd7ht", "updated": "2023-10-23T12:33:52Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Did you get this from the fact that a_1 <= b_1?", "created": "2023-10-23T13:59:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lo2ysbxmb2u4rn", "updated": "2023-10-23T13:59:43Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lo23vwr7ctc52m", "updated": "2023-10-23T13:59:43Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lo1p0l1ph8w6qf", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514044284, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 481, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T17:03:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo1px1brein55o", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-22T17:03:40Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lo1qybcamii62b", "to": "lo1px1bo65h55n", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-22T17:32:39Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lo1px1bo65h55n", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-10-22T17:38:18Z", "cid": "lo1r5l2gnku2a", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "to": "lo1px1bo65h55n", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-10-22T17:43:15Z", "cid": "lo1rby9sw337mu"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "to": "lo1px1bo65h55n", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-10-22T17:43:58Z", "cid": "lo1rcvazl7b5l8"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "F 22 Midterm Q 10", "created": "2023-10-22T17:03:40Z", "content": "

Doesnt bounded mean bounded above AND bounded below? Then for an increasing sequence that converges only the bounded above is necessary, so since this is an increasing sequence that is converging it doesnt imply that it is bounded below, but only implies that it is bounded above.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 75, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T17:32:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-22T17:32:39Z", "content": "Yes:

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lo1qybc6xzk629", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I understand that bounded means both bounded above and below, but why isnt the answer false? if an is an increasing sequence that converges, this only guarantees that it is bounded above, not bounded above AND below", "created": "2023-10-22T17:38:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

If a sequence converges then for all $$\epsilon >0$$, we eventually have $$|a_n - L | < \epsilon$$, i.e., $$ L - \epsilon < a_n < L + \epsilon$$.

So we can pick an $$\epsilon$$ large enough such that all terms of $$a_n$$ are within $$(L-\epsilon,L+\epsilon)$$, thus making $$a_n$$ bounded.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 483, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T17:32:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo1qyk317kn3zx", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-22T17:32:50Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "data": "lo23zu15my811p", "to": "lo1qyk2xule3zw", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-22T23:37:45Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "bisection method", "created": "2023-10-22T17:32:50Z", "content": "

for bisection method do stop at 2^(k+1) or 2^k? 

text book says k+1, my note says k. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T23:37:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-22T23:37:45Z", "content": "

It really just depends on how you're measuring things. Ultimately you just need the final interval you are using to be no more than twice the length of the $$\epsilon$$.

For example if $$\epsilon = 0.1$$ then you just need to make sure your final interval is no bigger than $$0.2$$ units (since the root would be in the middle of the interval $$\pm 0.1$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 485, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T18:16:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo1sii0haqi43z", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-22T18:16:20Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "data": "lo2vyx6yus636a", "to": "lo1sii0eyuh43y", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-23T12:40:51Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "2022 Midterm question 7", "created": "2023-10-22T18:16:20Z", "content": "Why we are finding the limit of x approaches 0 for the first function in order to find c?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 80, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-23T12:40:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hboagon4gy02ge", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-23T12:40:51Z", "content": "

Recall the definition of continuity at $$x=0$$ is that $$\\displaystyle\u00a0 \\lim_{x\\to0} f(x) = f(0)$$.

\n

\n

Since $$f(0) = c$$ we are required to calculate the limit of the other piece.

", "created": "2023-10-23T01:05:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lo2752wp7872nf", "updated": "2023-10-23T01:05:48Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Think of it like this. We know that the definition of $$|a|$$ is "$$a$$ when $$a \geq 0$$ and $$-a$$ when $$a < 0$$

Now let's apply this to both $$|x-3|$$ and $$|3-x|$$

if we let $$a = x-3$$, then $$a < 0$$ is true when $$x < 3$$. That means by our definition that $$\lim_{x\to 3^-}|x-3|$$ is $$\lim_{x\to 3^-} -(x-3)$$. Same thing can be applied to show $$\lim_{x\to 3^+}|x-3|$$ is $$\lim_{x\to 3^+} (x-3)$$ This makes sense and is what we expect

Now let's apply this to $$|3-x|$$. Let $$a = 3-x$$ This means $$a> 0$$ if $$x < 3$$. By our definition, this means that if $$x < 3$$, then $$|3-x|$$ is actually just $$3-x$$. Consequently, if $$a < 0$$, that means $$x > 3$$ and $$|3-x| = -(3-x)$$

For this limit in particular, I think the best way to solve it is to just say that $$|3-x| = |x-3|$$, so $$\lim_{x\to 3} \frac{|x-3|}{|3-x|} = \lim_{x\to 3} \frac{|x-3|}{|x-3|} = 1$$

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 95, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T20:35:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Kenzy Soror", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcm6iy84zh", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Shihan Sharar", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdbxatel6pr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-22T20:35:12Z", "content": "

If $$x \in (0, \delta)$$, then $$0 < x < \delta$$. So, the reciprocal, $$\frac{1}{x}$$, would be greater than $$\frac{1}{\delta}$$, which are both greater than $$0$$ since $$x, \delta > 0$$. So, if $$\delta = \frac{1}{N}$$ and $$x < \delta$$, then $$x < \frac{1}{N}$$. This means $$\frac{1}{x} > N$$, so $$\frac{1}{x}$$ is greater than the cutoff, thus the limit converges. 

This was my understanding, but there might be another interpretation.

{"history_size": 3, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 499, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-22T22:10:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo20vkfurou6e5", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-22T22:10:27Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lo20vyzbvt861", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2023-10-22T22:10:46Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lo20w4sfcocof", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2023-10-22T22:10:53Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lo22q9pk3gw21i", "to": "lo20vkfp8l6e4", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-22T23:02:19Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice Midterm LA Q8:", "created": "2023-10-22T22:10:53Z", "content": "

We are given the following question:

$$\text{Suppose } A, B \in \mathbb{R}, A > 0, B > 0 \text{ and } f : \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \text{ is a function such that if } |x - y| < A, \text{ then } |f(x) - f(y)| < B|x - y| \text{ for all } x, y \in \mathbb{R}. \text{ Prove that } f \text{ is continuous on } \mathbb{R}.$$

What about the case where $$x=y$$? Then $$|x-y| < A$$, however, $$B|x-y| = 0$$, which cannot possibly be strictly greater than $$|f(x) - f(y)|$$.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice Midterm LA Q8:", "created": "2023-10-22T22:10:46Z", "content": "

We are given the following question:

$$\text{Suppose } A, B \in \mathbb{R}, A > 0, B > 0 \text{ and } f : \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \text{ is a function such that if } |x - y| < A, \text{ then } |f(x) - f(y)| < B|x - y| \text{ for all } x, y \in \mathbb{R}. \text{ Prove that } f \text{ is continuous on } \mathbb{R}.$$

What about the case where $x=y$? Then $$|x-y| < A$$, however, $$B|x-y| = 0$$, which cannot possibly be strictly greater than $$|f(x) - f(y)|$$.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice Midterm LA Q8:", "created": "2023-10-22T22:10:27Z", "content": "

We are given the following question:

$$\text{Suppose } A, B \in \mathbb{R}, A > 0, B > 0 \text{ and } f : \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \text{ is a function such that if } |x - y| < A, \text{ then } |f(x) - f(y)| < B|x - y| \text{ for all } x, y \in \mathbb{R}. \text{ Prove that } f \text{ is continuous on } \mathbb{R}.$$

What about the case where $x=y$? Then $|x-y| < A$, however, $B|x-y| = 0$, which cannot possibly be strictly greater than $|f(x) - f(y)|$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 508, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-23T02:09:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo29f9i0xr22hm", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-23T02:09:43Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lo2b660q4y399", "to": "lo29f9hwrwv2hl", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-23T02:58:37Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Value of delta", "created": "2023-10-23T02:09:43Z", "content": "When proving the limit of a function using the fundamental definition of a limit of a function, why is delta made to be the minimum of a constant (usually 1) and a value involving epsilon? I would appreciate some clarification on this step of epsilon-delta proofs. Thank you."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 93, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-23T02:58:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-23T02:58:37Z", "content": "If you let delta to be less than some set value, then you can set a bound on x so that we can get a numeric value for some polynomials dependent on x. in Quiz 4 LA1's case it is $$\\frac{3+x}{9x^2}$$. Otherwise your delta will be dependent on x and that would be invalid.

You can also choose other value instead of 1. Some people used $$\\frac{1}{2}$$ for the bound. But 1 at most cases are easy to work with. I do want to note that if you choose value other than 1, your delta value will also change."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lo2b660mcru398", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lo29f9hwrwv2hl", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514078654, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Suppose A, B \u2208 R, A > 0, B > 0 and f : R \u2192 R is a function such that if |x \u2212 y| < A
then |f (x) \u2212 f (y)| < B|x \u2212 y| for all x, y \u2208 R. Prove that f is continuous on R.

\n

\n

Someone help pls

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 143, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-23T02:39:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Emma C", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwaf36re71ph", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-23T02:39:25Z", "content": "By defn if f is continuous on R then for every epsilon >0 there exist a delta>0 st if Ix-yI< delta then |f (x) \u2212 f (y)| < epsilon. You can do delta=min{A, epsilon/B}. Then consider two cases delta=A and delta=epsilon/B."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwaf36re71ph"], "children": [], "id": "lo2ahgpxc34780", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Why I can not directly let the delta equal to epsilon/B?", "created": "2023-10-23T15:54:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwehxe2xz7ok", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Because it's an implication, we should assume |x \u2212 y| < A is true, to get |f (x) \u2212 f (y)| < B|x \u2212 y|", "created": "2023-10-23T15:59:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lo3321bgl0p6cy", "updated": "2023-10-23T15:59:14Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lo32vjjorzc3wn", "updated": "2023-10-23T16:50:06Z", "config": {}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lo29z4s0qze1zm", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 7, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514080793, "default_anonymity": "no"}
