{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 521, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-23T15:03:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lo311qzgrioqp", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-23T15:03:01Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lo3bgi86l9447u", "to": "lo311qzcz5oqo", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-10-23T19:54:26Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Limits at Infinity Definition", "created": "2023-10-23T15:03:01Z", "content": "

Are these definitions right (since only the first one is given in the course notes):

- lim (x->infinity) f(x) = inifinity: for all M>0, there exists an N in real numbers s.t. if x>N then f(x) >M

- lim (x->infinity) f(x) = -infinity: for all M<0, there exists an  N in real numbers s.t. if x>N then f(x)<M

- lim (x->-infinity) f(x) = infinity: for all M>0, there exists an N in real numbers s.t. if x<N then f(x)>M

- lim (x->-infinity) f(x) = - infinity: for all M<0, there exists an N in real numbers s.t. if x<N then f(x)<M

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 118, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-23T19:54:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-23T19:54:26Z", "content": "It's a bit hard to read non-LaTeX math but I think this looks okay."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lo3bgi82anh47t", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lo311qzcz5oqo", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514093244, "default_anonymity": "no"}

\n

\n

Same applies to C. Derivative of b is DNE, not 0.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz5"], "nr": 552, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-31T03:05:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lodqyb0qmbo21u", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-31T03:05:52Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lof033iwvmj27u", "to": "lodqyb0mg1i21s", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-01T00:09:19Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice Problems MT - Question #8: How much of the solution given do we need to show?", "created": "2023-10-31T03:05:52Z", "content": "

I am wondering how much of the given solution we are expected to show. 

The question asks to show that the function f(x) = abs(sinx) is non-differentiable and continous for any x.

In my solution, I stated that it was continuous because it is the composition of two continuous functions; these being sin(x) and abs(x). I then showed that it was non-differentiable by taking the one sided limits of the original function and showing that they do not match at x = 0. 

Would this be enough to get full marks? I saw that the posted solution had a much longer solution.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 113, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T00:09:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T00:09:19Z", "content": "That's probably fine. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz6"], "nr": 561, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-31T23:03:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "data": "loexqpr88tl1oe", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-10-31T23:03:42Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lof04ka4zyh5mg", "to": "loexqpr55hf1od", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-01T00:10:27Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "subject": "Question about derivative", "created": "2023-10-31T23:03:42Z", "content": "since the definition of the derivative is $$\\lim_{h\\to0} \\frac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h} $$, if f(a) is not defined, we can immediately conclude that it is not differentiable at x=a right? Thank you"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz6", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 108, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T00:10:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Rosemary Liao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdh2s3927me", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T00:10:27Z", "content": "Yes. Another way to think about is that "differentiable implies continuous" and the contrapositive says "not continuous implies not differentiable." Hello, I'm wondering what exactly makes this statements false? I can't seem to reason through it in my mind.

The derivative of f (x) = |x| can be written as f ′(x) = |x|/x 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz6", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Akshayan Nimalathasan", "endorser": {"llazq0fual03ej": 1695254958, "lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697195721, "global": 1697750123}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8llfepa5yf", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 115, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-10-31T23:09:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sam Lee", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4dyzuzt6qr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "subject": "", "created": "2023-10-31T23:09:35Z", "content": "

No actually, the derivative of f(x) = |x| is  f'(x)= x/ |x| 

Here is a video that explains this: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TboqFzkx-a4

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "l6at4dyzuzt6qr"], "children": [], "id": "loexyafbbgn6j6", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

But $$\frac{|x|}{x}$$ and $$\frac{x}{|x|}$$ are the exact same function... for every x they produce the same value. It's like what's the difference between 1/-1 and -1/1, they're equivalent. 

", "created": "2023-11-01T02:42:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Akshayan Nimalathasan", "endorser": {"llazq0fual03ej": 1695254958, "lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697195721, "global": 1697750123}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8llfepa5yf", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Agreed. I'm not a huge fan of the wording of this particular question. To me, there isn't a substantial difference between the two functions; they represent the exact same thing. So it's arguable that this should maybe be true.

The reason it is written as false is given by the student answer.

Note that on an actual quiz, the instructional team makes sure that there isn't any ambiguity in our questions.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz6"], "nr": 566, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T01:16:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lof2hgorwm1lk", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-01T01:16:28Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lofrqa0r5ga29d", "to": "lof2hgoni401lj", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-01T13:03:10Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Finding Counterexamples", "created": "2023-11-01T01:16:28Z", "content": "

Is there any strategy to coming up with counterexamples to disprove claims? Anything that would help with multiple choice questions. 

Thank you for the help!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz6", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sampoorna Prakash", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697050635}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 91, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T13:03:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Harbin Kaur Dhillon", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwaij6bmq2cc", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sampoorna Prakash", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697050635}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T13:03:10Z", "content": "

One way to practice this is to think about the theorems we've covered and consider things like:

  • the converse of theorem -- if it's not an iff, chances are that the converse is false
  • relax some of the hypotheses -- chances are, this will make the statement false

and come up with counterexamples related to those two above points.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwaij6bmq2cc", "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "kggoe9bxe5d42u"], "children": [], "id": "lofrqa0ngiw29c", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["kggoe9bxe5d42u"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lof2hgoni401lj", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514141380, "default_anonymity": "no"}

If b makes function continuous, it is also differentiable.\u00a0 In this case, b = 0, it is a horizontal line which is differentiable"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T04:47:12Z", "content": "Treat it as a piecewise function. If b makes function continuous, it is also differentiable. It might be a constant or even a line(since we don't know what b is). In this case, b = 0, it is a horizontal line which is differentiable"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lofa0gxl34g4x0", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Why can you just treat b separately and say that its differentiable so therefore the function is differentiable? Also the derivative of the function at x=0 when b=0 should be 1/2, but if you just treat b as a horizontal line, the derivative would be 0.", "created": "2023-11-01T11:32:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

You can't.

\n

If $$x\\neq 0$$ then you can calculate the derivative of the function directly using our differentiation rules. For $$x=0$$, you need to use the limit definition of the derivative. You should find that this limit exists when $$b=0$$ (if I recall correctly).

", "created": "2023-11-01T19:21:12Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "log58fja91i1o3", "updated": "2023-11-01T19:21:12Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lofoh66b9of6l1", "updated": "2023-11-01T19:21:13Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T15:03:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T15:03:43Z", "content": "Just want to note that continuity doesn't mean it's differentiable. Hi there,

If we end up using $$\lim_{h\rightarrow 0} \frac{cosh-1}{h}=0$$ on the quiz, would it be required that we prove it, or that we cite it (if so, is there a name for the limit), or can we simply just use it without any justification.

Thanks!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz6"], "nr": 573, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T14:39:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lofv6h3p67z62e", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-01T14:39:44Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "data": "lofxy8lxd86zx", "to": "lofv6h3kufh62c", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-01T15:57:19Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Using multiple derivative rules in one step", "created": "2023-11-01T14:39:44Z", "content": "

Hello,

If I am taking the derivative of $$f(x) = x^2\sin(\frac{1}{x})$$, is it fine to apply the product rule and chain rule in one step to get the final answer? For example, this was my work:

$$f'(x) = (2x)(\sin(\frac{1}{x})) + (x^2)(\cos(\frac{1}{x}))(\frac{-1}{x^2})$$ (by product rule and chain rule)

$$f'(x) = 2x\sin(\frac{1}{x}) - \cos(\frac{1}{x})$$

Would this amount of steps be sufficient to get full marks?

Thank you.

Hi, shouldn't the answer for this question equal to 0. If I am wrong can someone explain to me why this is not defined. Thank you.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz6", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 81, "children": [{"history_size": 6, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T15:54:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T16:02:04Z", "content": "when $$x=0$$, $$\frac{sin(x)}{x}$$ is not continuous. Thus, it is not differentiable at $$x=0$$. Therefore $$f'(0)$$ DNE."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T16:01:40Z", "content": "when $$x=0$$, $$\frac{sin(x)}{x}$$ is not continuous. Thus, it is not differentiable at $$x=0$$. Therefore $$f'(x)$$ DNE."}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T15:55:01Z", "content": "when x=0, sin(x)/x is not cts. Thus, it is not differentiable at x=0. Therefore f'(0)DNE"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T15:54:49Z", "content": "

The derivative of $$\frac{sin(x)}{x}$$ is $$\frac{x\cdot cos(x)-sin(x)}{x^2}$$

And at $$x=0$$ it is undefined, since we would be dividing by zero.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T15:54:16Z", "content": "

For long answer question 1 on practice quiz 6. How does the conclusion f′(x) = −f′(−x) prove

f ′(−x) =−f ′(x)?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz6", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 91, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T15:58:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ryan Tonucci", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwda3897x6e4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T15:58:37Z", "content": "

$$f'(x)=-f'(-x)$$

Multiply both sides by $$-1$$

$$-f'(x)=f'(-x)$$

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwda3897x6e4"], "children": [], "id": "lofxzwy4pvs2ql", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lofxygev9itwd", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514154321, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz6", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 91, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T19:18:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T19:18:42Z", "content": "

It is not the case that $$f(x-h) = f(x+h)$$ (except for $$x=0$$).

If you think about this geometrically, $$f'(a) \approx \dfrac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h}$$ for small $$h$$.

Now, if instead you do $$f(a-h)$$, you are effectively going "backwards" from $$f(a)$$. In the limit, you would effectively pick up a negative in front. One way to see this is to use the linear approximation: $$f(x) \approx f(a) + f'(a)(x-a)$$. Plug in both $$x=a+h$$ and $$x=a-h$$ and you should see a negative appear when isolating for $$f'(a)$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "log557uskj0q4", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Thank you, after I plug in x=a+h and x=a-h, I got h = -h. However, since h approaches to 0, the statement h=-h seems to be true, which is not a contradiction? Could you further explain why $$\lim_{h\to0} f(x+h) = f(x) = \lim_{h\to0} f(x-h) $$ is wrong even though the function continuous.", "created": "2023-11-01T19:40:03Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Continuity isn't the issue. The thing I'm trying to point out is that when you have $$\dfrac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h}$$ vs $$\dfrac{f(a-h) - f(a)}{h}$$, you pick up a negative, meaning that the second term is $$-f'(a)$$.

To see this, if we approximate $$f(a+h)$$ with the linear approx at $$x=a$$, we have $$f(a+h) \approx f(a) + f'(a)h$$. Rearranging we find $$f'(a) \approx \dfrac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h}$$ (this is what we would expect as it's just recovers the definition of the derivative).

On the other hand, if we approximate $$f(a-h)$$, we get $$f(a-h) \approx f(a) + f'(a)(-h)$$. Rearranging we find $$-f'(a) \approx \dfrac{f(a-h) - f(a)}{h}$$.

The point is that in your above work on the second line, you should find that the limit evaluates to $$-f'(x)$$ and that you cannot replace $$f(x-h)$$ with $$f(x+h)$$.

You plug in 0 in the first x, making whatever follows irrelevant.

Not 100% though.
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "log9uvokmf17pa", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T21:39:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T21:57:33Z", "content": "

The one-sided limits of $$x \sin (1/x)$$ do exist and evaluate to 0, so the limit exists. If we further defined the function to evaluate to 0 at $$x=0$$ then it would be continuous.

To show those one-sided limits, you would need to use the squeeze theorem; one cannot state that 0 x DNE is 0 since the limit rules do not apply. 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T21:40:47Z", "content": "

The one-sided limits of $$x \sin x$$ do exist and evaluate to 0, so the limit exists. If we further defined the function to evaluate to 0 at $$x=0$$ then it would be continuous.

To show those one-sided limits, you would need to use the squeeze theorem; one cannot state that 0 x DNE is 0 since the limit rules do not apply. 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T21:39:34Z", "content": "The one-sided limits of $$x \sin x$$ do exist and evaluate to 0, so the limit exists. If we further defined the function to evaluate to 0 at $$x=0$$ then it would be continuous."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "loga6dct6si4ge", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "but I was asking x*sin(1/x)", "created": "2023-11-01T21:46:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Sorry, that was a typo on my end. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz6"], "nr": 598, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T21:37:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "loga43kfacc64u", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-01T21:37:48Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "data": "loga6b4bbdh6me", "to": "loga43kcec864s", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-01T21:39:31Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "logc2xnz3st3rf", "to": "loga43kcec864s", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-01T22:32:53Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Week 6 Quiz question", "created": "2023-11-01T21:37:48Z", "content": "

Why should I use squeeze theorem at the end of solution? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz6", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Smeet Shah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwda7cwkc6ez", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 133, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T21:39:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "professor", "name": "Eric Bembenek", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "gshu3x2txqf", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T21:39:31Z", "content": "You reach a point when solving the question where you cannot proceed with traditional algebraic reasoning, so you have to use alternative methods such as the squeeze theorem."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["gshu3x2txqf"], "children": [], "id": "loga6b46kjo6md", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-01T22:32:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-01T22:32:53Z", "content": "

It seems like you would like to use the arithmetic rules for limits, i.e., you want to do $$\lim_{h\to0} h \sin(1/h) = \lim_{h\to0} h \lim_{h\to0} \sin(1/h) = 0$$, however, you CANNOT apply the limit rules unless both limits exist on their own.

Here, $$\lim_{h\to0} \sin(1/h)$$ DNE so you cannot apply the limit rules. Hence the need for the squeeze theorem.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "logc2xnydmx3re", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwda7cwkc6ez"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "loga43kcec864s", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514176344, "default_anonymity": "no"}

why is b incorrect? this is what IVT is. 

Let f be a function defined on the interval [−1, 1]. If the equation f (x) = 0 has a solution
inside [−1, 1], then:
(a) f (−1) and f (1) must have different signs.
(b) There must be two distinct real numbers a and b inside [−1, 1] such that f (a) and
f (b) have different signs.
(c) f must be continuous on [−1, 1].
(d) None of the above has to be true.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Afnan Al-Banaa", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw88ajod33oq", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 104, "children": [{"history_size": 5, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-03T03:12:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Afnan Al-Banaa", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw88ajod33oq", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw86mj9cd3a3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-03T03:14:50Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz7"], "nr": 607, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-04T21:07:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lokjca8gw4w1ub", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-04T21:07:11Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwad9oocb1eb", "data": "lokjj00equ1ek", "to": "lokjca8do2m1ua", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-04T21:12:24Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lokjca8do2m1ua", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-04T21:13:13Z", "cid": "lokjk1bq1edz6", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwad9oocb1eb", "to": "lokjca8do2m1ua", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-04T21:13:27Z", "cid": "lokjkcbn9233oi"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lokjca8do2m1ua", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-05T18:11:45Z", "cid": "lolsijbrzty7n9", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lokjca8do2m1ua", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-05T18:13:14Z", "cid": "lolskfv9el33lu", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice questions Q3 week 7", "created": "2023-11-04T21:07:11Z", "content": "

For part b of Q3 of the week 7 practice questions, why did we chooe a=7 and a=pi for the 2 estimates?

\n

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz7", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 91, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-04T21:12:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yilin", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwam6q3i52z9", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwad9oocb1eb", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-04T21:12:24Z", "content": "From $$3a)$$, we know that the formula for the sequence generated by the polynomial $$x^2-a$$ is $$x_{n+1} = \\frac{1}{2} (x_n + \\frac{a}{x_n})$$. The polynomial $$f(x)\u00a0 =x^2-a$$ has roots $$x = \\pm \\sqrt{a}$$, so if we want to find the approximation for $$\\sqrt{7}$$, we can let $$a=7$$ and then perform Newton's method where the first step is $$x_1 = 3$$ as given by the question, then $$x_2 = \\frac{1}{2} (x_1 + \\frac{7}{x_n1}) = \\frac{1}{2}(3+\\frac{7}{3}) \\approx 2.66667$$, etc."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwam6q3i52z9"], "children": [], "id": "lokjj00ahqb1ej", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "ohh that makes sense. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 608, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-05T19:14:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lolurpmx5ud37p", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-05T19:14:53Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "data": "lom9pcdplcg2t4", "to": "lolurpmujyg37o", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-06T02:12:56Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Linear Approximation--Over/Under estimation", "created": "2023-11-05T19:14:53Z", "content": "Hi, does anyone know if the point in this graph's linear approximation is overestimated or underestimated?
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 75, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-06T02:12:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Zhirui Lyu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwehdad3p7l6", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-06T02:12:56Z", "content": "If the graph of the linear approximation is under the graph of the function at the point in question, then you have an under-approximation."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehdad3p7l6"], "children": [], "id": "lom9pcdmfxy2t3", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lolurpmujyg37o", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514187178, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz7"], "nr": 609, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-05T20:42:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "data": "lolxwtk2k4nqx", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-05T20:42:50Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lom71eom77h6jo", "to": "lolxwtjze83qw", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-06T00:58:20Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "subject": "question about trig power", "created": "2023-11-05T20:42:50Z", "content": "

if $$cos^{2}(x) = (cos(x))^{2}$$, why can't we also say that \u00a0$$cos^{-1} (x)= (cos(x))^{-1} $$ ? Why doing the same step will caused error for -1 which leads \u00a0$$arccos(x) = cos^{-1}(x) = \u00a0\\frac{1}{cos(x)} = sec(x)$$.

\n

Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz7", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 85, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-06T00:58:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-06T00:58:20Z", "content": "The notation $$\\cos^{-1}(x)$$ is ambiguous: it could mean $$\\arccos(x)$$ or it could mean $$\\frac{1}{cos(x)}$$.

Thus, we use $$\\arccos(x)$$ to denote the inverse function of cosine and $$\\sec(x)$$ to denote the reciprocal of cosine. Note that $$\\arccos(x) \\neq \\sec(x)$$, i.e., these are two different functions."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lom71eoj55j6jn", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lolxwtjze83qw", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514188250, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz7"], "nr": 613, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-06T02:11:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lom9nt6kxi61in", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-06T02:11:45Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "data": "lom9u6jtow7mf", "to": "lom9nt6h8d31im", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-06T02:16:42Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw92uc1gd161", "data": "lomel9tm3xy1fk", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-06T04:29:45Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw92uc1gd161", "data": "lomembd2nwb3m5", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-06T04:30:33Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Why is this log rule true?", "created": "2023-11-06T02:11:45Z", "content": "

I've heard this being referred to as the change of base rule. Would appreciate an explanation as to why it is true. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz7", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 101, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-06T02:16:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Amadi Opara", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8j0ruc25io", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw92uc1gd161", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-06T04:30:33Z", "content": "

$$log_a(x) = y$$

$$a^y = x$$

Since, $$a = b^{log_b(a)}$$

So, $$a^y = b^{log_b(a)⋅y} = x$$

Taking $$log_b$$ on both sides, $$log_b(b^{log_b(a)⋅y}) = log_b(x)$$

$$log_b(a)⋅y = log_b(x)$$ 

$$y = \frac{log_b(x)}{log_b(a)}$$

Since, $$y = log_a(x)$$

Therefore, $$log_a(x) = \frac{log_b(x)}{log_b(a)}$$

This proof is generic for any base $$b$$. If you let $$b = e$$, the result will equal to the one you have put above, i.e. $$log_a(x) = \frac{ln(x)}{ln(a)}$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw92uc1gd161", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-06T04:29:45Z", "content": "

$$log_a(x) = y$$

$$a^y = x$$

Since, $$a = b^{log_b(a)}$$

So, $$a^y = b^{log_b(a)⋅y} = x$$

Taking $$log_b$$ on both sides, $$log_b(b^{log_b(a)⋅y}) = log_b(x)$$

$$log_b(a)⋅y = log_b(x)$$ 

$$y = \frac{log_b(x)}{log_b(a)}$$

Since, $$y = log_a(x)$$

Therefore, $$log_a(x) = \frac{log_b(x)}{log_b(a)}$$

This proof is generic for any base $$b$$. If you let $$b = e$$, the result will equal to the one you have put above, i.e. $$ln(x) = \frac{ln(x)}{ln(a)}$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-06T02:16:42Z", "content": "You can find videos online showing the proof if you want to. "}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "lkqw8j0ruc25io"], "children": [], "id": "lom9u6jox4hme", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lom9nt6h8d31im", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514192537, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 102, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-07T00:55:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1697485981}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Nicole Anne Go", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdqj252r1jl", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-07T00:55:10Z", "content": "

First, we find $$f''(x) = -\sin(x) - \cos(x)$$ so that $$|f''(x)| = |\sin x + \cos x| \leq |\sin x| + |\cos x|$$ by trig inequality.

Then, the largest value that $$|\sin x|, |\cos x|$$ take is 1, so we find that $$|f''(x)| \leq 2$$.

The formula for $$(f^{-1})'(x)$$ is not defined when the derivative $$f'(x)=0$$. If you calculate the derivative of arcsine you get $$(\arcsin(x))' = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}$$. Notice that when $$x=1$$, the derivative is undefined.

This is consistent with the IFT since $$\sin(\pi/2) = 1$$ means that $$\arcsin(1) = \pi/2$$ and $$(\sin(\pi/2))' = 0$$ so we would expect that $$(\arcsin(1))'$$ to be undefined.

Sorry, I didn't read the original question since the image was posted sideways.

The domain being $$(\pi/2, 3\pi/2)$$ isn't the issue (or at least, not directly). Instead, when you do the special triangle to calculate $$\cos(\arcsin(x))$$ with $$\theta =\arcsin(x)$$. I believe you should pick up a negative sign when computing $$\cos \theta$$.

More intuitively, if you think about the graph of $$\sin(x)$$ on $$[\pi/2, 3\pi/2]$$, then you should notice that it's the same shape as $$\cos(x)$$ on $$[0,\pi]$$, so the derivative should look like the derivative of $$\arccos(x)$$ which is $$-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}$$.

If it fair to state that:

\n

La(x) is the only linear polynomial with properties that la(a)=f(a) and la'(a)=f'(a)

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz7", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 101, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-08T13:54:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-08T13:54:42Z", "content": "Here's an exercise: we have the linear approximation $$L_a(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a)$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz8"], "nr": 632, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-08T14:53:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lopvqzgrrxrdj", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-08T14:53:23Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "loq7c2v76ll56l", "to": "lopvqzgm9ygdh", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-08T20:17:43Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Newton Method not working", "created": "2023-11-08T14:53:23Z", "content": "How do you know when newton's method won't work for a function? Besides plugging values in and seeing it diverge is there a way to look at a function and know that it won't work?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 88, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-08T20:17:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-08T20:17:43Z", "content": "

One foolproof way is to check $$f'(x)$$. If the initial guess $$x_1$$ has $$f'(x_1) =0$$ then it will fail. Other than that, you would start calculating iterations and see if it looks like the terms are converging to a value.

\n

\n

(I believe there are some other techniques that can help you determine whether it fails for a particular guess, but that it beyond the scope of the course)

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz7", "other"], "nr": 638, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-08T18:02:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "loq2ibejg6s43n", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-08T18:02:36Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "loq7e7yjoz2uo", "to": "loq2ibefg3d43m", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-08T20:19:23Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "loq89ttwek7bw", "to": "loq2ibefg3d43m", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-08T20:43:58Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Newtons method limitations", "created": "2023-11-08T18:02:36Z", "content": "

Hello,

I was reading through some course notes and found that newton's method can sometimes not work because if you pick a point too far from the root, the sequence may diverge.

Could someone please explain this further as it was kind of confusing to me where the term sequence came from when we are talking about functions.

I would also really appreciate if you could give me an example of this happening

Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "quiz7", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 83, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-08T20:19:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-08T20:19:23Z", "content": "The iterations are a recursive sequence: $$x_{n+1} = x_n - \dfrac{f(x_n)}{f'(x_n)}$$ with an initial value $$x_1$$. Hence we can talk about the sequence $$\{x_n \}$$ converging or diverging."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwca7ky8m6lh"], "children": [], "id": "loq7e7yfa1q2um", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-08T20:43:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-08T20:43:58Z", "content": "

I might be wrong but i think an example of it failing would be  : 
For $$f(x) = \sqrt[3] x$$
We can define a recursive sequence : 
$$-2x_{n}$$
Here f(x) crosses the x-axis at x=0. If we use the recursive sequence for an x thats too far away, say x=2, we get x=-4. Then if we use x=-4, we get x=8, then x=-16, ...
We're getting further away from the root and it will never converge to anything.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz7"], "nr": 648, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-09T00:54:12Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "loqh7mzzw7a769", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-09T00:54:12Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lor97q9r9er1k7", "to": "loqh7mzwyro768", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-09T13:58:06Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Long Answer Questions on Quizzes", "created": "2023-11-09T00:54:12Z", "content": "Hi, this is a general question, but I am wondering on quizzes, if we get the correct answer on the long answer questions but our work is not correct, or we used a different method than we were meant to would we still get full marks, considering we found the correct answer? Or will we get marks taken off if some of our work is incorrect. Thanks."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz7", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 105, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-09T13:58:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-09T13:58:06Z", "content": "Generally yes, as long as the different method is valid. If the method is invalid, then it is possible there may be a part-mark for a correct final answer (but this is not always the case).

For example, on one of the previous quizzes, there was a question of the form $$\\displaystyle \\lim_{x\\to 0} x^2 \\sin(\\frac{1}{x})$$ and many students used the limit rules to show the limit to be 0. However, the limit rules cannot be applied since the limit of $$\\sin(\\frac{1}{x})$$ DNE and hence one needs to use the squeeze theorem. So applying the limit rules would not result in full points."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lor97q9nhzs1k5", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "loqh7mzwyro768", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514322758, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz7"], "nr": 649, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-09T01:21:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "loqi6wypekffp", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-09T01:21:38Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lor93c91asb3o9", "to": "loqi6wyldj7fo", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-09T13:54:41Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "linear function definition", "created": "2023-11-09T01:21:38Z", "content": "In Math137, is a constant function considered a linear function?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz7", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jiayi Zhao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwci5lhj4a0", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sam Lee", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4dyzuzt6qr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Erin Fan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwayddv4r53q", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 103, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-09T13:54:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-09T13:54:41Z", "content": "

A polynomial is of the form $$p(x) = c_n x^n + c_{n-1}x^{n-1} + \\dots + c_1 x + c_0$$ where $$c_i \\in \\mathbb{R}$$. Because of this, we can pick $$c_i = 0$$ except $$c_0$$ so a constant function would be a polynomial.

\n

\n

By the same logic, a linear function is of the form $$y = ax + b$$ where $$a,b \\in \\mathbb{R}$$ and we can take $$a=0$$ and say that any constant is also a linear function.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lor93c8xgru3o8", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwci5lhj4a0", "l6at4dyzuzt6qr", "lkqwayddv4r53q"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "loqi6wyldj7fo", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514323848, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hello,

For quiz 7B MC 51 when I was writing the quiz I was confused by the question because there was no domain given, and we know arccos is only differentiable on certain domains. I asked a proctor what the domain of x was and he told me this question was asking the derivative of arccos for all real numbers, or $$\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}arccos(x), x\epsilon \mathbb{R}$$.

Then shouldn't the answer be d), as the derivative of arccos(x) DNE for all x?

I would appreciate if someone could explain

Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz7", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 95, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-12T06:57:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-12T06:59:27Z", "content": "Sigh, that TA shouldn't answer that question.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz8"], "nr": 658, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-11T20:42:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "louijmq45i5315", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-11T20:42:36Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "loynmq6c6cg6gj", "to": "louijmq0uxe314", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-14T18:16:03Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "louijmq0uxe314", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-15T21:06:13Z", "cid": "lp095ejds322ii", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "to": "louijmq0uxe314", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-16T14:43:16Z", "cid": "lp1awsljps1224"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice Problem 8 Q9", "created": "2023-11-11T20:42:36Z", "content": "

Is it because f(0) DNE thus it not is differentiable at x=0, so there is no critical point?

But I am a bit confused that if it is not differentiable does it mean f'(0) DNE and if f'(0) DNE  then there is a critical point. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 90, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-14T18:16:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-14T18:16:03Z", "content": "If you try to find the value for $$\frac{|x|}{x}$$, you will realize it's not continuous at x = 0 o.o"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "loynmq68br56gi", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Just as a followup clarification question, couldn't it still be argued that the point is a critical point?

If it's not continuous at x=0, then it's not differentiable at x=0.

And if it's not differentiable at x=0, the derivative does not exist.

If the derivative doesn't exist, wouldn't it be a critical point?

", "created": "2023-11-15T21:06:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Your thinking is correct.

The reason the answer is false is that $$|x|/x$$ is undefined at $$x=0$$. That is, $$x=0$$ is not in the domain of $$f(x)$$ and hence is not a critical point.

", "created": "2023-11-16T14:43:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lp1awsljps1224", "updated": "2023-11-16T14:43:16Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lp095ejds322ii", "updated": "2023-11-16T14:43:18Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "louijmq0uxe314", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 7, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514333412, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz7"], "nr": 660, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-12T05:33:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lov1i37pu4i1qm", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-12T05:33:17Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lov4zgk5uww1v", "to": "lov1i37lg221ql", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-12T07:10:46Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lov50laqo261qh", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-12T07:11:39Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Week 8 practice question 7", "created": "2023-11-12T05:33:17Z", "content": "Could anyone explain what's being said in the solution that the derivative of the function is not equal to 0 so it is not possible to have 2 or more values that makes f(x) = 0. Why is this?\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz7", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 70, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-12T07:10:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-12T07:11:39Z", "content": "Consider mean value theorem. When we say the function has two roots, that means there exists 2 values of x, $$x_1$$ and $$x_2$$ such that $$f(x_1) = f(x_2) = 0$$. Which, by MVT, we should be able to find a value $$c$$ between $$x_1$$ and $$x_2$$ such that f'(c) = 0.

However, since $$ f'(x) > 0,\u00a0 \\forall x \\in \\mathbb{R}$$, that means there is no such $$c$$ that f'(c) = 0. Which means there is no way to have more than 2 roots."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-12T07:10:46Z", "content": "Consider mean value theorem. When we say the function has two roots, that means there exists 2 values of x, $$x_1$$ and $$x_2$$ such that $$f(x_1) = f(x_2) = 0$$. Which, by MVT, we should be able to find a value $$c$$ between $$x_1$$ and $$x_2$$ such that f'(c) = 0.

However, since f'(x) > 0 for all x belongs to real, that means there is no such $$c$$ that f'(c) = 0. Which means there is no way to have more than 2 roots."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lov4zgk1h6g1u", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lov1i37lg221ql", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514335527, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz8"], "nr": 666, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-14T16:04:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "loyixbk49p65i4", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-14T16:04:19Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lozubit0l9n5ds", "to": "loyixbjz2sb5i3", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-15T14:11:04Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Logarithmic Differentiation Restrictions?", "created": "2023-11-14T16:04:19Z", "content": "Hi. Just wondering, when we use logarithmic differentiation on a function f that is defined for all reals, how do we deal with the restrictions on ln (that requires x>0)? I think one of the practice solutions used absolute value on f, but how to deal with when f=0 (since ln f would then be undefined)?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 108, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-15T14:11:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-15T14:11:04Z", "content": "$$\\ln x$$ is undefined at $$x=0$$ (i.e., not continuous) so it is not differentiable there."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lozubisw8hq5dr", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "loyixbjz2sb5i3", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514342157, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-15T05:19:28Z", "content": "

I don't really get your question, but:

Solve for $$\frac {dx}{dy}$$ and you can see that a) is true

b) f(0) doesn't exist so false

c) Should be true, there is probably a mistake there

Reason: $$\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{y^2(x^3 + 2 y^2)}{x(2y^3 - x^2)}$$. Then if x = -1, y = $$\frac {1}{\sqrt {2}}$$. Therefore, true.

Nota that a) asks for $$\frac{dx}{dy}$$, while c) asks for $$\frac{dy}{dx}$$

d)

Just show that bottom is 0 and top is not.

One problem is that we don't know whether they want tangent line as in $$\frac{dx}{dy}$$ or $$\frac {dy}{dx}$$

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz8"], "nr": 676, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-15T09:51:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lozl1w5pbql3ea", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-15T09:51:38Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lozua3azbgc387", "to": "lozl1w5m2j83e9", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-15T14:09:57Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lozl1w5m2j83e9", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-15T14:41:58Z", "cid": "lozvf94snoe6ou", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "to": "lozl1w5m2j83e9", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-15T15:15:39Z", "cid": "lozwmkwkq8r3d9"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "to": "lozl1w5m2j83e9", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-16T14:41:30Z", "cid": "lp1auidrz126an"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Roots and Derivative", "created": "2023-11-15T09:51:38Z", "content": "Do the number of roots a function has have ant correlation with the number of critical points "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 69, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-15T14:09:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1697485981}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-15T14:09:57Z", "content": "

It's an interesting idea!

Sadly, there is no correlation. For example, you could have a function with an infinite number of critical points but no roots, e.g. $$\sin(x) + 2$$, or it could have no critical points and still have a root, e.g., $$\frac{1}{x} - 1$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt"], "children": [], "id": "lozua3ave6j386", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Would there be a special case for polynomials? I was wondering because the solution for 7 in the extra practice, I didn't understand the part where it says that it means it has 1 or 0 roots.

", "created": "2023-11-15T14:41:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

The solution for 7 implies that there is x value, such that derivative is 0. In other words, solution says that let there be more than 1 root in f(x) for a contradiction. Then, there is a and b such that f(a) = 0 and f(b) = 0.

If that is the case, then f'(c)=0, c$$\in (x_1, x_2)$$.

I don't think that polynomials are a special case, but I might be wrong.

", "created": "2023-11-15T15:15:39Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "ta", "name": "David-Nuo Cheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "lkqwazmzrpb5c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["kcat0wu2cik59z"], "id": "lozwmkwkq8r3d9", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-11-15T17:30:49Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

We can say that a odd-powered polynomial will definitely have at least 1 real root. This is because $$\lim_{x\to\infty} x^{2k+1} = \infty$$ and $$\lim_{x\to-\infty} x^{2k+1} = -\infty$$, so you'd be able to find some numbers $$a,b\in\mathbb{R}$$ such that $$f(a) < 0$$ and $$f(b) >0$$, so by IVT, you know there's at least one root.

We can also say that any polynomial of degree $$n$$ has, at most, $$n$$ real roots. For example, $$x^2 - 1$$ has two real roots but $$x^2+1$$ has no real roots.

However, if we allow for complex numbers, then we can say that any polynomial of degree $$n$$ has $$n$$ complex roots, e.g., $$x^2+1$$ has roots $$x = \pm i$$ where $$i= \sqrt{-1}$$. This is known as the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fundamental_theorem_of_algebra). I'll note that complex numbers are beyond the scope of 137 though; MATH 137 keep things real.

For 10, you can imagine a counter example of $|x|$ (appropriately shifted and scaled to satisfy the conditions in the problem).

One thing to point out about 11 is that it talks about differentiability on a closed interval and this is something that we haven't discussed in 137. For our purpose (at least in our course notes), we only talk about differentiability on an open interval. This is because the definition of differentiable: $$f'(a) = \lim_{h\to0} \frac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h}$$ is only doable on an open interval (since we'd need $$h\to0^+$$ and $$h\to0^-$$).

I was wondering this because I was trying to determine if global extrema also have f'(x) = 0 or f'(x) DNE?

I understand that global extrema are also local extrema, except the ones at the endpoints, so it should be true in the case when global extrema are within an open interval, but what about global extrema at the endpoints of a closed interval?

Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz8", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Michael Volovyk", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwd3xnhyi5aw", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 77, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-15T17:46:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-15T17:46:43Z", "content": "I think it depends on what you’re trying to differentiate. With the given restriction, we can apply ln to both sides in part a) and not have any issues. However, in b), if we ln both sides then the derivative doesn’t make sense for negative x. So, we use abs Val to resolve that issue. 

You could have a situation where there is no restriction but you don’t need to do anything special: ie: $$y=(x^2+1)^{2x}$$, since $$ln(x^2+1)$$ exists $$\forall x\in \mathbb{R}$$. 

Bottom line, I believe it depends on the question, not whether it’s restricted. Usually we want to avoid abs Val because it can be annoying to work with. 
"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-15T17:46:06Z", "content": "I think it depends on what you’re trying to differentiate. With the given restriction, we can apply ln to both sides in part a) and not have any issues. However, in b), if we ln both sides then the derivative doesn’t make sense for negative x. So, we use abs Val to resolve that issue. 

You could have a situation where there is no restriction but you don’t need to do anything special: ie: $$y=(x^2+1)^{2x}$$, since $$ln(x^2+1)$$ exists $$/forall x/in /mathbb{R}$$. 

Bottom line, I believe it depends on the question, not whether it’s restricted. Usually we want to avoid abs Val because it can be annoying to work with.

A little late to this question, but I didn't have anything like that on version B today, so hopefully all is well.

Our professor said that we should know the Pythagorean identities, the quotient identities, and the reciprocal identities. All other identities (like angle sum and double angle) will be provided to us. 

I would become familiar with even-odd and cofunction identities too just to be safe but I don't know if that's necessary-- I think I'm just remembering using them on MTHEL99.

Here's a picture I pulled off Google for reference:

This is an elementary question but I have never learned the notation I->R before, does this mean the interval is all real numbers?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 91, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-15T21:18:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Lydia He", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwclm3shhvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-15T21:22:11Z", "content": "

Yes. "I" would be a set of real numbers.

If the statement showed "I -> N" for natural numbers then you would have to consider a interval where f(x) is only evaluated with natural numbers... which would be somewhat weird.

Really, the notation isn't much of a concern, I promise :)

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-15T21:18:43Z", "content": "Yes. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz8"], "nr": 699, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-16T01:16:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lp0i3bowik6100", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-16T01:16:32Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lp0ib9mx29566s", "to": "lp0i3botvs1zz", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-16T01:22:43Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lp0icwm1vcm2ij", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-16T01:23:59Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lp0idbuqkap3f9", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-16T01:24:19Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "rolle's throrem", "created": "2023-11-16T01:16:32Z", "content": "For me, there's some confusion regarding Rolle's theorem: why does the c only exist in (x1,x2) rather than [x1,x2]?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 98, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-16T01:22:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-16T01:24:19Z", "content": "Typically the derivative (two-sided limit) isn\u2019t defined at the endpoints, since we don\u2019t know what is outside the interval, so we conclude that f\u2019(c) has to be 0 somewhere in the open interval, not the closed.\u00a0

Edit: plus Rolle\u2019s thm assumes that f(x) is diff\u00e9rentiable on (a, b), not [a, b]
"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-16T01:23:59Z", "content": "Typically the derivative (two-sided limit) isn\u2019t defined at the endpoints, since we don\u2019t know what is outside the interval, so we conclude that f\u2019(c) has to be 0 somewhere in the open interval, not the closed.\u00a0

Edit: plus Rolle\u2019s thm assumes that f(x) is diff\u00e9rentiable on (a,b), not [a.b]
"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-16T01:22:43Z", "content": "Typically the derivative (two-sided limit) isn\u2019t defined at the endpoints, since we don\u2019t know what is outside the interval, so we conclude that f\u2019(c) has to be 0 somewhere in the open interval, not the closed.\u00a0"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lp0ib9mtbdy66r", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lp0i3botvs1zz", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514378331, "default_anonymity": "no"}

We've uploaded a few PDFs related to content in MATH 137. They can be found under Content -> Weekly Outline & Practice Problems -> Extra Practice.

Another free resource would be: https://lyryx.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Guichard-Calculus-EarlyTranscendentals-2017A.pdf

There are intro calculus textbooks available in the library. Another good resource would be any of the Calculus by James Stewart. New copies are expensive (~$200 on Amazon), however, any older edition would be useful. It also covers the content of several courses: functions, limits, differentiation, integrals, differential equations, sequences and series, vector calculus, multivariable calculus.

Method will converge.

\n

Is a constant function considered a linear function, even though the x term has a degree of 0?

It's very helpful to know where I stand in the class.\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["logistics", "other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Emma C", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwaf36re71ph", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Jayden DeSouza", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcef64b7ck", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Kai Huang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwccxlksg732", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Michael Volovyk", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwd3xnhyi5aw", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 105, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-17T14:02:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ismail Hosny", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwa900l7one", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-17T14:02:16Z", "content": "

I'm not sure if that's very useful since the graph is skewed. That said, we can start including it for the rest of the quizzes, assuming that it doesn't cause much confusion.

In terms of knowing where you stand in the class, I would argue it's better to compare your performance against yourself (i.e., how are you scoring today compared to quizzes 1, 2, 3, etc.) rather than the entirety of the class. Recall that you need a 60 to pass the course and take 138 in the Winter term, whether you have a 68 or 70 or 75 doesn't matter in that context.

\n

\n

This is also true for any sort of general life stuff too: you'll always find individuals that outperform you so the better comparison to make is to your past self.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz9"], "nr": 711, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-18T01:21:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lp3d5zntmovhq", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-18T01:21:57Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lp5qqwp9w8r1qy", "to": "lp3d5znpi1dhp", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-19T17:17:40Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "Week 9 practice problem 1", "created": "2023-11-18T01:21:57Z", "content": "

Perhaps I'm misremembering from high school, but why do we include when $$f(x)=0$$ in our interval of increasing and decreasing? Like in 1a), $$f(x)$$ is increasing on $$x\in[-2, 0]\cup [2, \infty)$$. Wouldn't $$x=-2, 0, 2$$ mean that $$f(x)$$ is neither decreasing nor increasing so we shouldn't include it in the answer?

Also for 1d), I don't really understand what the solution is saying in the note

Are they just saying that we should show the interval is continuous instead of having it divided?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz9", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 111, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-19T17:17:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-19T17:17:40Z", "content": "

Here is our definition for increasing:

For $$f(x) = x^4-8x^2$$ we know that $$f(2) < f(x)$$ for any $$x>2$$, so we would included $$2$$ in our interval of increase. Similar for the other two cases you mentioned.

For 1d, they're just combining the two intervals since that $$f(x)$$ is increasing on $$[-1,\infty)$$ instead of "separately" on $$[-1,2]$$ and then $$[2,\infty)$$.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz9", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 88, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-19T22:39:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Milind Singh Meetarbhan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcbcphb86sf", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-19T22:39:34Z", "content": "Okay the general idea is, say limit of g(x) as x->a is equal to an arbituary number L < 0.
