However you can always find an $$\epsilon < |L|$$ which $$|g(x) - L| > \epsilon$$, which contradicts."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwcbcphb86sf"], "children": [], "id": "lp628v9a2f26iv", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lp5kh92hguq99", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514397429, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz9"], "nr": 718, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-19T18:42:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lp5trtrzwnmkb", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-19T18:42:22Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lp620c6jxea371", "to": "lp5trtrvseyka", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-19T22:32:56Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lp620w5hxo44ma", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2023-11-19T22:33:22Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Week 9 Practice Problem 7", "created": "2023-11-19T18:42:22Z", "content": "

Hi, 

For the following question

How did they determine the following inequalities

$$x + sin(x)cos(x) \geq x-1$$. 

$$f(x)e^{sin(x)} \geq \frac{x-1}{e}$$

Thank you for your time. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz9", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 87, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-19T22:32:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nadia Anwar", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdnjctl125", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-19T22:33:22Z", "content": "Consider sin(x)cos(x). Note that both sin(x) and cos(x)'s range are [-1, 1], then we can say $$-1 \leq sin(x)cos(x) \leq 1$$, which leads to $$x-1 \leq x+ sin(x)cos(x) \leq x+ 1$$, which we can conclude $$f(x) \geq x-1$$.

Now, also because $$-1 \leq sin(x) \leq 1$$, then $$\frac{1}{e} \leq e^{sin(x)} \leq e$$, which $$e^{sin(x)} \geq \frac{1}{e}$$. Multiply $$f(x) \geq x-1$$ to the inequality, we can get $$f(x)e^{sin(x)} \geq \frac{x-1}{e}$$.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-19T22:32:56Z", "content": "Consider sin(x)cos(x). Note that both sin(x) and cos(x)'s range are [-1, 1], then we can say $$-1 \leq sin(x)cos(x) \leq 1$$, which leads to $$x-1 \leq x+ sin(x)cos(x) \leq x+ 1$$, which we can conclude $$f(x) \geq x-1$$.

Now, also because $$-1 \leq sin(x) \leq 1$$, then $$\frac{1}{e} \leq e^{sin(x)} \leq e$$, which $$e^{sin(x)} \geq \frac{1}{e}$$. Multiply $$f(x) \geq x-1$$. to the inequality, we can get $$f(x)e^{sin(x)} \geq \frac{x-1}{e}$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdnjctl125"], "children": [], "id": "lp620c6fhm3370", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lp5trtrvseyka", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514398497, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz8"], "nr": 719, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-19T23:28:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "data": "lp63zhbj9v553n", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-19T23:28:15Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lp8d3tew4z46hh", "to": "lp63zhbg10d53m", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-21T13:19:06Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "to": "lp63zhbg10d53m", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-25T20:02:38Z", "cid": "lpeha601ywb62j"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "to": "lp63zhbg10d53m", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-12-01T21:43:23Z", "cid": "lpn5iu3rvds3z4"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpn5lkiwuf64bd", "to": "lp63zhbg10d53m", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-01T21:45:30Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "subject": "Question about continuity and limit operations.", "created": "2023-11-19T23:28:15Z", "content": "

Could some prove why if the function is continuous, the following operation is allowed.

$$lim_{x\to\infty} ln(\frac{51x}{x+7} )= ln( \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{51x}{x+7})$$

By the way, does both function need to be continuous for this operation, or only the outer function is continuous (ln) will be sufficient for this operation.

thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 78, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-21T13:19:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xinhao Wang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwelvposqnn", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-21T13:19:06Z", "content": "

I'm certainly not up to the challenge of proving this for you, but I can offer some insights as to why it's true. In the Course Notes, [Thm 11: Sequential Characterization of Limits] and [Thm 15: Continuity of compositions] show that the limit of a sequence that approaches $$\infty$$ and is equal to $$a$$ is also equal to $$f(a)$$. You can also look at the proof of Thm 15 in lecture slides (One example is Lec 14 006_Kotecha (Continuity), which you can find under instructor content).

In terms of your second question, I think only the outer one needs to be continuous, then you can examine the inner limit and see whether it exists or not. In this case, the inner function would be discontinuous at $$x=-7$$ but I'm not sure if that matters since we want $$x\to\infty$$. The inner function might need to be continuous for $$x$$ near to $$a$$.

Would appreciate an instructor's insights on this question as well.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwelvposqnn"], "children": [], "id": "lp8d3tetv5f6hg", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "It had been a week. (Thank you for the insights by the way", "created": "2023-11-25T20:02:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "This is just an application of the continuity of compositions theorem which is proven in the course notes (p 112).", "created": "2023-12-01T21:43:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lpn5iu3rvds3z4", "updated": "2023-12-01T21:43:23Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpeha601ywb62j", "updated": "2023-12-01T21:43:25Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-01T21:45:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-01T21:45:30Z", "content": "The student answer is correct.

For a composition of functions, $$h(x) = g(f(x))$$, you need $$f$$ to be continuous at $$a$$ and $$g$$ to be continuous $$f(a)$$ and then you can conclude that $$h(x)$$ is also continuous at $$x=a$$."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpn5lkivdii4bc", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lp63zhbg10d53m", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514399559, "default_anonymity": "no"}

After doing LHR once you get 1/ (2x/1+x^2)). Since the denominator is 2x/1+x^2, applying LHR to this would give 1/x and so the overall limit DNE. 

or after doing LHR the first time you would get 1+x^2/2x, and applying LHR (as this is indeterminate form) would also suggest the overall limit DNE? Which approach is accurate or are both not correct?

I would probably do it as

$$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to\infty}\frac{x}{\ln(1+x^2)} \stackrel{LHR}{=} \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{1+x^2}{2x} \stackrel{LHR}{=} \lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{2x}{2} = \infty$$

If you apply the MVT on the interval $$[0,6]$$, what happens?"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l6at1dot3d61zg"], "children": [], "id": "lp75av1p5303o6", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Sorry, I'm still a bit confused by this explanation - if someone wouldn't mind re-explaining?

I understand the contradiction involving MVT, but why doesn't the following method work?

Why can't we apply half of the Bounded Derivative Theorem?

If f(6) = 5 and f'(x) <= 1, then can't we say,

f(0) <= f(6) + 1(x-6)

f(0) <= 5 - 6

f(0) <= -1 

-5 <= -1 and so the statement is true.

What makes this approach incorrect?

", "created": "2023-11-22T01:22:01Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "This is what I did, and I’m confused too on why this method doesn’t work?", "created": "2023-11-22T03:38:39Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lp97t6qn8l35di", "updated": "2023-11-22T03:38:39Z", "config": {}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

If you look at the statement of the Bounded Derivative Theorem





The reason it does not work is that you substitute the incorrect value for $$a$$ and $$x$$. In your case, you plugged in $$a = 6$$ and $$x = 0$$, but note that we NEED $$x\in [a,b]$$ (in this case $$b$$ is not really important) but clearly your $$x = 0$$ is not in $$[6,b]$$ becasue $$x = 0 < 6$$. If you pick $$a = 0$$ and $$b = 6$$, and pick $$x = 6\in [0,6] $$ then you get:


$$ f(6) \le f(0) + (6-0)\implies 5\le f(0) + 6\implies f(0) \ge -1$$



Which is why $$f(0)$$ cannot be $$-5$$.

Shouldn't both sides multiply by 2cos(x)?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz9", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 73, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-21T02:20:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "David", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwa7mpvvkep", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "camariut@uwaterloo.ca", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8gwt19q556", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-21T02:20:47Z", "content": "

You are multiplying everything by $$2\cos(x)$$, however you can squeeze the function using the fact that $$-2\leq 2\cos(x) \leq 2$$.

So you'd go from:

     $$\frac{1}{e} \leq e^{-\sin(x)} \leq e$$                                               (original)  

$$\Rightarrow \frac{2\cos(x)}{e} \leq 2\cos(x)e^{-\sin(x)} \leq 2\cos(x)e$$          (multiply by $$\cos(x)$$)

$$\Rightarrow \frac{-2}{e} \leq 2\cos(x)e^{-\sin(x)} \leq 2e$$                            (squeeze with the inequality previously noted)

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwa7mpvvkep", "lkqw8gwt19q556"], "children": [], "id": "lp7pl7g7d051i9", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lp7ndaf2oqs5st", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514404890, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz9"], "nr": 730, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-22T01:24:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lp93190uwwe1ip", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-22T01:24:57Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lpa2a9ivk5t2pl", "to": "lp93190r9y21io", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-22T17:51:44Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice 9 Q7d", "created": "2023-11-22T01:24:57Z", "content": "Hi, i cannot understand how can we get the value of x when g'(x) = 0. Can someone explain, please?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz9", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Li Xuanhe", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwej5x9pg6c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 69, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-22T17:51:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-22T17:51:44Z", "content": "We examine $$g'(x) = 2\\cos^2(x)e^{\\sin(x)} + (x + \\sin(x)\\cos(x))\\cos(x)e^{\\sin(x)}$$. We're looking for where $$g'(x)=0$$. Not sure if there's a more systematic approach to doing this, but observe that both terms contain a $$\\cos(x)$$ and an $$e^{\\sin(x)}$$. Since $$e^{\\sin(x)} > 0 \\;\\;\\forall x \\in \\mathbb{R}$$, the easiest way to have $$g'(x)=0$$ is to let $$\\cos(x)=0$$, which we know is true when $$x=\\frac{\\pi}{2}, \\frac{3\\pi}{2}...$$ otherwise expressed as $$x=\\frac{(2k +1)\\pi}{2}$$ for any $$ k\\in\\mathbb{N}$$"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpa2a9is85y2pk", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwej5x9pg6c"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lp93190r9y21io", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514411275, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz9"], "nr": 732, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-22T02:16:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lp94v7xjksi1pu", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-22T02:16:15Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lpa2x2lmiv5ts", "to": "lp94v7xfrk31pt", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-22T18:09:28Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lp94v7xfrk31pt", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-22T19:55:28Z", "cid": "lpa6pdsodcx14q", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "to": "lp94v7xfrk31pt", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-22T21:21:07Z", "cid": "lpa9rj512wm58a"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Mobius Practice Q2", "created": "2023-11-22T02:16:15Z", "content": "

since f is decreasing at [-1, 0] and (0, 1/3] (as stated in the solution), why can't I conclude that f is decreasing at [-1, 1/3]?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz9", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 54, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-22T18:09:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-22T18:09:28Z", "content": "

This isn't obvious just by looking at the first derivative, but there's actually a discontinuity at $$x=0$$ (a jump). I looked at desmos to confirm this.

The red line is for when $$x\leq0$$ and the blue is for $$x>0$$. You can see that the graph hits 0 and then jumps up to 1, so I don't think we would be able to include 0 in our interval of decreasing. 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpa2x2lj7zu5tr", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Oh it is because f(x) is not continuous at x=0 therefore the option [-1, 1/3] is not correct?", "created": "2023-11-22T19:55:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Yeah pretty much. 

I think if the second function jumped below then technically it would still be decreasing (not sure if that counts though). 

But since this jump clearly goes up ( f(0)<f(0.0001) ) then by definition it isn’t decreasing on the interval including 0.

Practice Problems 9 Q9 F

Hello, 

I was wondering why f is False:

Is it because the function approaches infinity so technically the limit DNE so we can't use LHR?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz9"], "nr": 738, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-22T14:56:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lp9w1fy5nrq4m7", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-22T14:56:55Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lpa3loe4xux5ax", "to": "lp9w1fy2vy14m6", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-22T18:28:36Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "To use IFT, does the function on the interval need to be continuous or differentiable", "created": "2023-11-22T14:56:55Z", "content": "

Just wanted to confirm.

I assume the answer is no for continuity and yes for differentiability because IFT works if f'(x) is > (or >=, <, <=) for all x in the interval. This would mean that the function must differentiable across the whole interval, but that doesn't necessarily mean that the function must be continuous throughout.

Is that correct?

Thanks in advance!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz9", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 85, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-22T18:28:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Rosemary Liao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdh2s3927me", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-22T18:28:36Z", "content": "

When you say IFT, are you referring to Inverse Function Theorem or Increasing Function Theorem?

For Inverse, f has to be continuous and differentiable on the shown intervals.

For Increasing, the fact that we assume $$f'(x)>0 \;\;\; \forall x\in I$$ implies that $$f(x)$$ is differentiable $$\forall x\in I$$ and therefore $$f(x)$$ is continuous $$\forall x\in I$$. (Differentiability implies continuity / you can't differentiate a discontinuous function).

Bottom line is, with either theorem the function must be differentiable across the interval, which automatically means that it is also continuous, since differentiability implies continuity.

Hope that helps!

In high school, my teacher told me that he didn't mind the use of open or closed intervals when talking about intervals at a continuous point.

\n

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz9"], "nr": 758, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-24T00:47:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpbwk7tp3ga34d", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-24T00:47:03Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpcr9bk0b0s37g", "to": "lpbwk7tlol634c", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-24T15:06:23Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lpbwk7tlol634c", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-24T15:54:48Z", "cid": "lpcszlk7cd71kz", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "to": "lpbwk7tlol634c", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-11-24T16:46:00Z", "cid": "lpcutfiziqy1ce"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Quiz 9 Version A SA 1: How does this answer work for a = 0, b = 0?", "created": "2023-11-24T00:47:03Z", "content": "

Hello,

I understand applying LHR to $$\lim_{x \to 1} \frac{x^a-1}{x^b-1}$$ will give $$\frac{a}{b}$$, but how does this work if $$a = 0$$ and $$b = 0$$ (since $$a,b\in\mathbb{R}$$)? In this case, the limit would evaluate to 1, but $$\frac{a}{b}$$ is 0/0. Furthermore, even by applying LHR to $$\lim_{x \to 1} \frac{x^0-1}{x^0-1}$$ multiple times will never result in the answer 1, but always result in $$\frac{0}{0}$$. Thus, LHR would not even apply since the derivative of the denominator is always 0. 

I was confused by this during the quiz, so I'm not sure how $$\frac{a}{b}$$ addresses the case when $$a = 0, b = 0$$.

I would appreciate some clarification on this.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz9", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Boris Tatchev", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8ec9go44ps", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 99, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-24T15:06:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-24T15:06:23Z", "content": "Ahh, that's a good point. In the case where $$b=0$$, we actually have DNE as an answer since $$\frac{x^a-1}{0}$$ is undefined for all $$x\in\mathbb{R}$$. Hence, we can't even take a limit in that situation (similar to taking $$\lim_{x\to0^-} \sqrt{x}$$).

I'll add a note to the solution and reupload shortly."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpcr9bjwnvy37f", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Sounds good. I ended up putting DNE for this reason, so I am assuming my answer would also be correct?

Thank you.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 759, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-25T17:41:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljiwjbjse314qh", "data": "lpec8trig23fs", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-25T17:41:38Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lpf3m29juol5km", "to": "lpec8trdd6qfr", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-26T06:27:45Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "ljiwjbjse314qh", "subject": "Proof Question: "Let" vs "If"", "created": "2023-11-25T17:41:38Z", "content": "What's the difference between using the word "Let" vs "If" to specify something in a proof? Are they synonyms? For example from a sequence limit proof: "Let \u03b5 > 0 be given. Let N > 2\u03b5/9, N \u2208 N. Then, if n \u2265 N , we get..."? Can we just say let \u03b5 > 0, let N \u2208 N, let N > 2\u03b5/9, let n \u2265 N?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 77, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-26T06:27:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Haaris Asif", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljiwjbjse314qh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-26T06:27:45Z", "content": "Well there is a difference in proof.

"Let" is more used if you want to define something. It also has similar meanings with "assume" or "suppose". You can consider it as setting a variable in programming languages. Usually if you used "let", then the things defined by "let" is considered to be true.\u00a0

You start something with "if" in the proof if you want to start an implication. This is the same logic as the "if" statement in programming languages. You want to use "if" to set up a condition or a conclusion, which if a condition is satisfied, then something will be met. Note that the condition after "if" may not be true.

(This is out of the scope of MATH 137 but in CS245/PMATH 330 you will learn more about truth table which "if A then B" means A->B, which also means A implies B, A and B are condition(s) here. You will understand more in depth about if/implication)



"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ljiwjbjse314qh"], "children": [], "id": "lpf3m29gmci5kl", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpec8trdd6qfr", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514442584, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Can it be shown that $$\frac{n!}{n^n}$$ is non increasing and bounded above 0?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "quiz3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 72, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-27T15:22:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-27T15:22:21Z", "content": "The MCT only tells us that a sequence converges, it doesn't tell us what it converges to, so you wouldn't be able to use the MCT to find the specific limit of a sequence."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lph25ey8sfuc8", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Wait I thought MCT told us that the sequence converges to the LUB/GLB if the sequence is non-decreasing/non-increasing and bounded above/below?", "created": "2023-11-27T20:03:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "ljiwjbjse314qh", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Right, that's true, but finding the lub/glb is something external to the MCT.", "created": "2023-11-27T20:04:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lphc8r59fmh3og", "updated": "2023-11-27T20:04:53Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "In this specific case, we can show that the GLB is 0, right? since $$1\leq n!\leq n^{n}$$ and $$0< \frac{n!}{n^{n}}\leq 1$$? Is the problem with using induction instead that it doesn't tell us if the lower bound is a GLB? If we can show that the sequence is both decreasing and show/find a GLB, we can still say it converges to 0 by MCT, right?", "created": "2023-11-27T20:10:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "ljiwjbjse314qh", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lphcfi8cj1j3rr", "updated": "2023-11-27T20:15:36Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

It's not clear why glb would be 0 given what you've written. For example, how do we know there isn't an $$\epsilon > 0$$ such that $$\frac{n!}{n^n} > \epsilon$$?  And so $$\epsilon$$ would then be the glb. I think the simpler technique here would be to use the squeeze theorem.

Yes, the induction won't tell us whether the bounds we pick are the glb or lub.

Side note: the inductive step isn't clear to me either: for example, I think that you should be trying to show $$a_{n+2} = a_{n+1}\dfrac{(n+2)(n+1)^{n+1}}{(n+2)^{n+2}}$$.

So by mvt, we know there is a x in (a,b) such that f'(x) = (f(a) - f(b))/(a-b) < M(a-b)/(a-b) = M.

Since f(x) is continuous on R, we know that |f'(x)| < M

", "created": "2023-11-27T15:28:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Minor point: you'd first need to add absolute values on the expression before you can use $$|f(x)-f(y)| \leq M|x-y|$$

Major point: I don't think this works because you've only shown it to be true for $$x\in(a,b)$$, however, the question is asking for us to show it to be true for ALL $$x\in\mathbb{R}$$. So you'd have to re-work the proof a bit more.

", "created": "2023-11-26T23:23:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "This looks like an application of MVT but the function is not continuous on this interval so I'm not sure how they found this. Maybe someone else can clarify on this? ", "created": "2023-11-27T14:04:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lpgzd922sf72fp", "updated": "2023-11-27T14:04:28Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

You're on the right track, the equation is the result of the MVT. As you pointed out though, the function is not continuous so you cannot apply the MVT to get the conclusion instantly.

Instead, you can write the equation for $$f'(c)$$ and the equation for $$\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}$$ and see if you can convince yourself that you can always find a value for $$c$$ so that LHS = RHS.

", "created": "2023-11-27T15:19:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lph22buurbc2z0", "updated": "2023-11-27T15:19:57Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpg3wmgtwu5716", "updated": "2023-11-27T15:19:58Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-27T13:58:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-27T13:58:11Z", "content": "

That notation is saying "the sum of the function values at each of the local extrema is equal to 0". So what you have to do is find the local extrema (you should find there are 2: a local min at $$-\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}$$ and a local max at $$\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}$$, you can easily verify this on desmos). Then, you take the function values of those extrema (ie: plug $$-\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}$$ and $$\sqrt{\frac{1}{3}}$$ into the original function) and add those results together. You should find the sum is 0, thus this statement is true. 

You might want a calculator, especially for doing the derivative tests and plugging in the extrema into the function. 

Let me know if you want more clarification on the steps I took!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 768, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-27T01:27:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "data": "lpg8bumwk0f42g", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-27T01:27:33Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lpgx7ngcgho4sa", "to": "lpg8bumtjuo42f", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-27T13:04:07Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "subject": "Concept", "created": "2023-11-27T01:27:33Z", "content": "Why can't constant function have inflection points?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 93, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-27T13:04:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-27T13:04:07Z", "content": "

Graphically, a constant function is just a horizontal line, so it is neither increasing nor decreasing, nor does it have any concavity. So, no poi where concavity changes.

\n

\n

In terms of calculus, when you take the first derivative of a constant function, you get 0. Then, you take the second derivative and also get 0. So there's no concavity (where f''(x)>0 or <0), so concavity can't change and result in a poi.

computing the derivative of |x|?", "created": "2023-11-27T22:21:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

It sort of depends. For example, you could write

$$f(x) =|x| = \begin{cases} x \ \text{ if } x\geq 0 \\ -x \ \text{ if } x < 0 \end{cases} $$ 

and then calculate

$$f'(x) = \begin{cases} 1 \ \text{ if } x > 0 \\ -1 \text{ if } x < 0 \end{cases}$$.

Alternatively, you can use the chain rule for $$f(x) = |x| = \sqrt{x^2}$$ so that

$$f'(x) = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x^2}} 2x = \frac{x}{|x|}$$.

In either case, you'd need to use the limit definition to determine whether $$f(x)$$ is differentiable at $$x=0$$.

we're not actually plugging $$\epsilon$$ into the sequence definition, right? Because $$\epsilon$$ isn't a natural number? This is just how it ends up because of the algebra we did on the original inequality with n, N, and $$\epsilon$$, right?

", "created": "2023-11-28T07:49:54Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "ljiwjbjse314qh", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lpi1ff15c422wu", "updated": "2023-11-28T07:50:31Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "We are plugging in into an inequality, rather than the sequence itself.", "created": "2023-11-30T14:22:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lplac47qjra2st", "updated": "2023-11-30T14:22:35Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpi0ehj698z2p2", "updated": "2023-11-30T14:22:38Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-30T14:20:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Haaris Asif", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljiwjbjse314qh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T14:20:50Z", "content": "

I would say yes, that is an issue because you are assuming the conclusion at the beginning of your proof. 

Basically, you shouldn't assume that $$|a_n - L |< \epsilon$$ at the beginning. Instead, you should derive this relationship in your calculation and your choice for $$N$$.

In the posted solution, notice that we start with $$|a_n - L|$$ and do a series of simplifications to get to $$|a_n - L| = \frac{2}{9n-3}$$.

Then, since $$n \geq N$$, we have $$\frac{2}{9n-3} \leq \frac{2}{9N-3}$$.

Finally, since we picked $$N>\frac{1}{9} (\frac{2}{\epsilon} + 3)$$, this means $$\frac{2}{9N-3} < \epsilon$$ (after simplification).

The main point is that the logical structure of the proof is important. You start with $$|a_n-L|$$ and then show that your choice of $$N$$ leads to a $$<\epsilon$$ at the end.

Does f have to be continuous at x = 0 for it to be an inflection point, or can it just be in the domain with f''(0) = 0 or DNE? 

Thank you for the help!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz10", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 78, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-29T16:55:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-29T16:55:37Z", "content": "

I think it has to be continuous at that point. Here's the definition from the textbook:

When you say "in the domain with f''(0) = 0 or DNE" I assume you're referring to endpoints and/or jump discontinuities? In either of those cases, you would not be able to assess the concavity of at least one side, so you would not be able to conclude that concavity changes.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz10"], "nr": 792, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-29T14:59:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpjw87c0i2j49c", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-29T14:59:52Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lpjz632eyu72wq", "to": "lpjw87bx9l649b", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-29T16:22:12Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpkab6nsbxk1zz", "to": "lpjw87bx9l649b", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-29T21:34:05Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice quiz q2: Can points of inflection be non-critical points", "created": "2023-11-29T14:59:52Z", "content": "

Is it true that some points of inflection can be at non-critical points?

For instance -- I know that the local extrema in this graph are critical points, but is it fair to say that there is an inflection point some where between (-1, 0) and (0, 1), since it seems like there must be a point in these intervals where the concavity has changed?

This is the graph from practice quiz MC question 2:

I'm wondering this because the answer to the question related to this graph seems to imply that there is a constant concavity between (-1, 0) and (0, 1), when I think that there should be a point where the concavity changes?

So a couple of questions:

1. Can inflection points be non-critical points

2. Is there an inflection point at (-1, 0) and (0, 1)

3. If so, wouldn't this mean that the explanation is partially incorrect, since we can't conclude that there is a constant direction in concavity between the intervals?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz10", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 98, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-29T16:22:12Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-29T16:22:12Z", "content": "

First, I want to mention that you might be misinterpreting this question. It says this is a graph of the first derivative, not of the function itself. I got confused when first looking at that question and I always make the mistake of treating it as the function instead of the derivative. 

That in mind, to answer your questions:

1. Yes, poi don't have to be critical points. POI are where the second derivative is 0 or DNE, CP's are where the first derivative is 0 or DNE. A POI doesn't imply a critical point. You can see an example of this in Lec 31 006_Kotecha (Curve Sketching) notes on Learn (at the point (-1, 0) on the final sketch). Let me know if you need help finding it.

2. No, since this is a graph of the first derivative, we can see that it is increasing on (-1, 0), thus f"(x) >0 on this interval. Similarly, the graph is decreasing on (0, 1) so f"(x)<0 on this interval. There is no poi on these intervals. (although I think the local extrema of this graph would be poi since f"(x)=0 there)

3. Again, you would be correct if this were the function itself, but since this is the first derivative we have to treat it differently. I think the concavity of this graph would be the third derivative but I'm not sure. 

Hope that helps, happy to clarify further! 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "lkqwec73jwh6mz"], "children": [], "id": "lpjz632axo2wn", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-29T21:34:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Anika Smith", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1701090248}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-29T21:34:05Z", "content": "

The student answer is correct, however, I would like to clarify one thing: points where $$f''(c) =0$$ or $$f''(c)$$ DNE are not necessarily inflection points, they are candidate inflection points. (Analogously, points where $$f'(c) = 0$$ and $$f'(c)$$ DNE are not necessarily local extrema, they are candidate local extrema.)

An inflection point at $$x=c$$ requires that concavity change sign around $$c$$ and that $$f(x)$$ is continuous at $$c$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8iusqnz5hk"], "children": [], "id": "lpkab6nrh0c1zy", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpjw87bx9l649b", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514478429, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz10"], "nr": 793, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-29T15:33:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpjxf0aljlo1ou", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-29T15:33:09Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lpjzj962x743lz", "to": "lpjxf0ai4pu1ot", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-11-29T16:32:26Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "ljiwjbjse314qh", "to": "lpjxf0ai4pu1ot", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-11-29T18:01:03Z", "cid": "lpk2p7ebwgv100"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice Quiz Question 4: Where does (x-a)! come from", "created": "2023-11-29T15:33:09Z", "content": "

I understand that $$\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}(x-a)+f(a)$$ is the secant line that forms between a and b, but where does $$(x-a)!$$ come from?

More importantly, what is the significance of the statement $$f(x)\leq f(a) + \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b-a}(x-a)!$$ and what does that prove?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz10", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 83, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-29T16:32:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Oscar Liu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwd1pdujw4wz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Rosemary Liao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdh2s3927me", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Haaris Asif", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljiwjbjse314qh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Kai Huang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwccxlksg732", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-29T16:32:26Z", "content": "

It seems like your question mostly revolves around the use of "!" after (x-a). I think that is just meant to be punctuation instead of a factorial. The endless cycle of math symbol confusion continues...

Just to reiterate, all this says is that when a graph is concave up, each point on the graph is $$\leq$$ the secant line, otherwise written $$f(x) \leq f(a) + \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}(x-a)$$

The MVT doesn't apply here since $$f(x)$$ is discontinuous in $$[-1,1]$$.

Instead, you can calculate $$f'(c)$$ and $$\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}$$ and see if you can convince yourself that there is always an $$c \in(-1,1)$$ that satisfies the RHS,

[SPOILER: IIRC, one idea is that the range of values of $$f'(c)$$ on $$c\in(0,1)$$ is all real numbers. Hence, no matter what $$a,b$$ are, you can always find some $$c$$ that satisfies the equation. Not sure if there's a simpler way.]

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz10"], "nr": 803, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-29T22:16:12Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpkbtcj5iix3ae", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-11-29T22:16:12Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpkdh7p31h23k", "to": "lpkbtcj2533ad", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-11-29T23:02:46Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Equivalent functions: one has inflection, other doesn't?", "created": "2023-11-29T22:16:12Z", "content": "

Practice question 3 has the function (which has an inflection point at x=0):

Another function (which I believe is equivalent), doesn't have an inflection point (according to stackexchange), but I don't understand why one has and one doesn't have inflection:

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz10", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 73, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-29T23:02:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-29T23:02:46Z", "content": "You're correct that both functions are equivalent.

In both cases you should find that $$f''(0)$$ DNE and hence you have a possible inflection point. When $$x>0$$, $$f''(x) = 2 $$ and when $$x<0$$, $$f''(x) = -2$$. Since the concavity changes signs at $$x=0$$ and the function is continuous at $$x=0$$, this means that $$x=0$$ is an inflection point."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpkdh7p0stk23j", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpkbtcj2533ad", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514490235, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I think you overlooked the part that said that f''(c) is continuous.

Note, f(x)=x^1/3 is continuous at 0 and has an inflection point at 0, BUT  (f''(x) = -2/(9x^5/3)), DNE at 0.

In our case, f'' IS continuous AND it has an inflection point, so it's true.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_2", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T18:16:32Z", "content": "I think you overlooked the part that said that f''(c) is continuous. Since, f(x)=x^1/3 is NOT continuous at 0 (f''(x) = -2/(9x^5/3)), that's why f''(0) does not exist."}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T18:15:17Z", "content": "f''(x) is continuous"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lplind0bffm2te", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-11-30T18:31:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T18:31:15Z", "content": "

If $$f(x)$$ has an inflection point at $$x=0$$, then either $$f''(0)=0$$ or $$f''(0)$$ DNE. Since $$f''(x)$$ is continuous, then it must be $$f''(0) = 0$$.

Another way to think about it: if $$x=0$$ is an inflection point then the concavity changes signs. Suppose that $$f''(x)<0$$ for $$x<0$$, and $$f''(x) > 0$$ for $$x>0$$. Since $$f''(x)$$ is continuous, then by the IVT we must have $$f''(0) = 0$$.  (Similar argument for $$f''>0$$ and $$f'' < 0$$).

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-11-30T18:31:08Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 806, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-01T02:58:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpm1crd15juil", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-01T02:58:55Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpmorruwscd2zg", "to": "lpm1crcycpiij", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-01T13:54:26Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Question about Critical Points", "created": "2023-12-01T02:58:55Z", "content": "Are all global extrema also critical points?\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 79, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-01T13:54:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-01T13:54:26Z", "content": "

Given a continuous $$f(x)$$ on $$[a,b]$$, if the global extrema is at $$c\\in(a,b)$$, then it is a local extrema and all local extrema are critical points.

\n


If the global extrema is at $$a$$ or $$b$$ (ie the endpoints), I would argue they are not local extrema and not CP.

Can someone please explain how to go about this question and how they got some of those answers?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-04T18:34:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-04T18:34:07Z", "content": "

We want to find $$N$$ such that if $$n\geq N$$, we have $$2+n^2>M$$.

So we want $$2+n^2 \geq 2+N^2 >M \Rightarrow N > \sqrt{M-2}$$.

Now, any $$N$$ that is bigger than our cutoff $$\sqrt{M-2}$$ will work.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 817, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-03T01:05:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpos6l3s4lh2lk", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-03T01:05:29Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpr95l6k30f2w4", "to": "lpos6l3oklt2lj", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-04T18:36:08Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice Midterm W23", "created": "2023-12-03T01:05:29Z", "content": "

Can someone please explain how this proof proves continuity? Is it proving that the limit exists at every a?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 87, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-04T18:36:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-04T18:36:08Z", "content": "

This is using the formal definition of continuity. The proof show that for any $$\epsilon > 0$$, we can specify $$\delta = \min(A, \epsilon/B)$$ such that if $$|x-a|<\delta$$, then we get $$|f(x) - f(a)| < \epsilon$$.

Since $$a$$ is taken to be arbitrary, it means that we've shown continuity at any $$a$$, so $$f(x)$$ is continuous on $$\mathbb{R}$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpr95l6gkb82w3", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpos6l3oklt2lj", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514505207, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz1"], "nr": 824, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-03T21:03:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lppyz2leccl331", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-03T21:03:22Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lpq2kieoq92gk", "to": "lppyz2la2hc330", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-03T22:44:01Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Triangle Inequality", "created": "2023-12-03T21:03:22Z", "content": "

4 (b) ||x| \u2212 |y|| \u2264 |x \u2212 y| for all x, y \u2208 R \u21d2 True

can anyone come up with a formal proof this q? or some tips to approach?

\n

\n

thanks.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 59, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-03T22:44:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-03T22:44:01Z", "content": "It's the reverse triangle inequality:
$$Write\\;||x| - |y|| \\leq |x-y|\\; as\\;-|x-y|\\leq|x|-|y|\\leq|x-y|$$

You can start with
$$ |x| = |x - y + y|$$
$$|x - y + y| \\leq|x-y|+|y|, by\\;\\triangle\\;inequality$$
$$ |x|-|y|\\leq|x-y|$$

Then you can prove the negative by starting with $$|y| = |y-x+x|$$, and using the same method."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ixjsn8icw2y1c3"], "children": [], "id": "lpq2kiejfhg2gj", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lppyz2la2hc330", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514512667, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz2"], "nr": 834, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-05T07:15:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lps0amjw5w34wm", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-05T07:15:53Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lpssgu24bgb42m", "to": "lps0amjtdln4wj", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-05T20:24:32Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lptqjy6afdo5to", "to": "lps0amjtdln4wj", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-06T12:18:44Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "week 2 outline 6", "created": "2023-12-05T07:15:53Z", "content": "

hi, i dont seem to understand how we arrived at the highlighted areas. i understand the |an - L| part, but i dont understand how we can get to |an-L| < epilson^2 and |an-L| < sqrt(L) * epsilon

thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 70, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-05T20:24:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-05T20:24:32Z", "content": "because we can chose any epsilon value greater than 0. "}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpssgu1zrb442l", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-06T12:18:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-06T12:18:44Z", "content": "Since you know that $$\lim_{n\to\infty} a_n = L$$, this means that for any $$\epsilon_0>0$$, there exists and $$N\in\mathbb{N}$$ such that if $$n\geq N$$, we have $$|a_n - L|<\epsilon_0$$. This means that you can decide how large to make this distance, $$\epsilon_0$$. You're goal is to show that $$|\sqrt{a_n} - \sqrt{L}|< \epsilon$$, so to that end, we pick $$|a_n-L|<\sqrt{L}\epsilon$$. The rest of the proof follows."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lptqjy68wh25tn", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lps0amjtdln4wj", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514523323, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 835, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-05T17:14:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpslokb86sl3r0", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-05T17:14:35Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpslvjpb7hf1n1", "to": "lpslokb6c593qz", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-05T17:20:01Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lpslokb6c593qz", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-12-05T17:59:14Z", "cid": "lpsn9zkzl0v604", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "to": "lpslokb6c593qz", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-12-05T18:14:38Z", "cid": "lpsntsmb3p42vv"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Taylor's Remainder", "created": "2023-12-05T17:14:35Z", "content": "Will Taylor's Remainder be tested on the exam? (wasn't sure if that counted as part of the Taylor's Theorem)"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 138, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-05T17:20:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Aaron Gao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8cumgny4hc", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-05T17:20:01Z", "content": "Taylor's inequality is testable.

Taylor's Approximation Theorem 1 (starting on page 276) is not. I'll edit the announcement to clarify this."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8cumgny4hc"], "children": [], "id": "lpslvjp6cc71mz", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Sorry does that mean TAT1 will or won’t be on the exam? Thanks ", "created": "2023-12-05T17:59:14Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

TAT1 will not. Specifically, we won't give you a question like "Use TAT1 to determine $$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0} \frac{e^x-1-x}{x^2}$$."

However, we can ask you something like "find an upper bound on the error in approximating $$\sqrt{2}$$ using $$T_{3,0}(x)$$." Here, you would do something like $$|f(x) - T_{3,0}(x)| \leq \frac{|f^{(4)}(c)|}{4!}x^4$$ and find an upper bound on $$f^{(4)}(c)$$.

TAT1 is slightly different in that you use it to find limits of functions with the squeeze theorem.

Does that make sense?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 837, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-05T21:19:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpsuf4fabnu2bx", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-05T21:19:11Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpsvt99q13c6lf", "to": "lpsuf4f73xu2bw", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-05T21:58:10Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "LATEX Assignment", "created": "2023-12-05T21:19:11Z", "content": "

Hi 

As of latex assignment,

do we convert the pdf given to us to latex document form

and wright answers on that

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 841, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-06T02:34:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "data": "lpt5o60nscj77r", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-06T02:34:09Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lptwc2kasgf7mo", "to": "lpt5o60ldaj77p", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-06T15:00:34Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "subject": "Sequential Characterization of Limits", "created": "2023-12-06T02:34:09Z", "content": "Why is it that in sequential characterization when xn=yn, we can not conclude the behaviour towards the limit"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 60, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-06T15:00:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-06T15:00:34Z", "content": "To prove a limit is $$L$$ using sequential characterization, you need to verify that you get the same limit for\u00a0every possible $$x_n$$ (where $$x_n \\to a, x_n \\neq a$$)."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lptwc2k691z7mm", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpt5o60ldaj77p", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514530787, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 842, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-06T02:42:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpt5ycrqi5i4bd", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-06T02:42:04Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lptqmw69xwd1i4", "to": "lpt5ycrnpix4bb", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-06T12:21:01Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lpt5ycrnpix4bb", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-12-06T15:06:13Z", "cid": "lptwjc5qwsz2lv", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "to": "lpt5ycrnpix4bb", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-12-06T16:57:46Z", "cid": "lpu0ism5vad5yu"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Question about indeterminant form", "created": "2023-12-06T02:42:04Z", "content": "

For limits in the form 0/infinity like the picture below, is it always equal 0? Also if it was x -> 0 from the left would the answer be the same or would it be DNE?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 68, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-06T12:21:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-06T12:21:01Z", "content": "

$$0/\infty$$ isn't indeterminate. If you have a limit of the form $$1/\infty$$, this means the denominator is getting bigger and that makes the fraction overall get smaller, i.e., overall $$\to 0$$. In this case, both parts of the limit are making the fraction getting smaller, so the overall limit is just $$0$$.

You can't take the limit as $$x\to0^-$$ since $$\ln(x)$$ is undefined, hence you would have DNE.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lptqmw64i4a1i3", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "So just to confirm the reason this limit goes to zero even though if we simplify it it’s in the form of 0/infinity is because x is approaching zero from the right so it’s technically not exactly zero?", "created": "2023-12-06T15:06:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Just to clarify: the form $$0/\infty$$ is not indeterminate, it is always 0.

In contrast, something like $$\infty/\infty$$ is indeterminate: the limit could evaluate to $$0$$, $$C\in\mathbb{R}$$, $$\infty$$, etc.

When we're talking about limits, the function doesn't necessarily need to reach the value of $$L$$ at $$x=a$$, rather it has to within $$\epsilon$$ distance for any $$\epsilon>0$$ (think back to the formal definition of limits of a function at a point).

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 843, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-06T03:57:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpt8nw0qqdn76d", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-06T03:57:55Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lpt9r1dsdjgeh", "to": "lpt8nw0n27q76c", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-06T04:28:21Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lpt9rc9pwdz14c", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-12-06T04:28:35Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lpt9sh8k6is440", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-12-06T04:29:28Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lpt9ulgcf5l20e", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-12-06T04:31:07Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lpt9vwztxjc5l6", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-12-06T04:32:09Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpv9t1m25c44c4", "to": "lpt8nw0n27q76c", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-07T14:05:27Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "2022 Final Exam Practice Question 6", "created": "2023-12-06T03:57:55Z", "content": "

Hello,

I have been working on the 2022 final exam practice and am completely confused by Q6.

What worries me most is that I can't think of any way to connect this problem to the course material.

We assume that f'(x) is increasing, but we can't assume f is twice differentiable so it feels like a useless hint (since no conclusions about concavity can be made).

The idea of the tangents intersecting seems like it comes out of no where and I can't think of any theorems we learned that deal with things like this.

I would like to ask for help on this question as well as some overall tips on how to approach proofs on the exam. I assume they will be similar to this one in the sense that they will be unlike anything we have seen before. I know part of the proof is being able to think of a solution on the spot but in scenarios like these I would pretty much use up all my time on this question and still not get an answer.

I have similar concerns about Q7 as well :(

Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Milind Singh Meetarbhan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcbcphb86sf", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 145, "children": [{"history_size": 5, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-06T04:28:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Milind Singh Meetarbhan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcbcphb86sf", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "professor", "name": "Eric Bembenek", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "gshu3x2txqf", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-06T04:32:09Z", "content": "

Well, I would always start by listing out (on paper or mentally) the information we have and see where we can go from there. So in this case, we have $$f(x)$$ is differentiable on $$\mathbb{R} \implies f(x)$$ is cts on $$\mathbb{R}$$. We also have the fact that $$f'(x)$$ is increasing (not assuming that the function is twice differentiable), which means that for any $$x_1 < x_2$$, we have $$f'(x_1) < f'(x_2)$$, or in other words, no two tangent lines have the same slope.

Now, let's consider any $$a \in\mathbb{R}$$ and the tangent line at $$x = a$$, we have $$y = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a)$$. For these types of questions, proof by contradiction will probably work out. So let's assume for contradiction that the tangent line intersects $$f(x)$$ for some $$b \in\mathbb{R}, b\neq a$$, which means that $$f(b) = f(a) + f'(a)(b-a)$$. Since $$f(x)$$ is cts for all $$\mathbb{R}$$, we can use MVT, which gives us $$\exists c \in (a,b)$$ (or $$(b,a)$$), such that $$f'(c) = \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a} = f'(a)$$. Since $$c \neq a$$, this implies that the tangent line at $$x=c$$ has the same slope as the tangent line at $$x=a$$, which is a contradiction to our assumptions. Since $$a$$ is arbitrary, every tangent line of $$f(x)$$ only intersects $$f(x)$$ once. Q.E.D.

Since $f(x)$ is cts for all $\mathbb{R}$, we can use MVT, which gives us $\exists c \in (a,b)$ (or $(b,a)$), such that $f'(c) = \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a} = f'(a)$. Since $c \neq a$, this implies that the tangent line at $x=c$ has the same slope as the tangent line at $x=a$, which is a contradiction to our assumptions. Since a is arbitrary, every tangent line of $f(x)$ only intersects $f(x)$ once. Q.E.D.  

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-06T04:28:21Z", "content": "

Well, I would always start by listing out (on paper or mentally) the information we have and see where we can go from there. So in this case, we have $f(x)$ is differentiable on $\mathbb{R} \implies f(x)$ is cts on $\mathbb{R}$. We also have the fact that $f'(x)$ is increasing (not assuming that the function is twice differentiable), which means that for any $x_1 < x_2$, we have $f'(x_1) < f'(x_2)$, or in other words, no two tangent lines have the same slope.

Now, let's consider any $a \in\mathbb{R}$ and the tangent line at x = a, we have $y = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a)$. For these types of questions, proof by contradiction will probably work out. So let's assume for contradiction that the tangent line intersects f(x) for some $ b \in\mathbb{R}, b\neq a$, which means that $f(b) = f(a) + f'(a)(b-a)$. Since $f(x)$ is cts for all $\mathbb{R}$, we can use MVT, which gives us $\exists c \in (a,b)$ (or $(b,a)$), such that $f'(c) = \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a} = f'(a)$. Since $c \neq a$, this implies that the tangent line at $x=c$ has the same slope as the tangent line at $x=a$, which is a contradiction to our assumptions. Since a is arbitrary, every tangent line of $f(x)$ only intersects $f(x)$ once. Q.E.D.  

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "lkqwcbcphb86sf", "gshu3x2txqf"], "children": [], "id": "lpt9r1dnvx9eg", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-07T14:05:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Robert Yan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdmx6iv7yd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-07T14:05:27Z", "content": "

The student answer is correct. I'll also add that when you're giving an abstract problem like this, it is useful to also think about what major theorems are applicable.

In this problem, $$f$$ is differentiable everywhere, so we can certainly apply the MVT, IVT, and EVT. The MVT has a $$f'$$ in it and this problem gives me information related to $$f'$$ whereas IVT, EVT don't talk at all about $$f'$$. So at first glance, it feels like MVT may be useful here.

A slightly different approach would be the following: the tangent line at $$x=a$$ is given by $$L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a)$$. Then, we're asked to show that $$L(x) = f(x)$$ at exactly one point (it's clear that $$L(a) = f(a)$$). We can also re-frame the problem and define $$h(x) = L(x) - f(x)$$ and now we're asked to show that a function has exactly 1 root. Can you think about how we can do that?

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdmx6iv7yd"], "children": [], "id": "lpv9t1m0tk94c3", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwcbcphb86sf"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpt8nw0n27q76c", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 7, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514532947, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 847, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-06T16:51:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpu0aeg0z2a1z3", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-06T16:51:14Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lpumxklbwih1fx", "to": "lpu0aefxfky1z2", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-07T03:25:07Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpv9ewvi9jg3pc", "to": "lpu0aefxfky1z2", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-07T13:54:28Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Bounding derivative for Taylor Approx", "created": "2023-12-06T16:51:14Z", "content": "

Hello,

I was just wondering about how bounding the derivative works when calculating M for our Taylor approx error. Take for example any nth degree derivative of f(x) = sinx. We know we can bound |derivative| by 1 but would we also be correct to select M as 2? Obviously we would lose some accuracy but in the case of TF question like this would it be valid?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 77, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-07T03:25:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-07T03:25:07Z", "content": "Hi, what theorem will be helpful to solve this question?"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpumxkl6hnp1fw", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-07T13:54:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-07T13:54:28Z", "content": "

This would be true.

Since Taylor's equality gives $$|f(x) - T_{n,0}(x)| \leq \frac{M}{(n+1)!} |x|^{n+1}$$. As you pointed, we know that $$M \leq 1$$ and since $$1\leq2$$ so we have

$$|f(x) - T_{n,0}(x)| \leq \frac{1}{(n+1)!} |x|^{n+1} \leq \frac{2}{(n+1)!} |x|^{n+1} $$ .

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwca7ky8m6lh"], "children": [], "id": "lpv9ewvhkng3pb", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpu0aefxfky1z2", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514537196, "default_anonymity": "no"}
