{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz6"], "nr": 859, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-07T22:53:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpvsnmtu7i94iv", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-07T22:53:07Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpwpkz4vrqb3vf", "to": "lpvsnmtpeq24iu", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-08T14:14:51Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpwpnj69kvh5n", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2023-12-08T14:16:50Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Quiz 6A LA2b", "created": "2023-12-07T22:53:07Z", "content": "

Do we have to use the definition of the derivative to find if the derivative exists at a? Or can we just show that $$\lim_{x\to0^-} 2x=\lim_{x\to0^+}xcosx+sinx=0$$?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz6", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 66, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-08T14:14:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Daniel Yang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw91fw8w2x8", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-08T14:16:50Z", "content": "

Yes, you do need to use the definition of the derivative at $$x=0$$ here.

Note that the limit existing for your $$f'(x)$$ doesn't mean the function is differentiable at that point.

For example, consider $$f(x) = \begin{cases} x+1 \ &\text{ if } x \geq 0 \\ x \ &\text{ if } x < 0 \end{cases}$$.

Clearly, we can say that $$f'(x) = \begin{cases} 1 \ &\text{ if } x > 0 \\ 1 &\text{ if } x < 0 \end{cases}$$. We might be tempted to say that $$f'(x) = 1$$ at $$x=0$$ too because of the limits agreeing, however, notice that $$f(x)$$ is discontinuous at $$x=0$$, so it can't be differentiable there.

You can confirm that $$f'(0)$$ DNE using the limit definition of the derivative.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-08T14:14:51Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 868, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-08T03:02:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpw1jq9lqjo6hh", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-08T03:02:02Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpwoxezqepv6ee", "to": "lpw1jq9ik0q6hg", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-08T13:56:31Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Antiderivatives", "created": "2023-12-08T03:02:02Z", "content": "Hi I’m just wondering if there is going to be anything on anti-derivatives on the exam? We went over it in class but we were never asked any questions about it on either quizzes nor practice problems, but it wasn’t explicitly noted that it won’t occur on the exam so I thought I’d ask for clarification.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Jenagan Ramez Kumar", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwccq5hu071o", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 114, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-08T13:56:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-08T13:56:31Z", "content": "

Anti-derivatives are testable material. I probably wouldn't spend much time on them though. In principle, if you can take a derivative, then you can compute the anti-derivative.

The hardest question related to anti-derivatives we could ask would be anti-derivatives of some basic functions, e.g. $$\int \sin(x) + \cos(x) \, dx$$ or $$\int e^x + x \, dx$$ and so on. Remember that, once you've computed the anti-derivative, taking the derivative must give back the integrand so it's very easy to check.

MATH 138 will cover anti-derivatives (and techniques) in much more detail.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpwoxezmkwr6ed", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwec73jwh6mz", "lkqwccq5hu071o"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpw1jq9ik0q6hg", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514559451, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 870, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-08T05:33:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpw6yerl4pd1k8", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-08T05:33:25Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lpwp0naofq732r", "to": "lpw6yeri5ex1k7", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-08T13:59:02Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Does MCT apply to all sequences ?", "created": "2023-12-08T05:33:25Z", "content": "I was answering F2021 TF10 and noticed that the answer was false.

In my notes a sequence is monotonic when non-dec or non-inc or in other words, when it is increasing or decreasing. By that definition, can MCT apply to any sequence that is increasing or decreasing?

Note: I am not saying every sequence converges by MCT, I\u2019m just wondering if MCT can be applied to all sequences.


"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 90, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-08T13:59:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-08T13:59:02Z", "content": "Yes, the MCT can be applied to any sequence that satisfies the conditions. For example, we can say that $$a_n = \\frac{1}{n}$$ is decreasing and is bounded below by $$-1$$, so by the MCT we know it converges. Note that the MCT does not give us the limit directly, that is something we need to do separately. (We do know that the glb of $$a_n$$ will be the limit, but we still need to find the glb.)"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lpwp0naj8rg32q", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpw6yeri5ex1k7", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514561589, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Alexandre Boutot", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8td58i4797", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Aaron Gao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8cumgny4hc", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Milind Singh Meetarbhan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcbcphb86sf", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 114, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-09T17:53:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-09T17:53:05Z", "content": "

I think it has to do with making the function discontinuous.

f(x) = 0 , x = 0

f(x) = 0, x = 1

f(x) = x + 1 (0 < x < 1)

With this, you'd have f(0) = f(1) = 0, and f(x) = x + 1 IS differentiable on (0, 1), but then no c such that f'(c) = 0 exists.

I think that should be right, hope that helps!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz8"], "nr": 875, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-09T16:57:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpyau3mf65i793", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-09T16:57:34Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lpycmy1rkib7as", "to": "lpyau3md4sa792", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-09T17:48:00Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lpyau3md4sa792", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-12-09T17:57:39Z", "cid": "lpyczd1wcnbp3", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8em1rz14rg", "to": "lpyau3md4sa792", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-12-09T18:02:11Z", "cid": "lpyd574g5sc58r"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Quiz 8A MC Question", "created": "2023-12-09T16:57:34Z", "content": "

Could someone please explain the idea of this question? Thanks.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 61, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-09T17:48:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-09T17:48:00Z", "content": "

How I thought about this is that of course we have a local max at x = 0. However recall that the definition of a point being a local max/min is that you can create an interval around that point where it is either >= to every point in that interval, or <= to every point in that interval. 

Since when x is not 0, the function is just 0, a straight line, every point will be equal, and hence will be both local maxes and mins. 

So every c in R is a local min, other than at x = 0, and every c in R is a local max, and we also know that it is a local max at x = 0 (by the function definition). Thus f(x) will have a local max at every c in R

Let me know if theres any flaws in this logic, this is just how I went about approaching the problem. Hope that helps!

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ixjsn8icw2y1c3"], "children": [], "id": "lpycmy1nrnk7ar", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Oh I see, that makes more sense. So you're saying that 1) you know f has a local min at every c except at x=0 since you can't create an interval around x=0 where x=0 <= interval. 2) Contrastingly, again you know f has a local max at every c INCLUDING x=0 since you CAN create an interval around x=0 where x >= interval.", "created": "2023-12-09T17:57:39Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "yup", "created": "2023-12-09T18:02:11Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqw8em1rz14rg", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lpyd574g5sc58r", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-12-09T18:02:12Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpyczd1wcnbp3", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-12-09T18:02:23Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lpyau3md4sa792", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514567028, "default_anonymity": "no"}

So this definition is true:

If f'(x) < 0, then f is decreasing

But the converse if FALSE?:

If f is decreasing, f'(x) < 0

Since we would get the direct limit definition of f'(a), since L(x) at x = a is f(a)", "created": "2023-12-09T20:51:28Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lpyj6vz22ri3xf", "updated": "2023-12-09T20:51:28Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "yes, you are right that L(x) at x=a is f(a) and then the result is f'(a), but here La(x) means just the equation for linear approximation (i.e f(a)+f'(a)(x-a)), if it were La(a) then it would be exactly what you meant", "created": "2023-12-09T20:58:21Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lpyjfqmk4y5il", "updated": "2023-12-09T20:58:21Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Yes, it is 0, could you check the logic on how I did it.

(f(x) - L(x))/(x - a) 

-> (f(x) - f(a) - f'(a)(x - a))/(x - a)

-> (f(x) - f(a) - f'(a)x - af'(a))/(x - a)

At x = a this is a 0/0, so we can use LHR

-> (f'(x) - f'(a))/1             we can get rid of f(a) and af'(a) as they are constants
-> (f'(a) - f'(a))                evaluating at x = a

-> 0

I think this logic make sense, lmk if you agree.

I don't understand it", "created": "2023-12-10T22:50:56Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lq02wdbwpf24b4", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2023-12-10T22:50:56Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

An alternative approach if to just sub in $$L_a(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a)$$. Then, we have

$$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to a} \frac{f(x) - f(a) - f'(a)(x-a)}{x-a}$$. 

Simplifying and recalling the limit definition of $$f'(a)$$ should give you 0 at the end.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 79, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-10T01:11:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-10T01:11:15Z", "content": "

An example of this would be $$f(x) =x^3$$. Note that $$f'(x) = 3x^2$$. By our definition in class, this function is increasing $$\forall x \in \mathbb{R}$$ (even though it looks like it's not increasing at $$x=0$$, at least to me). This is because there is only one, infinitesimally small point where $$f'(x) = 0$$, namely at $$x=0$$, but for all other values of $$x$$ the derivative is positive and $$f(a) < f(b)$$. 

There might be more examples that I can't think of but this is probably the simplest to visualize. Hope that helps! 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ixjsn8icw2y1c3"], "children": [], "id": "lpysgz9lxoy7jr", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I am still not clear, Can someone explain it more? please", "created": "2023-12-10T01:17:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

The question is saying if $$f(x)$$ is differentiable and increasing on $$(a,b)$$, then $$f'(x)>0$$ for all $$x \in (a, b)$$. 

$$f(x) = x^3$$ is a polynomial so it is differentiable, and it is increasing by our definition in class. 

However, $$f'(x) = 3x^2 = 0$$ when $$x=0$$. 

So, we have a function that is differentiable and increasing, however we have shown that $$f'(x) \not > 0$$ at $$x=0$$, so the statement is false. 

Is there a certain part that you are unclear about? I'd be happy to explain anything about the question itself, my example, or any remaining questions you have

I believe the answer to this would be (d). Originally I figured it was (c) but I thought about it for a bit, I'll still walk you through my thinking. Visually, I'm picturing something like this: 

Case 1: the global max is at 6. Take $$f(x) = x$$. If we're only looking at $$x\in [2, 6]$$ then the global max is 6. 

Case 2: the global max is at 2. Take $$f(x) = -x$$. If we're only looking at $$x\in [2, 6]$$ then the global max is 2

.

Case 3: the global max is at 4. Take $$f(x) = - (x-4)^2$$. Here, even without the specified interval, our global max is at 4. 

 

Remember that global extrema can occur at endpoints or at points where $$f'(x) =0$$ OR $$f'(x) = DNE$$. continuity $$\not \Rightarrow$$ differentiability, and the question says nothing about when $$f'(x) = DNE$$. So now, I have this (horrific) function here: 

This graph is continuous, and $$f'(x) = 0$$ only when $$x=4$$ (the derivative doesn't exist at $$x=3$$, you can verify this if needed), however the global maximum is at $$x=3$$. So the global maximum could be wherever really, since we don't know anything about when $$f'(x)$$ DNE. For reference, I graphed this on Desmos:

TLDR: (d) because we could have a global max when $$f'(x)$$ DNE.

I believe this is false. Take the constant function $$f(x) = a$$ for some $$a\in\mathbb{R}$$. $$f$$ is differentiable, with $$f'(x) = 0$$ and $$f''(x) = 0$$, $$\forall a\in\mathbb{R}$$. However, technically all values of $$f$$ are local extremum because $$f(c) = f(x) = a$$. (I included the definition below for reference)

My general approach for these questions is to try and think of a really simple function where the conjecture might be false. Hope that helps, let me know if you need any clarification!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz10", "exam"], "nr": 893, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-10T09:27:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lpza6kmhziv5sq", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-10T09:27:03Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lpzkyxr3xiu4z3", "to": "lpza6kmdmem5sp", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-10T14:29:02Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "quiz 10", "created": "2023-12-10T09:27:03Z", "content": "

Can f' not be <0? since concave up has going down on the left side and going up on the right side

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "quiz10", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-10T14:29:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-10T14:29:02Z", "content": "

Is your question about (b)? I can explain (a) as well if needed.

(b) doesn't say anything about whether $$f'(x) > 0$$, only that it is increasing on $$\mathbb{R}$$. We know that $$f'(x)$$ is increasing since $$f''(x) > 0$$.

It's possible that $$f'(x)<0$$ across the entire interval, but regardless it is still increasing. 

For example, take $$f(x) = 2^{-x}$$. In this example, $$f'(x)=-2^{-x}\ln(2)$$ and $$f''(x)=2^{-x}\ln(2)^2$$. We have $$f''(x)>0$$, and we can see that $$f'(x)$$ is increasing (I like to plot on Desmos to check, but you can easily verify this with methods shown in this course).

Let me know if you need more clarification on anything!

Can you explain it more in depth?\u00a0", "created": "2023-12-11T02:16:26Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Proving $$lim_{x \\to 0} f(x) = f(0)$$ shows that f(x) is continuous at 0.

\n

To clarify, $$lim_{x \\to 0+} f'(x) = lim_{x \\to 0-} f'(x)$$ shows that the derivative/slope approaching $$x = 0$$ from both sides are equal (since $$f'(0)$$ doesn't directly exist) so then $$f(x)$$ would be differentiable at $$x = 0$$.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 75, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-11T01:28:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-11T01:28:59Z", "content": "

$$T_{n,a}(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x-a) + f''(a)(x-a)^2/2 + ... + f^{(n)}(a)(x-a)^n /n!$$.

This is how I proved it, idk if its 100% correct but....

First prove existence. Sub in 0 into the equation and show that you'll get 1=1.

Then assume for contradiction there's another number where that equation is true. Call it b.

Now note that the equation is the function from part b, just rearranged and set to equal zero.

This function satisfies the conditions of the theorem from part a, since:

f(0)=0 and f'(x) > f(x), as proven in part b and and the existence part of part c.

So by the theorem in part a), f is always increasing. Then we can't have that f(b)=0 since the definition of increasing is that for x1 < x2, f(x1) < f(x2).

So we have arrived at a contradiction and we must have that there is only one solution, 0.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Alexandre Boutot", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8td58i4797", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 134, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-12T14:22:54Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Taehyeon Kim", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwehero027lg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-12T14:22:54Z", "content": "In part (a), looks like you use MVT on the two intervals and that will give you some values $$f'(c)$$ and $$f'(d)$$ where $$c\\in(0,1)$$ and $$d\\in(2,3)$$. You do something similar in part (b) on the interval $$[c,d]$$ and then you probably have to argue about the maximum and minimum size of $$|c-d|$$ to get the inequality parts."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehero027lg"], "children": [], "id": "lq2fmqflc2kna", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I still can't figure it out, can you give me another hint in the right direction? Thank you!", "created": "2023-12-13T04:42:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Part (a) is just applying MVT to $$[0,1]$$ and $$[2,3]$$, so you should get $$f'(c) = ...$$ for $$c\\in(0,1)$$ and $$f'(d) = ...$$ for $$d\\in(2,3)$$.

In part (b), apply the MVT to $$(c,d)$$ to get that $$f''(a) = \\frac{f'(d) - f'(c)}{d-c}$$ for $$a\\in (c,d) \\subseteq (0,3) $$. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["quiz5"], "nr": 911, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-11T19:56:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lq1c3yzomb128f", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-11T19:56:33Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lq1i5hgmgxw4j6", "to": "lq1c3yzlf028e", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-11T22:45:41Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Sequential Characterization of Limits vs Continuity", "created": "2023-12-11T19:56:33Z", "content": "

In sequential characterization of limits, we require $$x_n \neq a$$.

But in sequential characterization of continuity, we do not have the same requirement (and this is even made note of in the course notes). 

Can someone please explain why this is?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["quiz5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 68, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-11T22:45:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-11T22:45:41Z", "content": "

For limits at a point, we don't necessarily care about what the function is doing at $$x=a$$.

For continuity, we do care about what the function is doing at $$x=a$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lq1i5hgimjk4j5", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lq1c3yzlf028e", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514605544, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 95, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-12T02:36:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-12T02:36:30Z", "content": "If I'm remembering the correct question, once you show that $$g'(x) > 0$$ and that $$g(0)=0$$, this implies that $$g(x) > g(0) = 0$$ if $$x>0$$ by the increasing function theorem or "comparing functions using derivatives" theorem.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lq1qeb6ep7dog", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lq1d82uef941ql", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514606608, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 919, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-11T23:06:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lq1ivx3s3p33hi", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-11T23:06:15Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lq1qihenlri1gt", "to": "lq1ivx3nm8i3hf", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-12T02:39:45Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lq21rg8c2zivt", "to": "lq1ivx3nm8i3hf", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-12T07:54:39Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "data": "lq21rtbgwl11d7", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2023-12-12T07:54:56Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "General Advice on approaching proofs", "created": "2023-12-11T23:06:15Z", "content": "

Hello,

\n

I wanted to ask if any instructors have some general advice on approaching proofs. Although I do all the practice, I still sometimes find that I'm absolutely blank when certain proofs come up. Aside from just memorizing all the theorems and understanding what they say, I would really appreciate some guidance or strategies on how to deal with proofs. Are there some steps/ a process you recommend taking?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Paige Horner", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwd88uya3624", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750, "llazq0fual03ej": 1702407827}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Tanvir Singh Gahunia", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwercwuyh1nc", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 96, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-12T02:39:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-12T02:39:45Z", "content": "

I would say look for patterns in questions. For example, if you see \u201cprove a root exists\u201d you know you would have to use IVT, or if you see some insane limit calculation, see if you could use L\u2019hopitals rule. I would just review the past exams and find patterns in questions.

\n

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lq1qihejpsy1gs", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-12T07:54:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750, "llazq0fual03ej": 1702407827}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sampoorna Prakash", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697050635}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-12T07:54:56Z", "content": "It really depends on what kind of proof you are asking for.

If you are asking to prove something is false, usually you prove it either by contradiction or counter example. If you are proving some results to be true, then you would have to find the clues yourself and use the right theorems to prove it correct.

You may ask, "how do I know what theorem to use when writing proof?" My answer to that is, if you don't know which theorem to use or why we are using this theorem, it's most likely that you didn't fully understand the meaning and purpose of the theorem o.o

If you don't know how to do proof of a question, look at the solution and grasp why the solution is writing in this way. Do not just memorize the solution, as you may not understand the reason why solution write it in this way. After you think "oh okay I think I understand now", try do the question all over again without any help, then compare your answer with the solution see what you are missing. The thing you are missing are likely the knowledge point which you didn't fully understand yet.

Also, mathematics is a rigorous subject. So in your proofs you shouldn't jump steps or not referencing theorems."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kcat0wu2cik59z", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-12T07:54:39Z", "content": "It really depends on what kind of proof you are asking for.

If you are asking to prove something is false, usually you prove it either by contradiction or counter example. If you are proving some results to be true, then you would have to find the clues yourself and use the right theorems to prove it correct.

You may ask, "how do I know what theorem to use when writing proof?" My answer to that is, if you don't know which theorem to use or why we are using this theorem, it's most likely that you didn't fully understand the meaning and purpose of the theorem o.o

If you don't know how to do proof of a question, look at the solution and grasp why the solution is writing in this way. Do not just memorize the solution, as you may not understand the reason why solution write it in this way. After you think "oh okay now I think I understand now", try do the question all over again without any help, then compare your answer with the solution see what you are missing. The thing you are missing are likely the knowledge point which you didn't fully understand yet.

Also, mathematics is a rigorous subject. So in your proofs you shouldn't jump steps or not referencing theorems.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "kggoe9bxe5d42u"], "children": [], "id": "lq21rg8an5fvs", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwd88uya3624", "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "lkqwercwuyh1nc"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lq1ivx3nm8i3hf", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514614372, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 922, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-12T00:39:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lq1m7diw2l52vw", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-12T00:39:08Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lq1m7dirt4h2vv", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-12-12T00:40:13Z", "cid": "lq1m8rbtdn743i", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lq1m7dirt4h2vv", "type": "feedback", "when": "2023-12-12T00:51:18Z", "cid": "lq1mn12rl1346c", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lq1oz56kkpy539", "to": "lq1m7dirt4h2vv", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-12T01:56:43Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lq1m7dirt4h2vv", "type": "followup", "when": "2023-12-12T03:09:41Z", "cid": "lq1rkzlhx691la", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice final confusion", "created": "2023-12-12T00:39:08Z", "content": "

Where do the power of cos(x)+1 and cos(x)-1 come from? Why not just -ln(sin(x))*sin(x)+ (cos(x))^2/ sin(x) for d/dx?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 75, "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "what question is that?", "created": "2023-12-12T00:40:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "It's simply calculating the derivative of sin(x) raised to the power of cos(x)", "created": "2023-12-12T00:51:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lq1mn12rl1346c", "updated": "2023-12-12T00:51:19Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lq1m8rbtdn743i", "updated": "2023-12-12T02:33:22Z", "config": {}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-12T01:56:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Junyan Ye", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwb17ooi55le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-12T01:56:43Z", "content": "

I can explain the second line with $$\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)}$$ if needed, but it seems like you understand that from your question. 

Then, we want to solve just for $$f'(x)$$, so we need to multiply both sides by $$f(x) = \sin(x)^{\cos(x)}$$.

So we get $$f'(x) = -\sin(x)\ln(\sin(x))\sin(x)^{\cos(x)} + \cos(x) \cdot \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)} \cdot \sin(x)^{\cos(x)} $$.

Then, we can simplify with exponent laws to get $$f'(x) = -\ln(\sin(x))\sin(x)^{\cos(x)+1} + \cos^2(x) \sin(x)^{\cos(x)-1} $$.

Let me know if you need more clarification on any of these steps, best of luck on the exam!

the posted solutions say that δ = min(6ε,1) when I believe it should be δ = min(4ε,1)

above is a screenshot from desmos graphing the inequalities where green is represents |x-3| < δ and purple represents |(3x+1)/(x+2) - 2| < ε

below is a screenshot of what I believe to be correct

 an ε - δ proof is an implication if the distance from x to an arbitrary point "a" is less than some δ provided δ > 0 then the distance from f(x) to an arbitrary point f(a) is less than some ε provided ε > 0

with the posted solution there are counter examples such as the following:

|x_1 - 3| - δ is < 0 which means  |x_1 - 3| < δ

but |(3x_1 + 1)/(x_1 + 2) - 2| - ε is > 0 which means

|(3x_1 + 1)/(x_1 + 2) - 2| > ε and not less than ε

the posted solutions say that δ = min(6ε,1) when I believe it should be δ = min(4ε,1)

above is a screenshot from desmos graphing the inequalities where green is represents |x-3| < δ and purple represents |(3x+1)/(x+2) - 2| < ε

below is a screenshot of what I believe to be correct

 an ε - δ proof is an implication if the distance from x to an arbitrary point "a" is less than some δ provided δ > 0 then the distance from f(x) to an arbitrary point f(a) is less than some ε provided ε > 0

with the posted solution there are counter examples such as the following:

|x_1 - 3| - δ is < 0 which means  |x_1 - 3| < δ

but |(3x_1 + 1)/(x_1 + 2) - 2| - ε is > 0 which means

|(3x_1 + 1)/(x_1 + 2) - 2| > ε and not less than

"should the answer use delta= epsilon/4 instead"

ε/4 works because ε/4 < 4ε

however, you should use 4ε because it was determined from the initial assumption

|x - 3| < δ  

assume  δ < 1

|x - 3| < 1
-1 < x - 3 < 1
4 < x + 2 < 6
1/(x + 2) > 1/4
it is important that the constant is less than so we can "downshift" our value and be assured it is actually less than
when we simplify |(3x+2)/(x+2)|  ---> |1/(x+2)||x-3| < ε
we can confidently say that |1/4||x-3| < ε is still true because |1/4| < |1/(x+2)|

|x-3| < 4ε

therefore choose δ = min(1, 4ε)
minimum of 1 and 4ε because this proof relies on |x-3| < 1

Some key points about this question:

- $$f$$ is defined on the closed interval, not necessarily continuous (in fact, I don't think it's possible for it to be continuous, given the other properties)

- $$f$$ is strictly decreasing on the open interval.

The little diagram doesn't do a good job at explaining the whole picture, so I'll draw another one to hopefully clarify things:

Another thing I'll point out is this example from the course notes, just under the definition of global extrema:

So we can see that there is no global maxima or minima in this function, since we are getting infinitely close to a global extrema but never reaching it.

Hi, 

I am confused on how to evaluate the following limits. 

In the above question, I multiplied it by the conjugate and simplified. I am unsure on how the answer is 0. 

For the question below, I do not know where to begin. 

Could someone guide me in the right direction? 

Thank you in advance. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 81, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-12T16:21:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nadia Anwar", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdnjctl125", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Tanvir Singh Gahunia", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwercwuyh1nc", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Lydia He", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwclm3shhvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-12T16:48:44Z", "content": "

For (m), multiplying by the conjugate should have brought you to $$ 0$$. You'll actually end up with $$\lim\limits_{x\to\infty} \frac{-3}{\sqrt{x^2-2}+\sqrt{x^2+1}}$$ once you multiply by the conjugate and simplify.

From there, you "plug in" $$\infty$$ to get $$\frac{-3}{\infty}$$ which simplifies to $$0$$. Or you can do the "divide by the highest power" at this step, but I feel like that's less intuitive.

** my bad, my answer for (o) was incorrect, for this question since the left side doesn't exist (can't have a real root of a negative number) the overall limit does not exist

Let me know if you'd like any clarification, best of luck on the exam! 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-12T16:21:02Z", "content": "

For (m), multiplying by the conjugate should have brought you to $$ 0$$. You'll actually end up with $$\lim\limits_{x\to\infty} \frac{-3}{\sqrt{x^2-2}+\sqrt{x^2+1}}$$ once you multiply by the conjugate and simplify.

From there, you "plug in" $$\infty$$ to get $$\frac{-3}{\infty}$$ which simplifies to $$0$$. Or you can do the "divide by the highest power" at this step, but I feel like that's less intuitive.

For (o), I think this is kind of a trick question in that it reminds you to try subbing in $$a$$ from the $$\lim\limits_{x\to a}$$ as your first step. Plug in $$7$$ and you should find the answer! 

Let me know if you'd like any clarification, best of luck on the exam!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 948, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-12T19:10:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lq2px21nzc322j", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-12T19:10:51Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lq2t0mvkvz3z4", "to": "lq2px21ldg22i", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-12T20:37:37Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Newtons Method convergence", "created": "2023-12-12T19:10:51Z", "content": "If the newton's method sequence converges on a function that has a root will it always converge to 0?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 77, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-12T20:37:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Lydia He", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwclm3shhvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-12T20:37:37Z", "content": "

not sure if im getting your question right but
No it won't always converge to 0, it converges to the root.

Newtons method is a way to approximate roots, so if you pick the right initial value and everything goes well for a function f(x), it’ll converge to a value $$x_1$$ where

f($$x_1$$) = 0 

[definition of a root]

Could someone explain this please?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 85, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-12T19:36:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nicole Anne Go", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdqj252r1jl", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sampoorna Prakash", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697050635}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-12T19:37:12Z", "content": "

By log laws, move the exponent 2023 to the front of the fraction as a coefficient. Now we have $$2023* \frac{ln(x)}{e^{x}}$$

By our fundamental log limit this is 2023 * 0

Note that if you don't remember that you can just use L'Hoptial's rule now.

So the answer is actually 0

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-12T19:36:20Z", "content": "

For example:

f(x) = 1     for all x < a

f(x) = -1    for all x >= a

then lim x->a for f(x) DNE since the left and right limits are not equal

but lim x -> a for |f(x)| Does exist since you get f(x) = 1 for all x in R

Let me know if this makes sense!

I was a little confused on this one, but what I did was examine the piecewise and noticed that $$(1+\frac{1}{x})\sin(x)$$ is continuous and differentiable everywhere except possibly at $$x=1$$. So to make sure that it is differentiable there, I use the limit definition of the derivative. 

It's a little janky so let me know if you want clarification on my steps / if you find a mistake 

Steps for the limit definition: 

1- Write it down (helps me formulate my ideas too)

2- Sub in $$(1+\frac{1}{x+h})\sin(x+h)$$ and $$f(0) = 1$$ from the function definition (I then simplified to $$(1+\frac{1}{h})\sin(h)$$ since $$x=0$$)

3- distribute the $$\sin(h)$$

4- separate it into 3 separate fractions 

5- use the fundamental trig limit on $$\frac{\sin(h)}{h}$$

6- simplify to get 1

So the derivative is equal to 1 there, then I just did the derivative of $$(1+\frac{1}{x})\sin(x)$$ and made a piecewise.

We verified both the original function and the derivative on desmos, you'll see a hole in the derivative at (0, 1) which we remove through our piecewise definition. Hope that helps!

Yeah, I think you might be right.

For the forward direction, we can assume that |f(x)| -> 0 as x -> a

Since |f(x)| -> 0, we can say that ||f(x)| - 0| < e

so ||f(x)|| < e

so |f(x)| < e

and f(x) -> 0 is true only if 

|f(x) - 0| < e --> |f(x)| < e,  which we know to be true since assuming |f(x)| -> 0 led to this conclusion.

Based on this isn't the forward direction correct?

||f(x)| - 0| <= |f(x)| + |0| = |f(x)| < e   

so then the reverse is true as well? I'm not sure if this is a valid proof, lmk what you think

Not necessarily! Consider this function: (idk how to do piecewise functions in latex yet sorry)

$$f(x) = x+5$$ when $$x\leq0$$ and $$f(x)=x$$ when $$x>0$$.

This function is increasing on $$x\in(-\infty, 0]\cup (0, \infty)$$, however when we look at this graph we notice that $$f(0) > f(0.0000001)$$ which means that it is decreasing on this interval. 

Here's a Desmos pic for reference: 

It has to jump down from $$x=0$$ to $$x=0.00001$$ so it is not increasing here.

Hope that helps!

I'm not 100% on this one.

One of my students presented $$f(x) = x+ \ln(x)$$ as a counterexample, specifically $$f'(-1)=0$$ but $$x=-1$$ is not in the domain of $$f(x)$$ hence it wouldn't be a CP.

At the same time though, since $$f'(c) = 0$$ this means that $$f'(c) = \lim_{h\to 0}\frac{f(c+h) - f(c)}{h}$$ exists. So, implicitly, it seems like the question is suggesting that $$c$$ is in the domain of $$f$$. Note that in the counterexample, we wouldn't have that $$f'(-1)=0$$ by the limit definition.

So, evaluate $$g(3)=3+3=6$$ then you know $$c=6$$ to make your function continuous!\u00a0

I believe the idea here is that {an} converges to L as we go to infinity. {an} is defined as $$f(n)$$, so when we take $$f(n^2)$$ we are essentially taking a subsequence of {an} where we are only looking at the square number terms (1, 4, 9, etc).

We know {an} converges, to logically this subsequence of {an} which should have the same behaviour as {an} will also converge to the same L.

There may be a better, more sound way of looking at this but this is how I understood it.

To my knowledge, this is possible (and it was a T/F question in quiz 10a). This is due to the following definintions.

Local extrema: Assuming the function is continuous, there is exists a c in interval [a, b] such that f(c) is the max or min value.

Inflection point: If f(x) is continous at x=c and the concavity of f changes at f(c). This doesn't require f''(c) =0.

Finally consider this piecewise function as counter-argument below. Hope it helps!

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwc7am5pi62a", "gshu3x2txqf", "lkqwercwuyh1nc"], "children": [], "id": "lq32uzfllnw504", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lq31zab7gdi3hn", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514671991, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 975, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T01:08:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lq32p3d57p93o6", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-13T01:08:35Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lq3ab7zayn729t", "to": "lq32p3d1ytx3o5", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-13T04:41:45Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "local max/min/poi for constant functions", "created": "2023-12-13T01:08:35Z", "content": "

Hey all,

\n

I'm still a little confused on the rules for constant functions (and the zero function) and how we interpret their derivatives. We know f' = 0 for all x, and f'' = 0 for all x.
Does this mean every x value in a constant function is a local max/min?

\n

What can we say about the concavity of constant functions/the zero function?

Yes, every value is a local max/min and by extension a global max/min
The concavity is neither concave up nor concave down since it is always 0.\u00a0

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 980, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T03:11:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lq3733z5yzm7lr", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-13T03:11:27Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lq3r67v47xm3f6", "to": "lq3733z2h3e7lq", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-13T12:33:45Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Trivial theorem", "created": "2023-12-13T03:11:27Z", "content": "Is it fine if i ommit some of the thrivial theorems/ idea when i am solving problem, i.e. product rule, chain rule"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 101, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T12:33:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-13T12:33:45Z", "content": "You don't need to cite the minor theorem like limits rules, differentiation rules, etc and you\u00a0do need to cite the major theorems, like squeeze theorem, MCT, IVT, etc.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lq3r67v0nlh3f5", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lq3733z2h3e7lq", "config": {"editor": "plain", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514679444, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 981, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T03:23:49Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lq37j0gzg9h421", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-13T03:23:49Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "data": "lq3ilkekwvv7as", "to": "lq37j0gwzx1420", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-13T08:33:44Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "F22 7aii", "created": "2023-12-13T03:23:49Z", "content": "I did not understand 7aii. Would appreciate if someone explained"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 127, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T08:33:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-13T08:33:44Z", "content": "


$$g'(x) = \frac{f'(x)-f(x)}{e^x}$$

We know from the question that f'(x) > f(x) for all x 
So, f'(x) - f(x) >0 and since $$e^2x >0$$, then g'(x) has to be positive for all values

And we know if g'(x)>0 then g(x) is increasing.

Then you proceed by smacking cases at the wall to see what sticks, for x>0 and x<0.

If x>0 , since g(x) is increasing, for any point >0

g(x) > g(0) 

Replace and use f(0) = 0 to get rid of f(0) 

If x<0, again since g(x) is increasing, [at this point, I think there's a typo in the solution where they use f(x) instead of g(x)] 

g(x) < g(0) 

Same thing as first case.



"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lq3ilkegg797ar", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lq37j0gwzx1420", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514680515, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I got

Triangle Inequality 

Monotonic Convergence Theorem (MCT)

is there anything I'm missing?

Let me know if you need any clarification! "}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lq39xreyqg81s7", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "how I went about this one is if f'(4) = 0, then x=4 could be a global max OR a global min. The question says the global max "must" be at a certain point but you can't say that point for sure. So none of the above MUST be true.", "created": "2023-12-13T15:08:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Junyan Ye", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwb17ooi55le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I'm not sure that would actually contradict this statement. Since this is a closed interval, we are guaranteed a global max by EVT.

You are correct in that $$x=4$$ could be a global min, but I think that only rules out option a). It doesn't give us any indication about the other options provided.

Even if $$x=4$$ is a global min, we could still have a global max at 2 or 6, so the way to show that the answer is "none of the above" is to find where the global max is not at 2, 4, or 6. (like in @890 at the bottom where I showed it at 3)

", "created": "2023-12-13T15:15:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lq3wyfe2of23u3", "updated": "2023-12-13T15:15:39Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

if x=4 is a global min, then a and c are ruled out

if x=4 is a global max (which it could be, you don't know for sure based off the info provided in the question), then b is ruled out 

therefore only d can be true

Don't need to do extra work

What about a function like $$f(x)= (x-4)^2$$?

So there may be more critical points than at x = 4, and that leaves more possibilities for global extremas. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lq3yzb5omwd1jw", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lq39tl4fvfi11y", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 7, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514684785, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Then I compare the interval before it and after it to know increasing or decreasing?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 108, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T13:25:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Junyan Ye", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwb17ooi55le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-13T13:25:30Z", "content": "

The only criteria for a critical point are a) $$f'(c)=0$$ or DNE and b) $$c$$ is in the domain of $$f$$.

So yes, you do need to consider it a critical point. And definitely check intervals of increasing / decreasing around it since something funky might be happening there!

"children": [], "id": "lq3d0ah6utb29x", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "These are actually not indeterminate forms, you can evaluate them. $$\\frac{\\infty}{0}$$ is $$\\infty$$ and $$\\frac{0}{\\infty}$$ is 0.\u00a0

The indeterminate forms listed in lecture are the only ones! (At least as far as I know\u2026) So if they don\u2019t follow in exactly that form, they can be evaluated (or DNE if they\u2019re undefined)

Indeterminate forms: $$\\frac{0}{0}$$, $$\\frac{\\pm\\infty}{\\infty}$$, $$0\\cdot \\infty$$, $$1^{\\infty}$$, $$\\infty^0$$, $$0^0$$, and $$\\infty - \\infty$$\u00a0
If they\u2019re not one of those, we (probably?) know the answer already!
", "created": "2023-12-13T13:12:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "professor", "name": "Eric Bembenek", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "gshu3x2txqf", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Actually, $$\\frac{\\infty}{0}$$ is not $$\\infty$$.\u00a0 For example, $${\\displaystyle \\lim_{x\\to 0}\\frac{e^{1/x^2}}{x}}$$ does not exist since $${\\displaystyle \\lim_{x\\to 0^+}\\frac{e^{1/x^2}}{x}}=\\infty$$, but $${\\displaystyle \\lim_{x\\to 0^-}\\frac{e^{1/x^2}}{x}}=-\\infty$$.", "created": "2023-12-13T14:38:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Alex Fang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw9182jfyvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqw9182jfyvy"], "id": "lq3vm94vjl03o2", "updated": "2023-12-13T15:52:20Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Very interesting, thank you for your insights! Is there a way we could manipulate this limit to apply L'Hopital's rule or are we simply to use the LHL and RHL?", "created": "2023-12-13T14:41:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lq3vqkedomd1rf", "updated": "2023-12-13T14:41:33Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "L'Hopital's Rule will not apply to that limit.\u00a0 All we can say about limits of $$\\frac{\\infty}{0}$$ form is that it will never be a finite real number and this is why such limits are not indeterminate form (it is determined that these limits are not any real number).\u00a0\u00a0", "created": "2023-12-13T16:13:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lq3z0m6h1b811s", "updated": "2023-12-13T16:13:20Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": ["gshu3x2txqf"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lq3sjzqby5g1k2", "updated": "2023-12-13T16:13:20Z", "config": {}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lq3byyjykrt5oz", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 7, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514686929, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 988, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T05:56:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lq3czif4nfniy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-13T05:56:37Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lq3u9ukpiym4vx", "to": "lq3cziezfd3iv", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-13T14:00:33Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Limit Differentiability vs f'(x) existing", "created": "2023-12-13T05:56:37Z", "content": "if the limit definition of f'(x) evaluates to a limit, but the actual point on f'(x) is undefined, do we say f(x) is differentiable or not differentiable, since technically the derivative at every point exists (by the limit definition), but f'(x) is also undefined at this point?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 97, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T14:00:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-13T14:00:33Z", "content": "

If the limit definition of $$f'(a)$$ exists, then $$f(x)$$ is differentiable at $$x=a$$. It cannot be the case that $$f'(x)$$ is undefined at $$x=a$$ and $$f'(a)$$ exists.

\n

\n

There's an example of this on one of the practice finals that I think is leading to this confusion, it's something like $$(1+\\frac{1}{x})\\sin(x)$$ if $$x\\neq0$$ and $$1$$ if $$x=0$$. In that situation, you would calculate $$f'(x)$$ normally (with differentiation rules etc) for $$x\\neq0$$ and then use the limit definition at $$x=0$$ to determine where the function is differentiable.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lq3u9ukmsz54vu", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lq3cziezfd3iv", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514687994, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 990, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T09:48:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lq3l983nal31e", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-13T09:48:07Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "data": "lq3qnpjnskq1fg", "to": "lq3l983k41s31c", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2023-12-13T12:19:21Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lq3rdel5aroli", "to": "lq3l983k41s31c", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-13T12:39:20Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lq3rededwb21j2", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-12-13T12:40:05Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lq3relnq7bq1qs", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-12-13T12:40:16Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lq3rhmzmpau4jh", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2023-12-13T12:42:37Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "[FINAL 2019] Limits - Why is this wrong?", "created": "2023-12-13T09:48:07Z", "content": "

Since its indeterminate we rearrange to be able to use LHR. but when you rearrange as follows :

$$\lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{ln(e^x+x)}{x}$$

Using log laws we know : 

$$ln(e^x)*ln(x)$$ and $$ln(e^x) = x $$ so we get

$$\frac{x*ln(x)}{x}$$ and x cancels out, leaving 
$$\lim_{x\to\infty} x = \infty$$

Why is this wrong? 

Thanks

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Cathy Sheng", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8txmlg77co", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 124, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T12:19:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Milind Singh Meetarbhan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcbcphb86sf", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-13T12:19:21Z", "content": "The log laws part is incorrect."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwcbcphb86sf"], "children": [], "id": "lq3qnpjjssp1ff", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T12:39:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Milind Singh Meetarbhan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcbcphb86sf", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-13T12:42:37Z", "content": "Looking at your answer, I got confused too, but I checked log laws to make sure:

You have it backwards where $$\ln(a+ b) = \ln(a)\cdot\ln(b)$$
There’s no rule about simplifying sums/differences within a logarithm, only the sums/differences of separate logarithms

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["exam"], "nr": 991, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T13:11:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lq3sig3cgdq2mg", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-13T13:11:15Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lq3siosaoi331q", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2023-12-13T13:11:26Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lq3srim39ff76p", "to": "lq3sig38iuv2mf", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-13T13:18:18Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Continuity of composition", "created": "2023-12-13T13:11:26Z", "content": "It is false that if f(x) and g(x) are both continuous on the interval [0,1], then g(f(x)) is also continuous on [0, 1]. Can someone provide a counter-example>"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Continuity of composition", "created": "2023-12-13T13:11:15Z", "content": "It is false that if f(x) and g(x) are both continuous on the interval [0,1], then g(f(x)) is also continuous on [0, 1]. Can some provide a counter-example>"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 96, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T13:18:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Erin Fan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwayddv4r53q", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "professor", "name": "Eric Bembenek", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "gshu3x2txqf", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-13T13:18:18Z", "content": "

Consider $$f(x)= x-100$$ and $$g(x) = \ln(x+1)$$. $$f(x)$$ is continuous everywhere since it is a polynomial, and $$g(x)$$ is continuous when $$x>-1$$. So, both functions are continuous on $$x\in[0, 1]$$. 

However, $$g(f(x))=\ln(x-100+1)=\ln(x-99)$$ which is not continuous on $$x\in[0, 1]$$ because $$\ln(x)$$ is not defined for $$x\leq 0$$.

Hope that helps! You can try graphing them on Desmos too-- I find that helpful for understanding. 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwayddv4r53q", "gshu3x2txqf"], "children": [], "id": "lq3srim0beo76n", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lq3sig38iuv2mf", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714514691200, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Looks true to me. Here's a sketch of a proof:

$$\Rightarrow$$: $$\lim_{x\to a}|f(x)| = 0$$ means $$||f(x)| - 0| < \epsilon$$. Notice that $$||f(x)| - 0| = ||f(x)|| = |f(x)| = |f(x) - 0| < \epsilon$$.

$$\Leftarrow$$: $$\lim_{x\to a}f(x) = 0$$ means $$|f(x) - 0| < \epsilon$$. Again, $$|f(x) - 0| = ||f(x)|| = ||f(x)| - 0| <\epsilon$$.

You can also do this with the squeeze theorem, $$-|f(x)| \leq f(x) \leq |f(x)| $$.

I'm not 100% sure which theorem you're referring to so I'll include both for reference.

When $$f'(c)$$ does not exist, you won't be able to evaluate the second derivative.

This does not apply since we won't be able to find what $$f''(c)$$ is. 

This does not apply, since for this theorem we assume $$f'(x) = 0$$ and that $$f''(x)$$ is continuous at $$x=c$$, neither of which are true for the scenario you are describing. You would not be able to evaluate the second derivative at a point where $$f'(x)$$ is discontinuous. 

Hope that helps!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["logistics"], "nr": 996, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T15:27:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lq3xdr8tyxk1qd", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2023-12-13T15:27:34Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lq3xq33nt161mj", "to": "lq3xdr8qavl1qc", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2023-12-13T15:37:09Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Taylor polynomials general Q", "created": "2023-12-13T15:27:34Z", "content": "if our approximating for taylor polynomials is an underestimate, would the new interval would be [Tn,a (x)-error, Tn,a (x)] "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["logistics", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 136, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T15:37:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wania Saqib", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwekj0scwfe", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Doug Park", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "ixjsn8icw2y1c3", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-13T15:37:09Z", "content": "

I think it would be the other way around.

For an underestimate, our taylor polynomial is less than the actual value, so our interval would be $$f(x) \in [T_{n, a}(x),\;\; T_{n, a}(x) +error]$$. Because at the very least, our estimate would be spot on (left side of interval), but likely we are underestimating so it could be anything within our taylor polynomial + error. 

For overestimate, we would have $$f(x) \in [T_{n, a}(x)-error,\;\; T_{n, a}(x)]$$.

TeChnicaLLy, if the question doesn't specify the smallest possible interval, and you are unsure whether to add the error or subtract, you can just say $$f(x) \in [T_{n, a}(x)-error,\;\; T_{n, a}(x) + error]$$. Although tactics like this are generally discouraged (but still valid with justification! ;D )

Do I fail the course and have to redo? Do I have to drop out of my program?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["exam", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 251, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T23:09:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-13T23:09:10Z", "content": "you might want to contact your academic advisor"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lq4dvdyaj44ry", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2023-12-13T23:58:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "gshu3x2txqf", "subject": "", "created": "2023-12-13T23:58:56Z", "content": "

If you score below 50% that is a fail.

\n

\n

If you score between 50 and 60% then you have passed the course, however, you cannot take MATH 138. You can take other courses that don't require a prerequisite 60% in MATH 137 (eg MATH 128). Whether you can take 128 instead of 138 depends on your program.

You should speak with an academic advisor to discuss your particular situation.
